<TABLE>
<TR><TD COLSPAN=5><a name="description"></a>&nbsp;<p><p align='center'><span style='font-family: TIMES;'><strong>2.A.1  The Major Facilitator Superfamily (MFS) </strong></span></p>
<p><span style='font-family: TIMES;'> The MFS is a very old, large and diverse superfamily that includes millions of sequenced members. They catalyze uniport, solute:cation (H<sup>+</sup></span>, but seldom Na<sup>+</sup>) symport and/or solute:H<sup>+</sup> or solute:solute antiport. Most are of 400-600 amino acyl residues in length and possess either 12, 14, or occasionally, 24 transmembrane &alpha;-helical spanners (TMSs).  The mechanistic principles applicable to all MFS carriers have been summarized by Law et al (<span id='ref5641.18537473' class='cite'>2008</span>), while <span id='ref34546361.26234418' class='cite'>Zhang <em>et al.</em> 2015</span> considered the interaction between protonation and the negative-inside
membrane potential. Functional roles of the conserved sequence motifs were also discussed in the
context of the 3D structures. Transporters can be modified posttranslationally by phsophorylation, ubiquitination, glycosylation and/or palmitoylation (<span id='ref34549155.29966598' class='cite'>Czuba <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). The mammalian proteins have been analyzed from phylogenetic standpoints, revealing three major groups with differing conserved residues (<span id='ref34549648.30888203' class='cite'>Jia <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>). Proteins of different topologies were also identified. <span id='ref34551367.32373195' class='cite'>Hu <em>et al.</em> 2020</span> reviewed the main substrates and functions of SLCs that are expressed in the brain, with an emphasis on selected SLCs that are important physiologically, pathologically, and pharmacologically in the blood-brain barrier, astrocytes, and neurons. The glucose (hexose) transporters, GLUTs, TC# 2.A.1.1, have been reviewed (<span id='ref34551865.32591905' class='cite'>Holman 2020</span>; <span id='ref34555214.35955833' class='cite'>Ismail and Tanasova 2022</span>). Single-molecule FRET studies of membrane transport proteins has revealed their conformational flexibilities (<span id='ref34553122.33945656' class='cite'>L&ouml;w <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>). All MFS porters have the MFS fold (<span id='ref34555317.36164651' class='cite'>Ferrada and Superti-Furga 2022</span>).&nbsp;<span id='ref34556623.37298344' class='cite'>Anagnostakis <em>et al.</em> 2023</span> discuss the key structural and functional characteristics of SLC family members involved in glioma pathogenesis, and active ion transmembrane transporter activities were overrepresented in patients with Alzheimer's disease (<span id='ref34557368.37762226' class='cite'>D'Angiolini <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). Similarly, Parkinson's disease involves activation of ion transporters via the Leucine Rich Repeat Kinase 2 (LRRK2) in miroglia of mice (<span id='ref34557369.37745519' class='cite'>Nazish <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).&nbsp; Differentially expressed SLC transcripts in phagocytes (macrophages, 
dendritic cells, and neutrophils) have been identified, compared to adaptive immune cells; new potential immune cell markers based on SLC 
expressionhave been revealed; and user-friendly online tools for 
researchers to explore SLC genes of interesthave been created (<span id='ref34557575.38077407' class='cite'>Aaes <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). The motions of transport systems have been documented (<span id='ref34557588.37945540' class='cite'>Loland <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).&nbsp;</p>
<p>.The 24 TMS MFS permease, NarK, of <em>Paracoccus pantotrophus</em> has two 12 TMS domains, NarK1 and NarK2, both of which are required for normal nitrate uptake.  NarK1 catalyzes NO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup>:H<sup>+</sup> symport, dependent on the pmf, while NarK2 catalyzes NO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup>:NO<sub>2</sub><sup>-</sup> antiport, independently of the pmf (<span id='ref2107.11967076' class='cite'>Wood <em>et al</em>., 2002</span>).  Thus, the protein is a fusion protein of two homologous but distinct MFS permeases.&nbsp; Various mechanisms for importing sugars needed to create cellular homeostasis and survival in several kinds of cells have been reviewed (<span id='ref34556353.37047055' class='cite'>Carb&oacute; and Rodr&iacute;guez 2023</span>).</p>
<p>MFS permeases exhibit specificity for sugars, polyols, drugs, neurotransmitters, Krebs cycle metabolites, phosphorylated glycolytic intermediates, amino acids, peptides, osmolites, siderophores (efflux), iron-siderophores (uptake), nucleosides, organic anions, inorganic anions, etc. They are found ubiquitously in all three kingdoms of living organisms. Among the yeast MFS MDR transporters, the DHA2 family (TC 2.A.1.3) is more variable between species than the DHA1 family (TC 2.A.1.2) (<span id='ref34548127.16630275' class='cite'>Gbelska <em>et al.</em> 2006</span>). Genome-wide analysis of 40 Major Facilitator Superfamily members and their expression in response of poplar to<em> Fusarium oxysporum</em> infection has been published (<span id='ref34554220.34745233' class='cite'>Diao <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>). Nano-targeted delivery systems have been created to overcome the main drawbacks of conventional drug treatment, including insufficient stability and solubility, lack of transmembrane transport, short circulation time, and undesirable toxic effects. These systems have been reviewed (<span id='ref34556452.37122851' class='cite'>Cheng <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p>
<p>One member of the DHA2 family with 14 TMSs, the TetL Me<sup>2+</sup>&middot;  tetracycline:H<sup>+</sup> antiporter of <em>B. subtilis</em> (TC #2.A.1.3.16), which also exhibits monovalent ion antiport activity, can be converted to a monovalent cation (Na<sup>+</sup>, K<sup>+</sup>, H<sup>+</sup>) antiporter with no tetracycline transport activity by deletion of TMSs 7 and 8, the two central and extra TMSs (<span id='ref758.11274128' class='cite'>Jin <em>et al</em>., 2001</span>). Genome analyses of MFS permeases have been published (<span id='ref5520.17490609' class='cite'>Lorca <em>et al</em>., 2007</span>).</p>
<p>A 6.5 &Aring; resolution structure for the MFS permease, OxlT (TC #2.A.1.11.1) was obtained in early studies (<span id='ref2237.11500368' class='cite'>Heymann <em>et al</em>., 2001</span>; <span id='ref2238.12118242' class='cite'>Hirai <em>et al</em>., 2002</span>) which shows the positions of the transmembrane &alpha;-helices but does not allow assignment of the TMS # to these helices.  Molecular modeling (<span id='ref2239.12591890' class='cite'>Hirai <em>et al</em>., 2003</span>) led to the suggestion that the 12 TMS protein arose from a 3 TMS element by two successive duplication events.  The same suggestion resulted from sequence comparisons showing that the primordial 3 TMS element may have arisen from a VIC family (TC #1.A.1) 2 TMS channel-forming unit <span id='ref7698.' class='cite'>Hvorup &amp; Saier, (2002)</span>.This conclusion has been extensively confirmed in several more recent studies.</p>
<p>The high-resolution 3-dimensional structures (3.3 and 3.5 &Aring; resolution) of the glycerol-3-P:P antiporter (GlpT; TC #2.A.1.4.3) and the lactose:H<sup>+</sup> symporter (LacY; TC #2.A.1.5.1), respectively (<span id='ref2575.12893936' class='cite'>Huang <em>et al</em>., 2003</span> and <span id='ref2572.12893935' class='cite'>Abramson <em>et al</em>., 2003</span>, respectively; see also <span id='ref2577.12893929' class='cite'>Locher <em>et al</em>., 2003</span>; <span id='ref5183.17881559' class='cite'>Guan <em>et al</em>., 2007</span>) have been determined.  These structures reveal the 2-fold symmetry expected, based on sequence similarity of the two halves.  The substrate pathway is predicted to exist between the two halves of the permeases using an alternating access mechanism with a single substrate binding site (<span id='ref2575.12893936' class='cite'>Huang <em>et al</em>., 2003</span>).  This mechanism is termed a 'rocker switch' type of movement. Several putative mechanisms involving MFS and other types of transporters underly etridiazole (EDZ)-induced developmental deformities in Zebrafish (<span id='ref34557549.37894748' class='cite'>Vasamsetti <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p>
<p>As suggested above, MFS symporters and antiporters are believed to operate via a single binding site, alternating-access mechanism that involves a rocker-switch type movement of the two halves of the protein (<span id='ref5641.18537473' class='cite'>Law <em>et al</em>., 2008</span>). In the sn-glycerol-3-phosphate transporter (GlpT) from <em>Escherichia coli</em>, the substrate-binding site is formed by several charged residues and a histidine that can be protonated. Salt-bridge formation and breakage are involved in the conformational changes of the protein during transport (<span id='ref5641.18537473' class='cite'>Law <em>et al</em>., 2008</span>).</p>
<p>Vesicular glutamate transporters (VGLUTs [2.A.1.14.13, 2.A.1.14.16, etc.]) are responsible for the vesicular storage of L-glutamate and play an essential role in glutamatergic signal transmission in the central nervous system.  VGLUT2 facilitates L-glutamate uptake in a membrane potential (&Delta;&Psi;)-dependent fashion.  Uptake exhibited an absolute requirement for ~4 mM Cl<sup>-</sup> and was sensitive to Evans blue, but was insensitive to D,L-aspartate. VGLUT2s with mutations in the transmembrane-located residues Arg<sup>184</sup>, His<sup>128</sup>, and Glu<sup>191</sup> showed a dramatic loss in L-glutamate transport activity. VGLUT2 appears to possess two intrinsic transport machineries that are independent of each other: a &Delta;&Psi;-dependent L-glutamate uptake and a Na<sup>+</sup>-dependent P<sub>i</sub> uptake (<span id='ref3639.17046815' class='cite'>Juge <em>et al</em>., 2006</span>). VGLUTs (TC# 2.A.1.14) and EAATs (TC# 2.A.23.2) may be potential targets in the treatment of Parkinson's Disease (PD). VGLUTs
 and EAATs can be used as clinical drug targets to achieve better 
efficacy (<span id='ref34553834.34220434' class='cite'>Li <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>).</p>
<p><em>Trichoderma</em> spp. are avirulent, fungal, opportunistic plant symbionts present in nearly all climatic soils. These <em>Trichoderma</em> strains produce secondary metabolites that are potent bio-control agents against microbial pathogens and
also can be plant growth promoters. The MFS includes a large proportion of efflux-pumps which
are linked with membrane transport of these secondary metabolites in<em> T. reesei</em> (<span id='ref34545230.27041239' class='cite'>Chaudhary <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>). Many of these export drugs such an anticancer agents and antibiotics.&nbsp; A comprehensive review of the classes of efflux pump inhibitors from various sources, highlighting their structure-activity relationships, which can be useful for medicinal chemists in the pursuit of novel efflux pump inhibitors has appeared (<span id='ref34549604.29424299' class='cite'>Dur&atilde;es <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>).</p>
<p>The generalized transport reactions catalyzed by MFS porters are:</p>
<p align='center'>(1)  Uniport: S (out) ⇌&nbsp;S (in)</p>
<p align='center'>(2)  Symport: S (out) + [H<sup>+</sup> (or Na<sup>+</sup>)] (out) ⇌&nbsp;S (in) + [H<sup>+</sup> (or Na<sup>+</sup>)] (in)</p>
<p align='center'>(3)  Antiport: S<sub>1</sub> (out) + S<sub>2</sub> (in) ⇌&nbsp;S<sub>1</sub> (in) + S<sub>2</sub> (out) (S<sub>1</sub> may be H<sup>+</sup> or a solute)</p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><HR>This family belongs to the <A HREF="superfamily.php?id=100">Major Facilitator (MFS) Superfamily</A>.<BR><HR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><a name="references"></a>&nbsp;<p><B>References:</B><P></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5>Aaes, T.L., J. Also transports glucose, xylose, fucose (6-deoxygalactose), 2-deoxygalactose and 2-deoxyglucose) (<span id="ref34547427.23115" class="cite">Henderson and Giddens 1977</span>;&nbsp;<span id="ref34547428.15558" class="cite">Henderson <em>et al.</em> 1977</span>; <span id="ref7167.11693918" class="cite">Hern&aacute;ndez-Montalvo <em>et al.</em>, 2001</span>). <em>et al.</em>, 2008</span>).&nbsp; GalP may exist as a trimer with each subunit having a sugar transporting channel (<span id="ref34547429.20006622" class="cite">Zheng <em>et al.</em> color=#3333CC><p>Low-affinity glucose transporter HXT1 of 570 aas and 12 TMSs. Substitutions of equivalent salt bridge-forming residues in Hxt1, Rgt2, and Glut4 are predicted to lock them in an inward-facing conformation but lead to different functional consequences. The salt bridge networks in yeast and human glucose transporters and yeast glucose receptors may play different roles in maintaining their structural and functional integrity (<span id="ref34557474.37844739" class="cite">Kim <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Fungi</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>HXT1 of <em>Saccharomyces cerevisiae </em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.109"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.109&tcname=">2.A.1.1.109</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Hexose transporter HXT14</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Fungi</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>HXT14 of <em>Saccharomyces cerevisiae  </em></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.11"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.11&tcname=">2.A.1.1.11</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>General &alpha;-glucoside:H<sup>+</sup> symporter, Gtr3, Mal11,Mal1T, Mtp1 or Agt1 . (Substrates include trehalose, maltotriose, maltose, turanose, isomaltose, &alpha;-methyl-glucoside, maltotriose, palatinose, and melezitose) (<span id="ref4978.18179544" class="cite">Smit <em>et al</em>., 2008</span>).&nbsp; Maltotriose is transported with higher affinity than maltose (<span id="ref34545560.27364826" class="cite">Magalh&atilde;es <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Yeast</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>AGT1 of <em>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.110"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.110&tcname=">2.A.1.1.110</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Hexose transporter HXT13</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Fungi</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>HXT13 of <em>Saccharomyces cerevisiae  </em></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.111"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.111&tcname=">2.A.1.1.111</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>High-affinity glucose transporter HXT2.&nbsp; Asp340 and Asn331 in part determine the high glucose affinity (<span id="ref34546369.17369259" class="cite">Kasahara <em>et al.</em> 2007</span>; <a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref11114">Kasahara and Kasahara 2010</a>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Fungi</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>HXT2 of <em>Saccharomyces cerevisiae </em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.112"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.112&tcname=">2.A.1.1.112</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>High-affinity glucose transporter Ght1 (Hexose transporter 1)</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Yeast</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Ght1 of <em>Schizosaccharomyces pombe  </em></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.113"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.113&tcname=">2.A.1.1.113</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p><!-- test--><p>
																												                                         																																																								                                     
																																																																	                                     Putative metabolite transport protein YyaJ</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Bacilli</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>YyaJ of <em>Bacillus subtilis </em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.114"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.114&tcname=">2.A.1.1.114</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p><!-- test--><p>

																																																																	                                     Putative metabolite transport protein YdjK</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>YdjK of <em>Escherichia coli </em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.116"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.116&tcname=">2.A.1.1.116</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Arabinose/xylose transporter, AraE (<span id="ref10234.23928049" class="cite">Wang <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Actinobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>AraE of <em>Coynebacterium glutamicum</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.117"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.117&tcname=">2.A.1.1.117</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Glucose transporter Rco-3 or MoST1. <span class="highlight">MoST1</span> plays a 
specific role in conidiation and mycelial melanization which is not 
shared by other hexose transporter family members in <em>M. oryzae</em> (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref10517">Saitoh <em>et al.</em> 2013)</a>.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Fungi</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MoST1 of <em>Magnaporthe oryzae</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.118"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.118&tcname=">2.A.1.1.118</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS porter of 435 aas</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Crenarchaea</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS porter of <em>Sulfolobus solfataricus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.119"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.119&tcname=">2.A.1.1.119</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The galacturonic acid (galacturonate) uptake porter, GatA, of 518 aas and 12 TMSs (<span id="ref11292.25177540" class="cite">Sloothaak <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Fungi</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>GatA of <em>Aspergillus niger</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.12"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.12&tcname=">2.A.1.1.12</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Glucose uniporter, Glut3 (also transports dehydro-ascorbate; <span id="ref2432.12381735" class="cite">Maul&eacute;n <em>et al.</em>, 2003</span>). Down-regulated in the brains of Alzheimer's disease patients (<span id="ref7021.18174027" class="cite">Liu <em>et al.</em>, 2008b</span>).&nbsp; The structure of the human orthologue with D-glucose bound was solved at 1.5 &Aring; resolution in the outward occluded conformation (<span id="ref34545461.26176916" class="cite">Deng <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>).&nbsp; Sugars are predominantly coordinated by polar
residues in the C-terminal domain. The conformational transition from the outward-open to the outward-occluded states entails a prominent local rearrangement of the extracellular part of&nbsp;
TMS 7. Comparison of the outward-facing GLUT3 structures with inward-open GLUT1 provides insight
into the alternating access cycle for GLUTs, whereby the C-terminal domain provides the primary
substrate-binding site and the N-terminal domain undergoes rigid-body rotation with respect to
the C-terminal domain (<span id="ref34545461.26176916" class="cite">Deng <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>). Glut3 is involved in several disease states in humans (<span id="ref34550168.31507372" class="cite">Lechermeier <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>). Resveratrol and soy isoflavones alone and in combination improve the learning and memory of aging rats. The mechanism may be related to up-regulating the expression of GLUT1 and GLUT3 genes and proteins in the hippocampus (<span id="ref34551321.32290941" class="cite">Zhang <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Gtr3 (Glut3) of <em>Rattus norvegicus</em> (rat)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.120"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.120&tcname=">2.A.1.1.120</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Major myo-inositol transporter, IolT1, of 456 aas (<span id="ref34543737.19833776" class="cite">Kr&ouml;ger <em>et al.</em> 2010</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>IolT1 of <em>Samonella enterica</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.121"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.121&tcname=">2.A.1.1.121</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Minor myo-inositol transporter, IolT2, of 478 aas (<span id="ref34543737.19833776" class="cite">Kr&ouml;ger <em>et al.</em> 2010</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>IolT2 of <em>Salmonella enterica</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.122"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.122&tcname=">2.A.1.1.122</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Sorbitol (glucitol):H<sup>+</sup> co-transporter, SOT2 (Km for sorbitol of 0.81 mM) of 491 aas and 12 TMSs (<span id="ref34546737.12692316" class="cite">Gao <em>et al.</em> 2003</span>). SOT2 of <em>Prunus cerasus</em> is mainly expressed only 
early in fruit development and not in leaves (<span id="ref34546737.12692316" class="cite">Gao <em>et al.</em> 2003</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Plants</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SOT2 of <em>Pyrus pyrifolia </em>(Chinese pear) <em>(Pyrus serotina)</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.123"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.123&tcname=">2.A.1.1.123</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Sorbitol (D-Glucitol):H<sup>+</sup> co-transporter, SOT1 (Km for sorbitol of 0.64 mM) of 509 aas and 12 TMSs (<span id="ref34546737.12692316" class="cite">Gao <em>et al.</em> 2003</span>).  SOT1 of <em>P. cerasus</em> is expressed throughout fruit development, but especially when 
growth and sorbitol accumulation rates are highest. In leaves, PcSOT1 
expression is highest in young, expanding tissues, but substantially 
less in mature leaves (<span id="ref34546737.12692316" class="cite">Gao <em>et al.</em> 2003</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Plants</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SOT1 of <em>Prunus salicina</em><em></em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.124"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.124&tcname=">2.A.1.1.124</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The high affinity sugar:H<sup>+</sup> symporter (sugar uptake) porter of 514 aas and 12 TMSs, STP10. It transports glucose, galactose and mannose, and is therefore a hexose transporter (<span id="ref34545145.26893494" class="cite">Rottmann <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>). The 2.4&nbsp;&Aring; structure with glucose bound has been solved, explaining high affinity sugar recognition (<span id="ref34549434.30679446" class="cite">Paulsen <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>). The results suggest a proton donor/acceptor pair that links sugar transport to proton translocation. It contains a Lid domain, conserved in all sugar transport proteins, that locks the mobile transmembrane domains through a disulfide bridge, and creates a protected environment which allows efficient coupling of the proton gradient to drive sugar uptake (<span id="ref34549434.30679446" class="cite">Paulsen <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>STP10 of <em>Arabidopsis thaliana</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.125"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.125&tcname=">2.A.1.1.125</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Glycerol:H<sup>+</sup> symporter of 530 aas and 12 TMSs, GT1.&nbsp; It is essnetial for the glycerol repression of the alcohol oxidase 1 (AOX1 gene (<span id="ref34545358.27189360" class="cite">Zhan <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>), and plays a role in glycerol and methanol metabolism in <em>Pichia pastoris</em> (<span id="ref34547482.29092019" class="cite">Li <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>).</p>
<p>.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>GT1 of <em>Komagataella pastoris </em>(Yeast)<em> (Pichia pastoris)</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.126"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.126&tcname=">2.A.1.1.126</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Myo inositol uptake porter of 574 aas and 12 TMSs, Fst1.&nbsp; Also takes up the polyketide mycotoxin produced by <em>Fusarium verticillioides</em> during the
colonization of maize kernels, Fumonisin B1 (FB1).&nbsp; The activity was demonstrated with the orthologue in <em>Weissella verticillioides</em> (<span id="ref34545364.27195938" class="cite">Niu <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>).&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Fst1 of <em>Weissella confusa</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.127"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.127&tcname=">2.A.1.1.127</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Hexose:proton symporter of 525 aas and 12 TMSs, Hxt5. Takes up D-glucose, D-fructose, D-xylose, D-mannose, D-galactose
with decreasing affinity in this order (<span id="ref34545717.27499747" class="cite">Rani <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Hxt5 of <em>Piriformospora indica </em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.128"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.128&tcname=">2.A.1.1.128</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Facilitative (Na<sup>+</sup>-independent) glucose-specific transporter (Km = 3 mM) of 486 aas and 12 TMSs, HT1; inhibited by cytochalasin B and localized to the midgut (<span id="ref34545872.17916500" class="cite">Price <em>et al.</em> 2007</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>HT1 of <em>Nilaparvata lugens </em>(Brown planthopper)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.129"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.129&tcname=">2.A.1.1.129</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><span>High-capacity facilitative transporter for 
trehalose, TRET1, required to induce anhydrobiosis. Anhydrobiotic larvae can 
survive almost complete dehydration. Does not transport maltose, sucrose
 or lactose. Transports trehalose synthesized in the fat body 
and incorporates trehalose into other tissues that require a 
carbon source, thereby regulating trehalose levels in the hemolymph (<span id="ref34546059.17606922" class="cite">Kikawada <em>et al.</em> 2007</span>; <span id="ref34546060.20035867" class="cite">Kanamori <em>et al.</em> 2010</span>).&nbsp; 70% identical to the <em>Drosophila </em>homologue, TC# 2.a.1.1.99.<br /></span></p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>TRET1 of <em>Polypedilum vanderplanki </em>(Sleeping chironomid)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.13"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.13&tcname=">2.A.1.1.13</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Fructose uniporter, GLUT5.&nbsp; The proteins from rat and cow have been crystalized and their structures have been determined in the  open outward- and open inward-facing conformations, respectively. On the basis of comparisons of
the inward-facing structures of GLUT5 and human GLUT1, a ubiquitous glucose transporter, a single point mutation proved to be enough to switch the substrate-binding preference from
fructose to glucose. A comparison of the substrate-free structures of GLUT5 with occluded substrate-bound structures of <em>E. coli</em> XylE suggested that, in addition to a global rocker-switch-like
re-orientation of the bundles, local asymmetric rearrangements of carboxy-terminal transmembrane
bundle helices, TM7 and TM10, underlie a 'gated-pore' transport mechanism (<span id="ref34544587.26416735" class="cite">Nomura <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>).&nbsp; GLUT5 is preferentially used for fructose uptake under (near) anoxic glycolysis to avoid feedback inhibition of phosphofructokinase (<span id="ref34546656.28428423" class="cite">Park <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>). Residues involved in fructose recognition have been identified (<span id="ref34547640.29259131" class="cite">Ebert <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>). Glucose (Glut-1 and 3) and fructose (Glut-2 and 5) transporter expression and regulation in the hummingbird occur independently of each other (<span id="ref34552254.32895327" class="cite">Ali <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). Complex plastic mechanisms allow adaptation to environmental changes (<span id="ref34556056.36810233" class="cite">Huang <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). C-3 modified 2,5-anhydromannitol (2,5-AM) compounds are inhibitory D-fructose analogues (<span id="ref34556368.37101605" class="cite">Rana <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).&nbsp; Discrimination of GLUTs by fructose isomers enables simultaneous screening of GLUT5 and GLUT2 activities in live cells (<span id="ref34556506.37116192" class="cite">Gora <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SLC2A5 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.130"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.130&tcname=">2.A.1.1.130</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Glucose transporter 1, GLUT1 or Slc2A1 of 491 aas and 12 TMSs.&nbsp; Expression occurs in the mesodermal region of <em>Xenopus </em>embryos, especially in the dorsal
blastopore lip at the gastrula stage.&nbsp; It is an important player
during gastrulation cell movement (<span id="ref34546211.17486538" class="cite">Suzawa <em>et al.</em> 2007</span>). This system is required for hepatocellular carcinoma proliferation and metastasis (<span id="ref34553708.34128989" class="cite">Fang <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>GLUT1 of <em>Xenopus laevis </em>(African clawed frog)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.131"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.131&tcname=">2.A.1.1.131</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Myo-inositol-specific uptake transporter, ITR1 of 509 aas and 12 TMSs.&nbsp; The K<sub>m</sub> for myo-inositol is about 1 mM; glucose and other inositols are apparently not transported (<span id="ref34546305.27965450" class="cite">Cushion <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ITR1 of <em>Pneumocystis carinii</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.132"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.132&tcname=">2.A.1.1.132</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bloom1 of 524 aas and 12 TMSs in a 6 + 6 arrangement. Mutations in the encoding gene give rise to shiny soybean seads with increased amounts of oil (<span id="ref34547718.29292374" class="cite">Zhang <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). This protein is 50% identical to the sorbitol transporter of <em>Prunus salicina</em> (TC# 2.A.1.1.123).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bloom1 of <em>Glycine max </em>(Soybean)<em> (Glycine hispida) (Glycine soja)<br /></em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.133"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.133&tcname=">2.A.1.1.133</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Facilitative glucose transporter, GLUT2 of 503 aas and 12 TMSs.&nbsp; Evidence suggests that the blunt snout bream is able to regulate its ability to metabolize glucose by improving GLUT2, GK, and PK expression levels (<span>Liang <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>).&nbsp; The ortholog in grass carp (<em>Ctenopharyngodon idellus</em>) is exactly the same size and 98% identical throughout its length. It is found in the anterior and mid intestine as well as the liver (<span id="ref34551016.32062828" class="cite">Liang <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>GLUT2 of <em>Megalobrama amblycephala</em> (Chinese blunt snout bream) <em>(Brema carp)</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.134"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.134&tcname=">2.A.1.1.134</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Sugar (mannose, fructose, glucose, galactose xylose) transporter of 521 aas and 12 TMSs, STP2 (<span id=""ref34548028.29587418"" class=""cite"">Liu <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>STP2 of <em>Manihot esculenta</em> (Cassava)<em> (Jatropha manihot)</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.135"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.135&tcname=">2.A.1.1.135</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Galactose-specific uptake porter of 515 aas and 12 TMSs, STP16 (<span id=""ref34548028.29587418"" class=""cite"">Liu <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>STP16 of <em>Manihot esculenta</em> (Cassava)<em> (Jatropha manihot)</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.136"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.136&tcname=">2.A.1.1.136</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Monosaccharide uptake porter of 529 aas and 12 TMSs, STP7. Transports mannose, galactose, glucose and fructose, but not xylose (<span id=""ref34548028.29587418"" class=""cite"">Liu <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>STP7 of <em>Manihot esculenta</em> (Cassava)<em> (Jatropha manihot)</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.137"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.137&tcname=">2.A.1.1.137</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Glycerol:H<sup>+</sup> symporter,WaStl1, of 561 aas and 12 TMSs. WaStl1 is a concentrative glycerol-H<sup>+</sup> symporter with twice the 
affinity of <em>S. cerevisiae</em>. It is 
repressed by glucose and derepressed/induced by glycerol. This yeast, aerobically growing on glycerol, was
 found to produce <span class="highlight">ethanol</span>, providing a redox escape to compensate the redox imbalance at the level of <span class="highlight">cyanide-resistant</span> <span class="highlight">respiration</span> (CRR) and glycerol 3P shuttle (<span id="ref34550878.30680472" class="cite">da Cunha <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Glycerol porter of<em> Wickerhamomyces anomalus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.138"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.138&tcname=">2.A.1.1.138</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Maltose permease, HPMAL2, of 582 aas and 12 TMSs in a 1 + 5 + 6 TMS arrangement.&nbsp; Expression of both of the adjacent HPMAL1 and HPMAL2 genes is coordinately regulated, repressed by glucose, and induced by maltose (<span id="ref34549885.16103021" class="cite">Viigand <em>et al.</em> 2005</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MAL2 of <em>Pichia angusta </em>(Yeast)<em> (Hansenula polymorpha)</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.139"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.139&tcname=">2.A.1.1.139</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Glut3 or Slc2a3a of 541 aas and 12 TMSs. Transcript analysis of zebrafish GLUT3 genes, slc2a3a and slc2a3b, have define overlapping as well as distinct expression domains in the central nervous system (<span id="ref34550168.31507372" class="cite">Lechermeier <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Glut3 of <em>Danio rerio</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.14"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.14&tcname=">2.A.1.1.14</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Hexose:H<sup>+</sup> symporter of 534 aas and 12 TMSs.&nbsp; Substrate 
accumulation can be up to 1500-fold;&nbsp; one proton&nbsp; is symporter per 
hexose taken up. Helices I, V, VII and XI interact with the sugar during
 translocation 
and line the transport path through the membrane (<span id="ref34546849.10965467" class="cite">Tanner 2000</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Plants</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Hup1 of <em>Chlorella kessleri</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.140"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.140&tcname=">2.A.1.1.140</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Cellodextrin transporter, CtA or CDT-1, of 535 aas and 12 TMSs.&nbsp; It transports cellobiose, cellotriose, cellotetraose and cellopeptaose, and its synthesis is induced by degradation products of cellulose (Lin et al., Feb. 2020, Identification and Characterization of a Cellodextrin Transporter in <em>Aspergillus niger</em>). It is 37% identical to the N crassa protein of the same specificity (TC# 2.A.1.1.82).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>CtA of&nbsp; <em>Aspergillus niger</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.141"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.141&tcname=">2.A.1.1.141</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Lactose permease of 533 aas and 12 TMSs; 45% identical to 2.A.1.1.140 (<span id="ref34552071.32944074" class="cite">Havukainen <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Lactose permease of <em>Aspergillus nidulans</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.142"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.142&tcname=">2.A.1.1.142</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS-type cellodextrin transporter, <span class="highlight">CdtG, of 538 aas and 12 TMSs (<span id="ref34552071.32944074" class="cite">Havukainen <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>).</span></p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>CdtG of<em> <span class="highlight">Penicillium</span></em> sp. 2HH</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.144"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.144&tcname=">2.A.1.1.144</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Facilitative glucose transporter 4, GLUT4, of 505 aas and 12 TMSs. MaGLUT4 is mainly distributed in muscle. Changes in the insulin, mRNA, and protein levels of MaGUT4 lagged far behind changes in blood glucose levels. This delay in insulin level changes and GLUT4 activation might be the reason for glucose intolerance of this fish species (<span id="ref34552318.33178047" class="cite">Liang <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>GLUT4 of <em>Megalobrama amblycephala </em>(Chinese blunt snout bream) (Brema carp)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.145"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.145&tcname=">2.A.1.1.145</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Plant MFS porter of 521 aas and 12 TMSs. This system affects nutrient minerals concentrations in wheat grains and showed a pleiotropic effect on Ca<sup>2+</sup>, K<sup>+</sup>, Mg<sup>2+</sup>, Mn<sup>2+</sup>, and Sulfur (<span id="ref34553514.34145452" class="cite">Alomari <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>). In view of its association with sugar uptake porters, we suggest that it is a sugar transporter, and sugar uptake increases the energy of the grains so as to stimulate elemental ion uptake.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS porter of <em>Triticum aestivum</em> (bread wheat)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.146"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.146&tcname=">2.A.1.1.146</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS-type sugar/inositol transporter of 510 aas and 12 TMSs. An orthologous system has been shown to be a highly specific L-arabinose transporter from <em>Trichoderma reesei</em> (<span id="ref34553824.34496831" class="cite">Havukainen <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>).<em> </em>Considering the high affinity for L-arabinose and low inhibition by D-glucose or D-xylose, Trire2_104072 could serve as a good candidate for improving the existing pentose-utilizing yeast strains (<span id="ref34553824.34496831" class="cite">Havukainen <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>L-Arabinose transporter of <em>Penicillium</em> sp.</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.147"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.147&tcname=">2.A.1.1.147</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS glucose transporter, Mfs1, of 550 aas and 12 TMSs. It is required for sugar transport, oxidative stress resistance, and pathogenicity of <em>Colletotrichum gloeosporioides</em> in <em>Hevea brasiliensis</em> (<span id="ref34553972.34698108" class="cite">Liu et al. 2021</span>). <em>C. gloeosporioides</em> is the causal agent of anthracnose in various plant species.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Mfs1 of <em>Colletotrichum gloeosporioides</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.148"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.148&tcname=">2.A.1.1.148</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Glucose transporter 1, GLUT1, of 500 aas and 12 TMSs. EgGLUT1 Is crucial for the viability of <em>Echinococcus granulosus</em> sensu stricto metacestode and may be a new therapeutic target (<span id="ref34554137.34858873" class="cite">Amahong <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>GLUT1 of <em>Echinococcus granulosus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.149"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.149&tcname=">2.A.1.1.149</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>High affinity hexose transporter, HxtA of 531 aas and 12 TMSs. HxtA is induced in vegetative hyphae upon starvation and in ascogenous hyphae during cleistothecium formation (<span id="ref34554558.14732261" class="cite">Wei <em>et al.</em> 2004</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>HxtA of <em>Emericella nidulans (Aspergillus nidulans)</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.15"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.15&tcname=">2.A.1.1.15</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Putative sugar transporter</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Archaea</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Porter of <i>Sulfolobus solfataricus</i>  </TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.150"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.150&tcname=">2.A.1.1.150</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Hexose transporter-like protein, GCR1, of 541 aas and 12 TMSs. Substrates include glucose, mannose and fructose. It functions in catabolite repression (as does Snf3p in <em>S. cerevisiae</em> (TC# 2.A.1.1.18)) of peroxisome biogenesis and of peroxisomal enzymes (<span id="ref34555166.14660581" class="cite">Stasyk <em>et al.</em> 2004</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>GCR1 of <em>Ogataea polymorpha</em> (<em>Hansenula polymorpha</em>)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.151"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.151&tcname=">2.A.1.1.151</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Facilitated trehalose transporter, Tret1-like, of 485 aas and 12 TMSs in a 6 + 6 TMS arrangement. Trehalose is the main blood sugar in insects and plays an important role in energy metabolism and stress resistance. <em>Plutella xylostella</em> (L.) is an agricultural pest worldwide. Tret1-like was cloned, knoched out and studied (<span id="ref34555228.36012281" class="cite">Zhou <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>). It was found that expression of the gene encoding PxTret1-like was affected by ambient temperature. A knockout mutation of PxTret1-like was generated, and the trehalose content and trehalase activity of the mutant increased at different developmental stages. The trehalose content increased in the fat body of the fourth-instar and decreased in the hemolymph. There was no significant change in glucose in the fat body and hemolymph. Mutant deletion strains of <em>P. xylostella</em> showed a significantly reduced survival rate, fecundity and ability to withstand extreme temperatures. Thus, PxTret1-like could affect the development, reproduction and temperature adaptability of <em>P. xylostella</em> by regulating the trehalose content in the fat body and hemolymph (<span id="ref34555228.36012281" class="cite">Zhou <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Tret1-like transporter of <em>Plutella xylostella</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.152"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.152&tcname=">2.A.1.1.152</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>INT7 of 504 aas and 12 TMSs in a 6 + 6 TMS pattern. There are nine INT homologues in <em>Populus trichocarpa,</em> all presumed to transport inositor, and they are involved in stress responses (<span id="ref34555791.36572075" class="cite">Zhang <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).<em><br /></em></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>INT7 of <em>Populus alba</em> x <em>Populus glandulosa</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.153"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.153&tcname=">2.A.1.1.153</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Sugar transporter of 529 aas and 12 TMSs.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Sugar transporter of <em>Planoprotostelium fungivorum</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.154"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.154&tcname=">2.A.1.1.154</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Solute carrier family 2, facilitated glucose transporter member 8 of 509 aas and 12 TMSs. Symbiotic cnidarians such as corals and anemones form highly productive 
and biodiverse coral reef ecosystems in nutrient-poor ocean 
environments, a phenomenon known as Darwin's paradox (<span id="ref34556075.36921053" class="cite">Cui <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).
Using the sea anemone <em>Aiptasia</em>, we show that during symbiosis, the 
increased availability of glucose and the presence of the algae jointly 
induce the coordinated up-regulation and relocalization of glucose and 
ammonium transporters. These molecular responses are critical to support
 symbiont functioning and organism-wide nitrogen assimilation through 
glutamine synthetase/glutamate synthase-mediated amino acid 
biosynthesis (<span id="ref34556075.36921053" class="cite">Cui <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Glucose transporter of <em>Exaiptasia diaphana</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.155"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.155&tcname=">2.A.1.1.155</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Sugar transporter ERD6-like 4 of 496 aas and 12 TMSs. Vacuolar sugar transporter EARLY RESPONSE TO DEHYDRATION 6-LIKE4 affects fructose signaling and plant growth (<span id="ref34556951.37427783" class="cite">Khan <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ERD6-like 4 of <em>Triticum aestivum</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.156"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.156&tcname=">2.A.1.1.156</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Mannosyltransferase&nbsp; with 3 C-terminal TMSs in a 2 + 1 TMS arrangement. It is involved in N-Glycan biosynthesis and displays an unexpected minimal cellulose-synthase-like fold (<span id="ref34551752.32569746" class="cite">Gandini <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MT of <em>Pyrobaculum calidifontis</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.157"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.157&tcname=">2.A.1.1.157</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative sugar uptake transporter of 456 aas and 18 TMSs in a 6 + 6 + 6 TMS arrangement.&nbsp; This protein has an N-terminal 6 TMSs that are not related to the MFS transporters, but the last 12 TMSs are homologous to members of MFS family 2.A.1.1. The N-terminal 6 TMSs are not related to sequences of the MFS but are homologous to members of the</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS transporter of <em>Alistipes</em> sp. HGB5</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.16"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.16&tcname=">2.A.1.1.16</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Low-affinity hexose (glucose, fructose, mannose, 2-deoxyglucose) uniporter.&nbsp; The evolution of hexose transporters in kinetoplastid protozoans has been studied (<span id="ref9044.22567148" class="cite">Pereira and Silber 2012</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Protozoa</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Gtr2 (D2) of <em>Leishmania donovani</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.17"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.17&tcname=">2.A.1.1.17</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Glucose transporter</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Protozoa</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Th2A of <i>Trypanosoma brucei</i> </TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.18"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.18&tcname=">2.A.1.1.18</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Glucose/mannose/fructose transporter and high affinity sensor, Snf3p, (regulates glucose transport via other systems).&nbsp; Residues involved in ligand preference are similar to those involved in transport (<span id="ref10738.20014043" class="cite">Dietvorst <em>et al.</em> 2010</span>).&nbsp; Snf3p in <em>Candida glabrata </em>is essential for growth in low glucose media but not high glucose media, and plays a role in the induction of severall hexose transporters (<span id="ref34544951.26648919" class="cite">Ng <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Yeast</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Snf3p of <em>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.19"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.19&tcname=">2.A.1.1.19</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Glucose transporter and low affinity sensor, Rgt2p (regulates glucose transport in conjunction with Snf3p). Rgt2 generates an intracellular signal in response to glucose that leads to inhibition of the Rgt1 transcriptional repressor and consequently to derepression of HXT genes encoding glucose transporters. They have unusually long C-terminal tails that bind to Mth1 and Std1, paralogous proteins that regulate the function of the Rgt1 transcription factor.&nbsp;<span>Scharff-Poulsen <em>et al.</em> 2018</span> showed that the C-terminal tail of Rgt2 is not responsible for its inability to transport glucose. RGT2 mutations that cause constitutive signal generation alter evolutionarily-conserved amino acids in the transmembrane spanning regions involved in maintaining an outward-facing conformation or the substrate binding site. These mutations may cause Rgt2 to adopt inward-facing or occluded conformations that generate the glucose signal. The cytoplasmic C-terminal domains of the yeast cell surface receptors Rgt2 and Snf3 play multiple roles in glucose sensing and signaling (<span id="ref34557806.38374219" class="cite">Kim <em>et al.</em> 2024</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Yeast</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Rgt2p of <em>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.2&tcname=">2.A.1.1.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Arabinose (xylose; galactose):H<sup>+</sup> symporter, AraE (low affinity high capacity) (<span id="ref34546414.11739756" class="cite">Khlebnikov <em>et al.</em> 2001</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>AraE of <em>E. coli</em> (P0AE24)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.20"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.20&tcname=">2.A.1.1.20</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Myoinositol:H<sup>+</sup> symporter, MIT</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Protozoa</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>MIT of <I>Leishmania donovani</I>; most similar to ITRI of <I>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</I> </TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.21"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.21&tcname=">2.A.1.1.21</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Hexose:H<sup>+</sup> symporter, Ght2 (Glucose > Fructose)</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Yeast</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Ght2 of <i>Schizosaccharomyces pombe</i> </TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.22"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.22&tcname=">2.A.1.1.22</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Hexose:H<sup>+</sup> symporter, Ght6 (Fructose > Glucose)</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Yeast</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Ght6 of <i>Schizosaccharomyces pombe</i> </TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.23"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.23&tcname=">2.A.1.1.23</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Gluconate:H<sup>+</sup> symporter, Ght3</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Yeast</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Ght3 of <i>Schizosaccharomyces pombe</i></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.24"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.24&tcname=">2.A.1.1.24</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Hexose (Glucose and Fructose) transporter, PfHT1 of 504 aas and 12 TMSs. This is the only hexose transporter, and it is found in the plasma membrane. It is an antimalarial drug target (<span>Meier <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>; <span id="ref34555289.35811673" class="cite">Wunderlich 2022</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Protozoa</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PfHT1 of <em>Plasmodium falciparum</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.25"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.25&tcname=">2.A.1.1.25</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Myoinositol:H<sup>+</sup> symporter, HMIT (also transport other inositols including scyllo-, muco- and chiro-, but not allo-inositol) (<span id="ref4743." class="cite">Aouameur <em>et al</em>., 2007</span>). Expressed in the Golgi of the hippocampus and cortex. May also transport inositoltriphosphate (<span id="ref6869.19607714" class="cite">Di Daniel <em>et al.</em>, 2009</span>). Interacts directly with &gamma;-secretase (9.B.47.1.1) to regulate its activity and the production of Abeta production, important in Alzheimer's disease (<span id="ref34545152.26094765" class="cite">Teranishi <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SLC2A13 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.26"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.26&tcname=">2.A.1.1.26</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Major myoinositol:H<sup>+</sup> symporter, IolT, of 473 aas and 12 TMSs in a 6 + 6 TMS pattern (<span id="ref2058.11807058" class="cite">Yoshida <em>et al.</em> 2002</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>IolT (YdjK) of <em>Bacillus subtilis</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.27"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.27&tcname=">2.A.1.1.27</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Minor, low affinity myoinositol:H<sup>+</sup> symporter, IolF, of 438 aas and 12 TMSs (<span id="ref2058.11807058" class="cite">Yoshida <em>et al.</em> 2002</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>IolF of <em>Bacillus subtilis</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.28"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.28&tcname=">2.A.1.1.28</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The erythrocyte/brain hexose facilitator, glucose transporter-1, Gtr1. SLC2a1 or Glut1. Transports D-glucose, dehydroascorbate, arsenite and the flavonone, quercetin, via one pathway and water via a distinct channel.   Sugar transport has been suggested to function via a sliding mechanism involving several sugar binding sites (<span>Cunningham <em>et al</em>., 2006</span>). Glut1 is the receptor for human T-cell leukemia virus (HTLV)) (<span>Manel <em>et al</em>., 2003</span>). The orientation of the 12 TMSs and the conformation of the exofacial glucose binding site of GLUT1 have been proposed (<span id="ref34554519.14688257" class="cite">Mueckler and Makepeace 2004</span>). It is regulated by stomatin (TC# 8.A.21) to take up dehydroascorbate (<span>Montel-Hagen <em>et al</em>., 2008</span>). Mutations cause Glut1 deficiency syndrome, a human encephalopathy that results from decreased glucose flux through the blood brain barrier (<span>Pascual <em>et al</em>., 2008</span>).&nbsp; <span>Mueckler and Makepeace (2009)</span> have presented a model of the exofacial substrate-binding site and helical folding of Glut1. Glut1, 2, 4 and 9 are functional both in the plasma membrane and the endoplasmic reticulum (<span>Takanaga and Frommer, 2010</span>). Glut1 is down-regulated in the brains of Alzheimer's disease patients (<span>Liu <em>et al.</em>, 2008b</span>).&nbsp;Metabolic stress rapidly stimulates blood-brain barrier endothelial cell sugar transport by acute up-regulation of plasma membrane GLUT1 levels, possibly involving an AMP-activated kinase activity (<span>Cura and Carruthers, 2010</span>). Serves as a receptor for neuropilin-1 (923aas; 2 TMSs; O14786) and heparan sulfate proteoglycans (HSPGs) (<span>Hoshino, 2012</span>). Glut1 has a nucleotide binding site, and nucleotide binding affects
transport activity (<span>Yao and Bajjalieh 2009</span>).&nbsp; The protein serves as a receptor for dermatin and &beta;-adducin which help link the spectrin-actin junctional complex to the erythrocyte plasma membrane (<span>Khan <em>et al.</em> 2008</span>).&nbsp; May play a role in paroxysmal dyskinesias (<span>Erro <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>). GLUT1 mediates infection of CD4+ lymphocytes by human T cell leukemia virus type 1 (<span>Jin <em>et al.</em> 2006</span>). Mutations in disordered regions can cause disease by introducing dileucine motifs, For example, mutations that are causative of GLUT1 deficiency syndrome are of this type, and the mutated protein mislocalizes to intracellular compartments (<span id="ref34548699.30197081" class="cite">Meyer <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). Glucose transits along a transmembrane pathway through significant rotational motions while maintaining hydrogen bonds with the protein (<span id="ref34549392.30700737" class="cite">Galochkina <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>). It is phosphoryated by protein kinase C-B (TC# 8.A.104.1.4) (<span id="ref34550071.25982116" class="cite">Lee <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>). GLUT1-mediated exchange of fluorosugars has been studied (<span id="ref34550208.30366625" class="cite">Shishmarev <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). Resveratrol and soy isoflavones alone and in combination improve the 
learning and memory of aging rats. The mechanism may be related to 
up-regulating the expression of GLUT1 and GLUT3 genes in 
the hippocampus (<a class="reflink" href="../../search/result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref34551321">Zhang <em>et al.</em> 2020</a>). The pore diameters of the transmembrane glucose transporters of all Class I GLUT proteins are constricted upon depletion of unsaturated fatty acids in the membranes (<span id="ref34551663.32477453" class="cite">Weijers 2020</span>). Diclofenac inhibits tumor cell glycolysis and growth by decreasing GLUT1 expression (<span id="ref34553090.33850556" class="cite">Yang <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>). <span>A</span>lmost the entire populations of Glut1 and three other 
transmembrane proteins are immobilized by either the incorporation 
within large multiprotein complexes or entrapment within the protein 
network of the cortical spectrin cytoskeleton (<span id="ref34553239.33069269" class="cite">Kodippili <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). This system is required for hepatocellular carcinoma proliferation and metastasis (<a class="reflink" href="http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref34553708">Fang <em>et al.</em> 2021</a>). The main triggers FoR activation of transport are located within the solvent accessible linker regions in the extramembranous zones (<span id="ref34553722.34260246" class="cite">Gonzalez-Resines <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>). DHHC9-mediated GLUT1 S-palmitoylation is requuired for plasma membrane localization and promotes glioblastoma glycolysis and tumorigenesis (<span id="ref34554064.34620861" class="cite">Zhang <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>). An ancient family of arrestin-fold proteins, termed alpha-arrestins, have conserved roles in regulating nutrient transporter trafficking and
 cellular metabolism as adaptor proteins. One alpha-arrestin, TXNIP 
(thioredoxin-interacting protein), is known to regulate myocardial 
glucose uptake, but the in vivo role of the related alpha-arrestin,
 ARRDC4 (arrestin domain-containing protein 4), was unknown. Interactions of ARRDC4 with GLUT1 prove to mediate metabolic stress in the ischemic heart (<span id="ref34555246.35950500" class="cite">Nakayama <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>). Mercury (Hg<sup>2+</sup>) decreased membrane deformability, impairing RBC capacity to deal with 
the shear forces in the circulation, increasing membrane fragmentation, and affecting transport (<span id="ref34555324.36126286" class="cite">Notariale <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>). GLUT-1 and GLUT-3 play important roles in the development of some 
types of malignant tumors, including glioblastoma, and expression of 
both is regulated by miRNAs (<span id="ref34555388.36157351" class="cite">Beylerli <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>). Glucose uptake inhibitors via Glut1 are potential anticancer agents (<span id="ref34555642.36432207" class="cite">Hung <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>). GLUT1 deficiency syndrome (GLUT1DS1) is a rare genetic metabolic disease, characterized by infantile-onset epileptic encephalopathy, global developmental delay, progressive microcephaly, and movement disorders (e.g., spasticity and dystonia) (<span id="ref34555685.36362347" class="cite">Mauri <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>). It is caused by heterozygous mutations in the SLC2A1 gene, which encodes the GLUT1 protein, a glucose transporter across the blood-brain barrier (BBB). Most commonly, these variants (~2 dozen) arise de novo, resulting in sporadic cases, although several familial cases with AD inheritance pattern have been described (<span id="ref34555685.36362347" class="cite">Mauri <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>). Fluoride exposure affects the expression of glucose transporters (GLUT1 and 3) and ATP synthesis (<span id="ref34556161.36950989" class="cite">Chen <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). GLUT1 is necessary for the flexor digitorum brevis (FDB) to survive hypoxia, but overexpression of GLUT1 was insufficient to rescue other skeletal muscles from hypoxic damage (<span id="ref34556474.37168496" class="cite">Amorese <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). The role of GLUT inhibitors, micro-RNAs, and long non-coding RNAs that aid in inhibiting glucose uptake by cancer cells have been discussed as potential theraputics (<span id="ref34556599.37093461" class="cite">Chamarthy and Mekala 2023</span>). GLUT1 overexpression in tumor cells is a potential target for drug therapy (<span id="ref34556879.37440905" class="cite">Zhao <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). HSP90B1-mediated plasma membrane localization of GLUT1 promotes radioresistance of glioblastomas (<span id="ref34557294.37750323" class="cite">Li <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).&nbsp; The core genes (Fgf2, Pdgfra, Ptpn11, Slc2a1) are highly expressed in sevoflurane anesthesia brain tissue samples. The 4 core genes (Fgf2, Pdgfra, Ptpn11, and Slc2a1) are associated with neurodegenerative diseases, brain injuries, memory disorders, cognitive disorders, neurotoxicity, drug-induced abnormalities, neurological disorders, developmental disorders, and intellectual disabilities. Fgf2 and Ptpn11 are highly expressed in brain tissue after sevoflurane anesthesia, the higher the expression level of Fgf2 and Ptpn11, the worse the prognosis (<span id="ref34557568.37960778" class="cite">Zhang and Xu 2023</span>). Target separation and potential anticancer activity of withanolide-based glucose transporter protein 1 inhibitors from <em>Physalis angulata</em> var. <em>villosa </em>have been evaluated (<span id="ref34557644.38117981" class="cite">Zhang <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).&nbsp; PIGT is a subunit of the glycosylphosphatidylinositol transamidase which is involved in tumorigenesis and invasiveness.&nbsp; PIGT promotes cell growth, glycolysis, and 
metastasis in bladder cancer by modulating GLUT1 glycosylation and 
membrane trafficking (<span id="ref34557664.38169393" class="cite">Tan <em>et al.</em> 2024</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SLC2A1 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.29"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.29&tcname=">2.A.1.1.29</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Glucosamine/glucose/fructose uniporter, Glut-2, Glut2 or ATG9A; it may also transport dehydroascorbate (<span id="ref8082.21621509" class="cite">Mardones <em>et al.</em>, 2011</span>;&nbsp;<span id="ref2432.12381735" class="cite">Maul&eacute;n <em>et al.</em>, 2003</span>), and cotransports water against an osmotic gradient (<span id="ref5044.18234816" class="cite">Naftalin, 2008</span>).&nbsp; Mutations may give rise to the rare autosomal recessive Fanconi-Bickel syndrome (<span id="ref34550217.31473689" class="cite">Batool <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>). It mediates intestinal transport of quercetrin (<span id="ref34551856.32612490" class="cite">Li <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>) and can transport the drug gastrodin, a seditive with a strcture of a phenolic glucoside (<span id="ref34556541.37254285" class="cite">Huang <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). It also functions in autophagy. The cryoEM structure of the human ATG9A isoform at 2.9-&Aring; resolution has been solved (<span id="ref34551859.32610138" class="cite">Guardia <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). The structure reveals a fold with a homotrimeric domain-swapped architecture, multiple membrane spans, and a network of branched cavities, consistent with ATG9A being a membrane transporter. Mutational analyses support a role for the cavities in the functions of ATG9A. Structure-guided molecular simulations predict that ATG9A causes membrane bending, explaining the localization of this protein to small vesicles and highly curved edges of growing autophagosomes (<span id="ref34551859.32610138" class="cite">Guardia <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). Both GLUT2 and GLUT3 have been expressed in yeast and exhibit most of the characteristics of the proteins expressed in humans (<span id="ref34552850.33681287" class="cite">Schmidl <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). Autophagy is a highly conserved pathway that the cell uses to maintain homeostasis, degrade damaged organelles, combat invading pathogens, and survive pathological conditions. A set of proteins, called ATG proteins, comprise the core autophagy machinery and work together in a defined hierarchy. ATG9A vesicles are at the heart of autophagy, as they control the rapid de novo synthesis of an organelle called the phagophore. ATG9A is present in different membrane compartments (<span id="ref34556821.37395569" class="cite">van Vliet <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).&nbsp; Metformin increases the uptake of glucose into the gut from the circulation in high-fat diet-fed male mice, which is enhanced by a reduction in whole-body Slc2a2 expression (<span id="ref34557337.37717665" class="cite">Morrice <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SLC2A2 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.3&tcname=">2.A.1.1.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Xylose (xylopyranose):H<sup>+</sup> symporter of 491 aas and 12 TMSs (<span id="ref34547382.29032199" class="cite">Wambo <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>).&nbsp; Also transports and binds D-glucose and 6-bromo-6-deoxy-D-glucose.&nbsp; The 3-d structure is known in three conformers, outward occluded, inward occluded and inward open (<span id="ref9481.23075985" class="cite">Sun <em>et al.</em> 2012: <span id="ref10457.24060988" class="cite">Quistgaard <em>et al.</em> 2013</span></span>).&nbsp; Most of the sugar-binding residues are conserved with the human Glut-1, 2, 3 and 4 homologues.&nbsp; The coalescence of intramolecular tunnels and cavities has been postulated to account for facilitated diffusion of sugars (<span id="ref11303.25163893" class="cite">Cunningham and Naftalin 2014</span>). Protonation of a conserved aspartate triggers a conformational transition from the outward-facing to the inward-facing state. This transition only occurs in the presence of substrate xylose, while the inhibitor glucose locks the transporter in the outward-facing state (<span id="ref34552395.33268777" class="cite">Jia <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>XylE of <em>E. coli</em> (P0AGF4)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.30"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.30&tcname=">2.A.1.1.30</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Low affinity, constitutive, glucose (hexose; xylose) uniporter, Hxt4 (LGT1; Rag1) (also transports arsenic trioxide [As(OH)<sub>3</sub>] as do Hxtl, 3, 5, 7 and 9) (<span id="ref2873.14966117" class="cite">Liu <em>et al</em>., 2004</span>).&nbsp; The <em>Kluyveromyces lactis</em> ortholog is 73% identical and is similarly regulated (<span id="ref34547577.16783006" class="cite">Rolland <em>et al.</em> 2006</span>). Key residues for efficient glucose transport by the hexose transporter CgHxt4 in the high sugar fermentation yeast <em>Candida glycerinogenes</em>.have been identified (<span id="ref34553816.34515842" class="cite">Qiao <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Yeast</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Hxt4 of <em>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.31"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.31&tcname=">2.A.1.1.31</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>High affinity, glucose-repressible, glucose (hexose) uniporter (Hxt6/Hxt7). Asn331 and hydrophobic residue side chains in TMS5 determine substrate affinity (<span id="ref8286.21892826" class="cite">Kasahara <em>et al.</em>, 2011; <span id="ref11114.20525688" class="cite">Kasahara and Kasahara 2010</span></span>).&nbsp; Also transports xylose (<span id="ref10234.23928049" class="cite">Wang <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Yeast</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Hxt6/Hxt7 of <em>Saccharomyces cerevisiae <br /></em>Hxt6 (P39003)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.32"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.32&tcname=">2.A.1.1.32</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Glucose/fructose:H<sup>+</sup> symporter, GlcP (<span id="ref2514.2507869" class="cite">Zhang <em>et al</em>., 1989</span>)</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>GlcP of <i>Synechocystis</i> sp. (P15729)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.33"></A><A GLUT10 transports glucose and 2-deoxy glucose (K<sub>m</sub>=0.3 mM), and is inhibited by galactose and phloretin  (<span id="ref4267.16550171" class="cite">Coucke <em>et al</em>., 2006</span>). </TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Animals</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>SLC2A10 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.6"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.6&tcname=">2.A.1.1.6</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Galactose, glucose uniporter, Gal2. Also transports xylose (<span id="ref10234.23928049" class="cite">Wang <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>).&nbsp; This transporter has been engineered by mutation (N376F) to transport xylose without being inhibited by glucose or transporting other hexoses (<span id="ref11057.24706835" class="cite">Farwick <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>).&nbsp; The 3-d structure is known (<span id="ref34544333.26217774" class="cite">Wang <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Yeast</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Gal2 of <em>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.60"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.60&tcname=">2.A.1.1.60</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>The major hexose transporter, Htr1 (mediates the active uptake of hexoses by sugar:H<sup>+</sup> symport. Can transport glucose, 3-O-methylglucose, fructose, xylose, mannose, galactose, fucose, 2-deoxyglucose and arabinose. Confers sensitivity to galactose in seedlings. K<sub>m</sub>=20 uM for glucose) (<span id="ref4287.12972665" class="cite">Stadler <em>et al</em>., 2003</span>; <span id="ref4288.8051137" class="cite">Boorer <em>et al</em>.,
