affinity monosaccharide (K<sub>m</sub> = 25 &micro;M) transporter (takes up glucose, galactose, mannose, xylose and 3-O-methylglucose, but not fructose and ribose), STP11 (expressed in pollen tubes) (<span id="ref4331.15565288" class="cite">Schneidereit <em>et al</em>., 2005</span>).&nbsp; This protein is also called Sugar Transport Protein (STP).&nbsp; Expression profiles of homologues in cabbage have been studied (<span id="ref34549475.30669698" class="cite">Zhang <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Plants</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>STP11 of <em>Arabidopsis thaliana</em> (Q9FMX3)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.62"></A><A The <em>L. infantum</em> ortholog (A4I8N6) is 95% identical to this protein and is the dominant protein in the plasma membrane of this organims (<span id="ref34552036.32822697" class="cite">Oliveira <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><em>Trypanosomatidae</em></p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Hexose transporter, GT4 of <em>Leishmania mexicana</em> (B1PLM1)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.72"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.72&tcname=">2.A.1.1.72</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The kidney basolateral urate efflux transporter (SLC2A9, URATv1 or GLUT9) (orthologue of 2.A.1.1.47) (<span id="ref6454.18701466" class="cite">Anzai <em>et al.</em>, 2008</span>). Human SLC2A9a and SLC2A9b isoforms mediate electrogenic transport of urate with different characteristics in the presence of hexoses (<span id="ref8777.22647630" class="cite">Witkowska <em>et al.</em>, 2012</span>).&nbsp;  It transports hexoses as well as urate, the latter by a 
uniport mechanism, thus catalyzing uptake as well as efflux. The ITM2B protein Q9Y287; 266 aas and 1 TMS) inhibits urate uptake and stimulates efflux (<span id="ref34550496.31695625" class="cite">Mandal and Mount 2019</span>). GLUT9's transcription is regulated by a hepatocyte 
nuclear factor, HNF4&alpha; (<span id="ref34545281.25209865" class="cite">Prestin <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>). Residues involved in urate transport have been identified (<span id="ref34546474.28117388" class="cite">Long <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>). Pathogenic variants of <em>SLC22A12</em> (URAT1) and <em>SLC2A9</em> (GLUT9) can give rise to renal hypouricemia (<span id="ref34556443.37176161" class="cite">Perdomo-Ramirez <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SLC2A9 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.73"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.73&tcname=">2.A.1.1.73</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Glycerol uptake permease (Glycerol:H<sup>+</sup> symporter) Stl1. (Involved in salt stress relief) (<span id="ref6529.19383674" class="cite">Kayingo <em>et al.</em> 2009</span>) (similar to Stl1 of <em>S. cerevisiae</em> (2.A.1.1.38))<br /</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Yeast</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Stl1 of <em>Candida albicans</em> (Q5A8J5)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.74"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.74&tcname=">2.A.1.1.74</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The putative L-rhamnose porter, RhaY</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Firmicutes, Actinobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>RhaY of <em>Listeria monocytogenes </em>(Q926Q9)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.75"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.75&tcname=">2.A.1.1.75</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The fructose/xylose:H<sup>+ </sup>symporter, PMT1 (polyol monosaccharide transporter-1). Also transports other substrates at lower rates. PMT2 is largely of the same sequence and function. Both are present in pollen and young xylem cells (<span id="ref4032.15598803" class="cite">Klepek <em>et al.</em>, 2005</span>). A similar ortholog has been identifed in pollen grains of Petunia hybrida (<span id="ref34546909.16937049" class="cite">Garrido <em>et al.</em> 2006</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Plants</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PMT1 of <em>Arabidopsis thaliana </em>(Q9XIH7)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.76"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.76&tcname=">2.A.1.1.76</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Glucose transporter, GT1. GT1, 2, and 3 are homologues. GT2 and GT3 transport ribose as well as glucose at different rates. GT3 transports ribose with 6-fold lower efficiency due to two threonines in GT3 that are alanines in GT2. They are in two loops between TMSs 3, 4, and 7, 8 (<span id="ref7389.20601430" class="cite">Naula <em>et al.</em>, 2010</span>). GT1 is expressed in the flagellar membrane and may be both a glucose transporter and sensor, allowing the parasites to enter the 
stationary phase when they deplete glucose although in the absence of 
the sensor, they lose viability (<span id="ref34544953.25300620" class="cite">Rodriguez-Contreras <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Eukaryota</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>GT1 of <em>Leishmania mexicana</em> (Q9F315)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.77"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.77&tcname=">2.A.1.1.77</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The D-glucose/D-ribose transporter, LmGT2 (Most similar to 1.A.1.1.18) (<span id="ref7389.20601430" class="cite">Naula <em>et al.</em>, 2010</span>).<span id="ref7393.20601430" class="cite"><br /></span></p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Protozoa</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>LmGT2 of <em>Leishmania mexicana </em>(O61059)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.78"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.78&tcname=">2.A.1.1.78</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The glucose transporter, LmGT3 (homologous to LmGT2 (1.A.1.1.75)). Two 
threonine residues located in the hydrophilic loops connecting TMSs 3 
&amp; 4 and 7 &amp; 8 of GT3 prevent transport of D-ribose. Changing 
these two residues to alanine (as in GT2) allows transport of ribose. 
Thus, loops 3-4 and 7-8 partially determine substrate specificity (<span id="ref7389.20601430" class="cite">Naula <em>et al.</em>, 2010</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Protozoa</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>LmGT3 of <em>Leishmania mexicana</em> (O61060)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.79"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.79&tcname=">2.A.1.1.79</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Polyol (xylitol):H<span><sup>+</sup> symporter, PLT4 (<span id="ref7453.21219252" class="cite">Kalliampakou <em>et al.</em>, 2011</span>)</span></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Plants</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PLT4 of <em>Lotus japonicus </em>(<span style="font-family: sans-serif;">Q1XF07</span>)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.8"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.8&tcname=">2.A.1.1.8</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Myoinositol:H<sup>+</sup> symporter</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Yeast</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ITR1 of <em>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.80"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.80&tcname=">2.A.1.1.80</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p><a></a></p>
<p>Insulin-responsive facilitative glucose transporter in skeletal and cardiac muscle, adipose, and other tissues, Glut4 (GTR4; SLC2A4; 509aas). Defects in Glut4 cause noninsulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (NIDDM).&nbsp;Hyperinsulinemia leads to uncoupled insulin regulation of the GLUT4 glucose transporter and the FoxO1 transcription factor (<span>Gonzalez <em>et al.</em>, 2011</span>). The first luminal loop confers insulin responsiveness to GLUT4 (<span>Kim and Kandror, 2012</span>). Exercise increases Glut4 synthesis in a process involving several 
protein kinases, the Glut4 enhancer factor (GEF; SLC2A4 regulator; 
Q9NR83), and the myocyte enhancing factor 2 (MEF2; NP_001139257). (<span>McGee and Hargreaves 2006</span>; <span>Wright 2007</span>; <span>Zorzano <em>et al.</em> 2005</span>). monoclonal antibodies against the GLUT4 inward-open and outward-open states have been isoated (<span>Tucker <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). It is phosphoryated by protein kinase C-&beta;, PRKCB or PKCB (<span id="ref34550073.25982116" class="cite">Lee <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>). Insulin-induced GLUT4 transport is observed in the heart and brain in addition to the skeletal muscle and adipocytes, and hormones other than insulin can enhance GLUT4 transport (<span id="ref34552431.33274014" class="cite">Wang <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). Prolonged preoperative fasting induces postoperative insulin resistance by ER-stress mediated Glut4 down-regulation in skeletal muscle (<span id="ref34552643.33526980" class="cite">Lin <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>). GLUT4 is the primary glucose transporter in adipose and skeletal muscle tissues, and its cellular trafficking is regulated by insulin signaling. Failed or reduced plasma membrane localization of GLUT4 is associated with diabetes. The cryo-EM structures of human GLUT4 bound to a small molecule inhibitor cytochalasin B (CCB) at resolutions of 3.3 &Aring; which exhibits an inward-open conformation. The cryo-EM structure reveals an extracellular glycosylation site and an intracellular helix that is invisible in the crystal structure of GLUT1 (<span id="ref34554951.35562357" class="cite">Yuan <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>). <span style="font-weight: normal;">Tectorigenin targets PKAC&alpha; to promote GLUT4 expression in skeletal muscle and improve insulin resistance <em>in vitro</em> and <em>in vivo </em>(<span id="ref34556301.37056927" class="cite">Yao et al. 2023</span>). </span>Key molecular players in insulin resistance (IR) are the 
insulin receptor and glucose transporter 4, and certain natural products, 
such as lipids, phenols, terpenes, antibiotics and alkaloids have 
beneficial effects on IR which are named "membrane-active immunomodulators" (MAIMs) (<span id="ref34556949.37513825" class="cite">Izbicka and Streeper 2023</span>). An example is the medium chain fatty acid ester diethyl azelate (DEA), which increases the fluidity of plasma membranes with subsequent 
downstream effects on cellular signaling and improves the symptoms of IR. The intracellular helical bundle of human glucose transporter GLUT4 is important for complex formation with ASP (<span id="ref34557252.37731227" class="cite">Huang <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). Diabetes-induced electrophysiological alterations on neurosomes in ganglia of the peripheral nervous system have been reported (<span id="ref34557307.37681090" class="cite">Leal-Cardoso <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). Regulated dynamic subcellular GLUT4 localization has been revealed by proximal proteome mapping in human muscle cells (<span id="ref34557646.38126809" class="cite">Ray <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). In goats, this system is closely associate with lipid metabolism (<span id="ref34557688.38175181" class="cite">Zhang <em>et al.</em> 2024</span>).</p>
<dl class="rprtid"><dd></dd></dl></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SLC2A4 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.81"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.81&tcname=">2.A.1.1.81</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The glucose uptake porter, GluP (<span id="ref7664.21464575" class="cite">Araki <em>et al.</em>, 2011</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>GluP of <em>Rhodococcus jostii </em>(Q0SE66)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.82"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.82&tcname=">2.A.1.1.82</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The cellobiose/cellotriose/cellotetraose/latose/cellodextrin transporter, Cdt-1 of 579 aas and 12 TMSs. It is a proton symporter with a Km of about 4&nbsp;&mu;M (<span id="ref7897.20829451" class="cite">Galazka <em>et al.</em>, 2010</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Fungi</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Cdt-1 of<em> Neurospora crassa</em> (Q7SCU1)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.83"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.83&tcname=">2.A.1.1.83</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The cellobiose/cellotriose/cellodextrin/lactose transporter, Cdt-2, of 525 aas and 12 TMSs. It functions by facilitated diffusion but with low efficiency and high affinity (K<sub>m</sub> = 3 &mu;M). Mutations can increase its activity substantially (<span id="ref34550927.24519319" class="cite">Lian <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>). It appears to be capable of catalyzing efflux of 2'-fucosyllactose (2'FL), the most abundant oligosaccharide in human breast milk, following genetic engineering (<span id="ref34550928.30557615" class="cite">Hollands <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>).&nbsp; It may also take up lactose (<span id="ref34557671.38189952" class="cite">Tamayo <em>et al.</em> 2024</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Fungi</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Cdt2 of <em>Neurospora crassa</em> (Q7SD12)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.84"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.84&tcname=">2.A.1.1.84</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The heteromeric TMT1/TMT2 glucose/sucrose:H<sup>+</sup>&nbsp;antiporter. Catalyzes glucose/sucrose antiport into vacuoles (<span id="ref7939.21668536" class="cite">Schulz <em>et al.</em>, 2011</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Plants</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The TMT1/2 sugar:H<sup>+</sup>&nbsp;anti-porter of <em>Arabidopsis thaliana</em>. TMT1 (Q96290). TMT2 (Q8LPQ8).</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.85"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.85&tcname=">2.A.1.1.85</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Zebrafish Slc2A10 (Glut10) facilitative glucose transporter.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Zebrafish Glut10 of <em>Danio rerio</em>&nbsp;(A8KB28)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.86"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.86&tcname=">2.A.1.1.86</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The sea bream facilitative glucose transporter 1 (GLUT1) (<span id="ref8746.22580053" class="cite">Balmaceda-Aguilera <em>et al.</em>, 2012</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.87"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.87&tcname=">2.A.1.1.87</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>solute carrier family 2, member 12, Glut12 of 617 aas and 12 TMSs.&nbsp; In contrast to most mammalian members of this family, this protein has been reported to be a glucose:proton symporter (<span HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.88&tcname=">2.A.1.1.88</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC> solute carrier family 2 (facilitated glucose transporter), member 6</TD><TD><b><font bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.89"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.89&tcname=">2.A.1.1.89</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Solute carrier family 2, facilitated glucose transporter member 8 (Glucose transporter type 8) (GLUT-8) (Glucose transporter type X1)</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Animals</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>SLC2A8 of <em>Homo color=#3333CC>LacP of <i>Kluyveromyces lactis</i> </TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.90"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.90&tcname=">2.A.1.1.90</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Solute carrier family 2, facilitated glucose transporter member 14 (Glucose transporter type 14) (GLUT-14)</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Animals</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>SLC2A14 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.91"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.91&tcname=">2.A.1.1.91</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Solute carrier family 2, facilitated glucose transporter member 3 (Glucose transporter type 3, brain) (GLUT-3 or GLUT3). It <span>mediates the facilitative uptake of glucose, 2-deoxyglucose, 
galactose, mannose, xylose and fucose, and probably 
dehydroascorbate, but not fructose (<span id="ref34550422.9477959" class="cite">Seatter <em>et al.</em> 1998</span>, <span id="ref34545461.26176916" class="cite">Deng <em>et al.</em> 2015</span></span>).&nbsp; GLUT3, a key neuronal transporter, exhibits multiple intermediate states (<span id="ref34550423.31617996" class="cite">Sun and Zheng 2019</span>). SLC2A3 may play a role in the progression of colorectal cancer (CRC) by regulating the epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) classical pathway as well as PD-L1 mediated immune responses (<span id="ref34553657.34211835" class="cite">Gao <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>). GLUT3 is consistently upregulated in actively proliferating human oral squamous cell carcinoma cells (<span id="ref34555265.35920070" class="cite">Paolini <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>). GLUT-1 and GLUT-3 play roles in the development of some types of malignant tumors including glioblastoma, and expression of both is regulated by miRNAs (<span id="ref34555388.36157351" class="cite">Beylerli <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>). The overexpression of GLUT3 or GLUT1 may be monitored alone or in 
combination (GLUT1/GLUT3 ratio) as a biomarker for preeclampsia onset, 
phenotype, and progression (<span id="ref34556078.36923708" class="cite">Agbani <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SLC2A3 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.92"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.92&tcname=">2.A.1.1.92</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Inner membrane metabolite transport protein YdjE</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>YdjE of <em>E. coli</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.93"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.93&tcname=">2.A.1.1.93</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Vacuolar protein sorting-associated protein 73</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Fungi</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>VPS73 of <em>Saccharomyces cerevisiae  </em></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.94"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.94&tcname=">2.A.1.1.94</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Putative metabolite transport protein YDL199C</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Fungi</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>YDL199C of <em>Saccharomyces cerevisiae  </em></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.95"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.95&tcname=">2.A.1.1.95</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p><!-- test--><p>

Vacuolar sugar transporter EARLY RESPONSE TO DEHYDRATION 6-LIKE4 affects fructose signaling and plant growth (<span id="ref34556951.37427783" class="cite">Khan <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). Regulation of intracellular sugar homeostasis is maintained by 
regulation of activities of sugar import and export proteins residing at
 the tonoplast. ERDL4 protein resides in the vacuolar membrane in <em>Arabidopsis thaliana</em>. Gene expression and subcellular fractionation 
studies indicated that ERDL4 participates in fructose allocation across 
the tonoplast, and modification of cytosolic fructose levels influences plant organ development and stress tolerance (<span id="ref34556951.37427783" class="cite">Khan <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p>
<p>.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Plants</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>At1g75220 of <em>Arabidopsis thaliana </em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.1.99"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.1.99&tcname=">2.A.1.1.99</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Facilitated trehalose transporter Tret1-1 (DmTret1-1); transports trehalose with a K<sub>m</sub> of 11 mM (<span id="ref34546060.20035867" class="cite">Kanamori <em>et al.</em> 2010</span>).&nbsp; Tret1 orthologs of other insects examined have differing Km values (Apis mellifera, 9 mM; Anopheles gambiae, 46 mM, and Bombyx mori, 72 mM).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Tret1-1 of <em>Drosophila melanogaster </em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=2.A.1.10">2.A.1.10 The Nucleoside: H<sup>+</sup> Symporter (NHS) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.10.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.10.1&tcname=">2.A.1.10.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Nucleoside porter, NupG.&nbsp; Guanosine, inosine, cytidine and thymidine but not uridine, adenosine and xanthosine are transported (<span id="ref9313.15678184" class="cite">Patching <em>et al.</em> 2005</span>). ADP-glucose is also a substrate of this system (<span id="ref34550464.30341391" class="cite"><span id="ref34550464.30341391" class="cite">Almagro <em>et al.</em> 2018</span></span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>NupG of <em>E. coli</em> (P0AFF4)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.10.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.10.2&tcname=">2.A.1.10.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Xanthosine porter, XapB.&nbsp; Xanthosine, inosine, adenosine, cytidine and thymidine but not guanosine and uridine are transported (<span id="ref9315.7559336" class="cite">Seeger <em>et al.</em> 1995</span>). The Km for Xanthosine is 136 &mu;M (<span id="ref1906.11466294" class="cite">N&oslash;rholm and Dandanell 2001</span>). The transporter is encoded within an operon with xanthosine phosphorylase which is inactive in <em>S. enterica</em> but can be mutated to the active form (<span id="ref34547371.16707709" class="cite">Hansen <em>et al.</em> 2006).</span></p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>XapB of <em>E. coli</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.10.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.10.3&tcname=">2.A.1.10.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p>Putative low affinity ribonucleoside transporter, YegT, of 425 aas and 12 TMSs.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>YegT of <em>Escherichia coli </em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=2.A.1.11">2.A.1.11 The Oxalate:Formate Antiporter (OFA) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.11.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.11.1&tcname=">2.A.1.11.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The oxalate:formate antiporter.&nbsp; Residues and TMSs involved in the translocation pathway and substrate binding have been identified (<span id="ref711.9651403" class="cite">Fu and Maloney 1998</span>; <span id="ref34546176.11113128" class="cite">Fu <em>et al.</em> 2001</span>; <span id="ref34546177.11919184" class="cite">Ye and Maloney 2002</span>; <span id="ref34546178.16922510" class="cite">Wang <em>et al.</em> 2006</span>). <span id="ref34550277.15820982" class="cite">Beuming and Weinstein 2005</span> developed a method to predict the structures of membrane proteins consisting of (1) identifying TMSs from sequence; (2) assigning buried and lipid-exposed faces of the TMSs; and (3) assembling the TMSs into a bundle, based on geometric restraints obtained from EM data. The OxlT structure was modeled (<span id="ref34550277.15820982" class="cite">Beuming and Weinstein 2005</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>OxlT of <em>Oxalobacter formigenes</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.11.10"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.11.10&tcname=">2.A.1.11.10</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS carrier of 577 aas and 12 TMSs</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS protein of <em>Entamoeba histolytica</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.11.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.11.2&tcname=">2.A.1.11.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative MFS transporter of 399 aas; 12 TMSs.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS porter of <em>Pseudomonas aeruginosa</em> (Q9I458)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.11.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.11.3&tcname=">2.A.1.11.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Inner membrane protein BtsT or YhjX (probably a pyruvate:proton symporter that can also function as an exporter) (<span id="ref34547414.29038258" class="cite">Vilhena <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>).&nbsp; Regulated by Crp as well as the LytS-like histidine sensor kinase, BtsS or YehU,
 and the corresponding LytTR-like response regulator, BtsR or YehT (<span id="ref34547412.29061664" class="cite">Kristoficova <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>).&nbsp; Possibly induced by 
peptides as cells enter the stationary growth phase because they release extracellular pyruvate, the true inducer (<span id="ref34547412.29061664" class="cite">Kristoficova <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>).&nbsp;
 Forms a complex with the BtsT (CsiA; YjiY) transporter (TC# 2.A.114.1.9) and two
 sensor kinase/response regulator pairs, BtsS/BtsR (YehU/YehT) and YdpA/YdpB, both of which respond to extracellular pyruvate, but with differing affinities (<span id="ref34543668.24659770" class="cite">Behr <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>).&nbsp; The carbon storage regulator A (CsrA) is involved in posttranscriptional regulation of both <span class="highlight">BtsT (YjiY)</span> and YjiX, a 67 aa soluble protein of unknown function (<span id="ref34543668.24659770" class="cite">Behr <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>). The two proteins, YhjX (TC# 2.A.1.11.3) and YjiY (TC# 2.A.114.1.9) may function together as an oligomer, and confusingly, have both been given the designation: BtsT (see UniProt entries).&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>BtsT or YhjX of <em>Escherichia coli </em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.11.4"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.11.4&tcname=">2.A.1.11.4</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Uncharacterized membrane protein YJL163C</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Fungi</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>YJL163C of <em>Saccharomyces cerevisiae  </em></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.11.5"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.11.5&tcname=">2.A.1.11.5</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><!-- test--></p>
<p>MFS-type transporter YcxA (ORF5) of 408 aas and 12 TMSs.&nbsp; Capable of exporting the peptide antibiotic, surfactin, synthsized by a non-ribosome mechanism in <em>B. subtilis</em> (<span id="ref34543833.25366377" class="cite">Li <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Firmicutes</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>YcxA of <em>Bacillus subtilis </em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.11.6"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.11.6&tcname=">2.A.1.11.6</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p><!-- test--><p>
																												                                         																																																								                                     
																																																																	                                     Uncharacterized MFS-type transporter YbfB</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Bacilli</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>YbfB of <em>Bacillus subtilis </em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.11.7"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.11.7&tcname=">2.A.1.11.7</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Uncharacterized protein of 512 aas and 12 TMSs.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Rhodophyta</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>UP of <em>Chondrus crispus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.11.8"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.11.8&tcname=">2.A.1.11.8</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Uncharacterized protein of 404 aas</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>UP of <em>Pseudomonas aeruginosa</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.11.9"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.11.9&tcname=">2.A.1.11.9</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Uncharacterized MFS porter of 508 aas and 12 TMSs.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>UP of <em>Entamoeba histolytica</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=2.A.1.12">2.A.1.12 The Sialate:H<sup>+</sup> Symporter (SHS) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.12.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.12.1&tcname=">2.A.1.12.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The sialic acid porter, NanT, of 496 aas and 14 TMSs.&nbsp; N-acetylneuraminic acid (Neu5Ac) serves as a sole source of carbon and 
nitrogen for<em> E. coli.</em>&nbsp; It is a mucus-derived carbon source in the 
mammalian gut. NanT can also take up and allow efficient growth on the related sialic acids, 
N-glycolylneuraminic acid (Neu5Gc) and 
3-keto-3-deoxy-d-glycero-d-galactonononic acid (KDN) (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref10264">Hopkins <em>et al.</em> 2013</a>). In animals, N-glycolylneuraminic acid is transported by exo- and endo-cytosis (<span id="ref34556052.36828446" class="cite">He <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>NanT of <em>E. coli</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.12.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.12.2&tcname=">2.A.1.12.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The lactate/pyruvate:H<sup>+</sup> symporter of 616 aas and 12 TMSs. Residues in the substrate translocation pathway have been reported (<span>Soares-Silva <em>et al.</em>, 2011</span>). This systems and its orthologs in fungi have been reviewed (<span>Guo <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Yeast</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Jen1 (YKL217w) of <em>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.12.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.12.3&tcname=">2.A.1.12.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Jen2 of 513 aas and 12 TMSs.&nbsp; It is a dicarboxylic acid (succinate, malate, fumarate) uptake porter, and is subject to catabolite repression by glucose. It is induced during infection, being upregulated following the phagocytosis of<em> C. albicans</em> cells by neutrophils and macrophages.&nbsp; It may be important during early stages of virulence (<span id="ref34552739.19968788" class="cite">Vieira <em>et al.</em> 2010</span>). In&nbsp; the acid-tolerant yeast, <em>Pichia kudriavzevii</em>, it transports the above mentioned dicarboxylates as well as &alpha;-ketoglutarate (sometimes) and citrate, and possibly lactate (<span id="ref34552744.33629807" class="cite">Xi <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Jen2 of <em>Candida albicans</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.12.4"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.12.4&tcname=">2.A.1.12.4</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Jen1 of 541 aas and 12 TMSs. Zt is a monocarboxylate (lactate) uptake porter that is upregulated following the phagocytosis of&nbsp;<em>Candida albicans</em> cells by neutrophils and macrophages. It may be important for virulence <span id="ref34552740.15764370" class="cite">(Soares-Silva <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>; <span id="ref34552739.19968788" class="cite">Vieira <em>et al.</em> 2010</span>). It may be the only lactate uptake porter and is subject to glucose catabolite repression. However, growth on lactate affects biofilm formation, morphology and 
susceptibility to fluconazole, and both Jen1 and Jen2 may play a 
role in these processes. Thus, the 
adaptation of <em>Candida</em> cells to the carbon source present in the host 
niches affects their pathogenicity (<span id="ref34552741.29094611" class="cite">Alves <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>; <span id="ref34552742.32398310" class="cite">Alves <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Jen1 of <em>C. albicans</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=2.A.1.13">2.A.1.13 The Monocarboxylate Transporter (MCT) Family (Halestrap, 2011)</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><p>MCTs play roles in the absorption, tissue distribution, and 
clearance of both endogenous and exogenous compounds. MCTs are required 
for the <span class='highlight'>transport</span> of essential cell nutrients and for cellular metabolic and pH regulation (<span id='ref34546175.27351344' class='cite'>Jones and Morris 2016</span>).</p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.13.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.13.1&tcname=">2.A.1.13.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The low affinity proton-linked monocarboxylate (lactate, pyruvate, mevalonate, branched chain oxo acids, &beta;-hydroxybutyrate, &gamma;-hydroxybutyrate, butyrate, acetoacetate, acetate and formate, succinate) uptake/efflux porter (<span id="ref8957.22878645" class="cite">Moschen <em>et al.</em> 2012</span>; <span id="ref34552269.32946811" class="cite">Reddy <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). pH-gated succinate secretion regulates muscle remodeling in response to exercise (<span id="ref34552269.32946811" class="cite">Reddy <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). The structural basis of MCT1 inhibition by anti-cancer drugs has been considered (<span id="ref34552417.33333023" class="cite">Wang <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). MCT1 also transports anti-tumor alkylating agents, 3-bromopyruvate and dichloroacetate (<span id="ref34543556.2491258" class="cite">Cooper <em>et al.</em> 1989</span>; <span id="ref34546077.27668346" class="cite">Su <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>; <span id="ref34550229.31532712" class="cite">Bailey <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>) as well as artemisinin (<span id="ref34551151.32152546" class="cite">Girardi <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). Activity is stimulated by direct interaction with carbonic anhydrase isoform II (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref3232">Becker <em>et al</em>., 2005</a>). This transporter interacts physically with the chaperone protein Basigin (CD147; TC #8.A.23.1.1) which is required both for targetting to the plasma membrane and for activity.  Mct-2 uses a different chaperone protein, GP70. Mct-1 also transports the methionine hydroxy analogue 2-hydroxy (4-methylthio) butanate (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref5416">Martin-Venegas <em>et al</em>., 2007</a>; <a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref5525">Becker and Deitmer, 2008</a>). MCT1, 3 and 4 require the ancillary protein, basigin (P35613; 8.A.23.1.1) for plasma membrane localization (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref7440">Ovens <em>et al.</em>, 2010</a>).&nbsp; It partially localizes to the peroxysomal membrane (<span id="ref10250.17173541" class="cite">Visser <em>et al.</em> 2007</span>). MCT1 is regulated by CD147 proteins, and this association is important for lactate export and cell proliferation in certain cancer cells (<span id="ref11111.24013424" class="cite">Walters <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>).&nbsp; It is upregulated in some cancers and maintains the metabolic phenotype of these cancer cells by mediating lactate efflux together with a proton, promoting pH homeostasis (<span id="ref34543558.24921258" class="cite">Baltazar <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>). MCT-1 functions as a positive regulator of osteoblast differentiation via suppression of p53 (<span id="ref34548573.30002387" class="cite">Sasa <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). It  plays a role in aggressive breast cancer subtypes (<span id="ref34548942.29775610" class="cite">Li <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>) as well as other cancers (<span id="ref34549241.30416849" class="cite">Park <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>).&nbsp; The SLC16A1 gene is a potential marker to predict race performance in Arabian horses (<span id="ref34550162.31510920" class="cite">Ropka-Molik <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>). MCT1 is a negative regulator and MCT2 and a positive regulator of osteoclast differentiation, while MCT2 is required for bone resorption by osteoclasts (<span id="ref34550515.31666601" class="cite">Imai <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>). MCTs 1 and 4 are present in increased amounts in solid tumors, and inhibitors as potential therapeutics have been reviewed (<span id="ref34551504.32388280" class="cite">Puri and Juvale 2020</span>). Interleukin-1beta induces monocarboxylate transporter-1 in an oxygen tension-dependent manner (<span id="ref34555260.35925448" class="cite">Tanaka <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>). Substrate protonation is a pivotal step in the mechanisms of several MCT-unrelated weak acid translocating proteins, but utilization of the proton binding and transfer capabilities of the transporter-bound substrate is probably a universal theme for weak acid anion/H<sup>+</sup> cotransport (<span id="ref34556663.36874278" class="cite">Geistlinger <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). This transporter is over expressed in breast cancer (<span id="ref34557223.37666071" class="cite">Arponen <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). Fasting upregulates MCT1 at the rat blood-brain barrier through PPAR &delta; activation (<span id="ref34557906.38589879" class="cite">Chasseigneaux <em>et al.</em> 2024</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MCT1 (SLC16A1) of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.13.10"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.13.10&tcname=">2.A.1.13.10</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p><a></a></p>
<p><a></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p><a></a></p>
<p>MCT8 (SLC16a2) homodimeric monocarboxylate thyroid hormone transporter 8 of 613 or 539 aas and 12 TMSs (<a><span>Visser <em>et al.</em> 2009</span>; Arjona <em>et al.</em>, 2011</a>).&nbsp; It is the X-linked mental retardation Allan-Herndon-Dudley syndrome (AHDS) (a severe psychomotor retardation syndrome) protein (<a>Schweizer and K&ouml;hrle 2012</a>; <span>Boccone <em>et al.</em> 2010</span>; <span>Johannes <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>). Lack of MCT8 function produces serious neurological disturbances, most likely due to impaired transport of thyroid hormones across brain barriers during development, resulting in severe brain hypothyroidism (<span id="ref34551458.32410949" class="cite">Grijota-Mart&iacute;nez <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). Arg residues important for function have been identified (<span>Groeneweg <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>).&nbsp; Thyroid hormone (TH) transporters in the brain and across the blood brain barrier have been reviewed (<span>Wirth <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>; <span>Bernal <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>). The product facilitates both TH uptake and efflux across the cell membrane. The disease goes together with low serum T4 and high T3 levels. The mechanisms underlying MCT8-deficient brain development in various animal models including humans has been reviewed (<span>Vancamp and Darras 2017</span>). Together with OATP1C1 (TC# 2.A.60.1.15), MCT8 controls skeletal muscle regeneration (<span>Mayerl <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>).&nbsp; Deafness and loss of cochlear hair cells occurs in the absence of thyroid hormone transporters, Slc16a2 (Mct8) and Slc16a10 (Mct10) (<span id="ref34550342.29535325" class="cite">Sharlin <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). Stable levels of MCT8 protein in endothelial cells of the blood-brain barrier, choroid plexus epithelial cells and tanycytes during postnatal development has been demonstrated (<span id="ref34551126.32143555" class="cite">Wilpert <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). Oligomerization involves noncovalent interactions between the N-terminal halves of MCT8 proteins (<span id="ref34551919.32724870" class="cite">Groeneweg <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). Genetic variants in MCT8, cause intellectual and motor disability and abnormal serum thyroid function tests, known as MCT8 deficiency (<span id="ref34552167.33141165" class="cite">van Geest <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). <span id="ref34552824.31774046" class="cite">Shaji 2021</span> identified natural inhibitors against MCT8. Emodin exhibited the best binding energy of -8.6 kcal/mol followed by helenaquinol, cercosporamide and resveratrol. Emodin and helenaquinol exhibit high binding energy. Cercosporamide and resveratrol exhibited higher binding energy than triac and desipramine and showed the binding energy similar to silychristin. Thus, these compounds could be promising candidates for further evaluation for AHDS prevention. MCT8 deficiency induces severe X-linked psychomotor retardation (<span id="ref34553584.34335438" class="cite">Iwayama <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>). It is common and severe in homozygous males (one X chromosome) but mild in heterozygous females (XX) (<span id="ref34555187.14661163" class="cite">Dumitrescu <em>et al.</em> 2004</span>). Thyroid normone transporters MCT8 and OATP1C1 are expressed in pyramidal neurons and interneurons in the adult motor cortex of human and macaque brains (<span id="ref34556004.36834621" class="cite">Wang <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). Thyroid hormone transporters MCT8 and OATP1C1 are expressed in projection neurons and interneurons of basal ganglia and motor thalamus in adult human brains (<span id="ref34556695.37298594" class="cite">Wang <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). MCT8 plays a vital role in 
maintaining brain thyroid hormone homeostasis. This transporter is expressed at the brain barriers, as the blood-brain 
barrier (BBB), and in neural cells, being the sole known thyroid 
hormone-specific transporter to date. Inactivating mutations in the MCT8
 gene cause the Allan-Herndon-Dudley Syndrome (AHDS) or MCT8 
deficiency, a rare X-linked disease characterized by delayed 
neurodevelopment and severe psychomotor disorders as well as BBB leakage (<span id="ref34557513.37924081" class="cite">Guill&eacute;n-Yunta <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). A novel <em>SLC16A2</em> gene mutation produced a rare case of delayed myelination with dysthyroidism, v Allan-Herndon-Dudley syndrome (<span id="ref34557668.38174482" class="cite">Mahesan <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). MCT8 inhibitors include methylmercury, bisphenol-AF and bisphenol-Z as well as previously known MCT8 inhibitors (<span id="ref34557875.38151217" class="cite">Wagenaars <em>et al.</em> 2024</span>).</p>
<hr /></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SLC16A2 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.13.11"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.13.11&tcname=">2.A.1.13.11</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Solute carrier family 16, member 5 (monocarboxylic acid transporter 6) of 505 aas and 12 TMSs. Found on the luminal side of small intestinal epithelial cells (<span id="ref34546174.23935065" class="cite">Kohyama <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>).
MCT6 mediates uptake of nateglinide, an oral hypoglycemic agent. The K(t) for 
nateglinide is 46 &mu;M. Thus, MCT6 may play a role in the intestinal absorption 
of nateglinide, although other transporters are also likely to be involved (<span id="ref34546174.23935065" class="cite">Kohyama <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SLC16A5 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.13.12"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.13.12&tcname=">2.A.1.13.12</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Solute carrier family 16, member 14 (monocarboxylic acid transporter 14), ATB<sup>o</sup> or MCT14.&nbsp; Transports carnitine with low affinity (~ 1 mM) (<span id="ref34544935.26607009" class="cite">Ingoglia <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>). Its tissue localization in the mouse has been determined (<span id="ref34545638.27364523" class="cite">Roshanbin <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>).</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SLC16A14 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.13.13"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.13.13&tcname=">2.A.1.13.13</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC> solute carrier family 16, member 11 (monocarboxylic acid transporter 11)</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Animals</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>SLC16A11 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.13.14"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.13.14&tcname=">2.A.1.13.14</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Solute carrier family 16, member 12, SLC16A12, or monocarboxylic acid transporter 12; MCT12. <span>Facilitative monocarboxylate transporter that mediates creatine transport across the plasma membrane (<span id="ref34551097.23578822" class="cite">Abplanalp <em>et al.</em> 2013</span></span>; <span id="ref34551326.32249133" class="cite">Takahashi <em>et al.</em> 2020</span><span>). It is</span> the cataract and glucosuria associated monocarboxylate transporter.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SLC16A12 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.13.15"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.13.15&tcname=">2.A.1.13.15</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Monocarboxylate transporter 7 (MCT 7; mTORC1) (Monocarboxylate transporter 6) (MCT 6) (Solute carrier family 16 member 6) of 523 aas and 12 TMSs in a 6 + 6 TMS arrangement. SLC16a6, mTORC1, and autophagy regulate ketone body excretion in intestinal cells (<span id="ref34557881.38132294" class="cite">Uebanso <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SLC16A6 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.13.16"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.13.16&tcname=">2.A.1.13.16</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Monocarboxylate transporter 9 (MCT 9) (Solute carrier family 16 member 9)</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Animals</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>SLC16A9 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.13.17"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.13.17&tcname=">2.A.1.13.17</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Monocarboxylate transporter 13 (MCT 13) (Solute carrier family 16 member 13)</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Animals</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>SLC16A13 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.13.18"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.13.18&tcname=">2.A.1.13.18</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Probable transporter MCH2</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Fungi</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>MCH2 of <em>Saccharomyces cerevisiae S288c</em></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.13.19"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.13.19&tcname=">2.A.1.13.19</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Probable transporter MCH4</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Fungi</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>MCH4 of <em>Saccharomyces cerevisiae  </em></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.13.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.13.2&tcname=">2.A.1.13.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The low affinity aromatic amino acid (Tyr, Trp, Phe) transporter, TAT1 (T-type amino acid transporter), MCT10, Slc16a10.&nbsp; Also transports N-methyl amino acids and thyroid hormones.&nbsp; Essential for aromatic amino acid homeostasis in various tissues of mice (<span id="ref9188.23045339" class="cite">Mariotta <em>et al.</em> 2012</span>). MCT10 is 58% identical
to MCT8. Both transporters mediate T3 transport,
but while MCT8 also transports rT3 and T4, these compounds are not efficiently transported by MCT10.&nbsp; A few amino acyl residue substitutions in the human orthologue broadens the substrate specificity of this porter (<span id="ref34545385.27244477" class="cite">Johannes <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>). The Six1 trahscription factor promotes a skeletal muscle thyroid hormone response through regulation of the MCT10 transporter (<span id="ref34554091.34809717" class="cite">Girgis <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>).</p>
<hr /></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Tat1 of <em>Rattus norvegicus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.13.20"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.13.20&tcname=">2.A.1.13.20</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative permease of 468 aas</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Rhdophyta</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative permease of <em>Galdieria sulphuraria</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.13.21"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.13.21&tcname=">2.A.1.13.21</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS porter of 392 aas</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MSF porter of <em>Pseudomonas stutzeri</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.13.22"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.13.22&tcname=">2.A.1.13.22</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SLC16 Family protein of 771 aas and 12 TMSs, GEM-1.&nbsp; GEM-1 acts in parallel to the GON-2
channel (TC# 1.A.4.5.10) to promote cation uptake within the developing gonad (<span id="ref34544174.19087963" class="cite">Kemp <em>et al.</em> 2009</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Gem1 of <em>Caenorhabditis elegans</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.13.23"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.13.23&tcname=">2.A.1.13.23</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Chicken MCT8 of 509 aas and 12 TMSs.&nbsp; Transports pro-thyroid hormone, T4, with high affiinity, and T3 as well (<span id="ref34545275.27070099" class="cite">Nele Bourgeois <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MCT8 of<em> Gallus gallus</em> (Chicken)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.13.24"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.13.24&tcname=">2.A.1.13.24</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MCT10 (SLC16A10) of 400 aas and 11 TMSs.&nbsp; Transports thyroid hormones, especially T3 (<span id="ref34545277.27070099" class="cite">Nele Bourgeois <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MTC10 of <em>Gallus gallus</em> (chicken)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.13.25"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.13.25&tcname=">2.A.1.13.25</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Thyroid hormones (TH) transporter, MCT8 of 526 aas and 12 TMSs (<span id="ref34546528.28274736" class="cite">Zada <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>). The mechanisms underlying MCT8-deficient brain development in various animal models including zebra fish and humans has been reviewed (<span id="ref34547652.29183795" class="cite">Vancamp and Darras 2017</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>TH transporter of <em>Danio rerio</em> (Zebrafish)<em> (Brachydanio rerio)</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.13.26"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.13.26&tcname=">2.A.1.13.26</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Thyroid hormones (TH) transporter, MCT10 of 505 aas and 12 TMSs.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MCT10 of <em>Danio rerio</em> (Zebrafish)<em> (Brachydanio rerio)</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.13.27"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.13.27&tcname=">2.A.1.13.27</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><span style="caret-color: #000000; font-size: 12px; font-style: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: normal; letter-spacing: normal; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; word-spacing: 0px; -moz-text-size-adjust: auto; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration: none; display: inline !important; float: none; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000;">MfsG of 447 aas and 12 TMSs.&nbsp; Exports fungicides such as glucosinolates and isothiocyanates. Exposure to glucosinolate-breakdown products induces expression of <em>mfsG</em>. MfsG functions in fungitoxic compound efflux (</span><span style="caret-color: #000000; font-size: 12px; font-style: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: normal; letter-spacing: normal; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; word-spacing: 0px; -moz-text-size-adjust: auto; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration: none; display: inline !important; float: none; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000;"><span id="ref34550750.31253809" class="cite">Vela-Corc&iacute;a <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>).</span></p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MfsG of <em>Botryotinia fuckeliana</em> (Noble rot fungus)<em> (Botrytis cinerea)</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.13.28"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.13.28&tcname=">2.A.1.13.28</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Uncharacterized protein of 652 aas and 12 TMSs</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>UP of<em> Trachymyrmex zeteki</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.13.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.13.3&tcname=">2.A.1.13.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The thyroid hormone transporter, MCT8 (transports L- and D-isomers of thyroxine (T4), 3,3',5-triiodothyronine (T3), 3,3'5'-triiodothyronine (rT3) and 3,3'-diiodothyronine [Km values = 2-5 &mu;M; Leu, Phe, Trp and Tyr were not transported]) (<span id="ref2606.12871948" class="cite">Friesema <em>et al</em>., 2003</span>). Loss of function mutations in MCT8 leads to Allan-Herndon-Dudley syndrome, severe X-linked psychomotor retardation and elevated serum T3 levels (<span id="ref4639.18187543" class="cite">Jansen <em>et al</em>., 2008</span>). Essential molecular determinants for thyroid hormone transport and their structural implications are presented by <span id="ref7291.20628049" class="cite">Kinne <em>et al.</em> (2010)</span>. Induced by retinoic acid (<span id="ref7293.20573951" class="cite">Kogai <em>et al.</em>, 2010</span>). Mediates energy-independent bidirectional transport. MCT8 is specific for L-iodothyronines and requires at least one iodine atom per aromatic ring. Thyronamines, decarboxylated metabolites of iodothyronines, triiodothyroacetic acid and tetraiodothyroacetic acid, TH derivatives lacking both chiral center and amino group, are not substrates (<span id="ref7291.20628049" class="cite">Kinne <em>et al.</em>, 2010</span>). A deficiency causes altered thyroid morphology and a persistent high triiodothyronine/thyroxine ratio after thyroidectomy (<span id="ref8378.21813593" class="cite">Wirth <em>et al.</em>, 2011</span>). Primary and secondary thyroid hormone transporters have been reviewed (<span id="ref8553.21835054" class="cite">Kinne <em>et al.</em>, 2011</span>). A differential effect of a shortage of thyroid hormone was observed compared with a knockout of thyroid hormone transporters 
Mct8 and Mct10 on murine macrophage polarization (<span id="ref34557832.38396788" class="cite">Hoen <em>et al.</em> 2024</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MCT8 of <em>Mus musculus</em> (O70324)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.13.4"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.13.4&tcname=">2.A.1.13.4</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The high affinity (17 &mu;M) facilitated diffusion, riboflavin-regulated riboflavin uptake system, Mch5 (<span id="ref3234.16204239" class="cite">Reihl and Stolz, 2005</span>)</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Yeast</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Mch5 of <em>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</em> (NP_014951)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.13.5"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.13.5&tcname=">2.A.1.13.5</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Low affinity monocarboxylate transporter-2 (MCT2). Transports &gamma;-hydroxybutyrate (<span id="ref4994.17502341" class="cite">Wang and Morris, 2007</span>). MCT2 requires the ancillary protein, embigin (Q6PCB8; 8.A.23.1.2) for plasma membrane localization (<span id="ref7440.20695846" class="cite">Ovens <em>et al.</em>, 2010</span>). It is present in neurons but not astrocytes where the low affinity MCT1 and MCT4 predominate (<span id="ref34550882.15586354" class="cite">Hertz and Dienel 2013</span>). Partially localizes to the peroxysomal membrane (<span id="ref10250.17173541" class="cite">Visser <em>et al.</em> 2007</span>). MCT1 is a negative regulator and MCT2 a positive regulator of osteoclast
 differentiation, while MCT2 is required for bone resorption by 
osteoclasts (<span id="ref34550515.31666601" class="cite">Imai <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>). Atorvastatin exerts more selective inhibitory effects on hMCT2 than on hMCT1 and hMCT4 (<span id="ref34556810.37351987" class="cite">Yamaguchi <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MCT2 (SLC16A7) of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.13.6"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.13.6&tcname=">2.A.1.13.6</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p><a id="2.A.1.13.6"></a></p>
<p><a></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p><a id="2.A.1.13.6"></a></p>
<p>Plasma membrane proton-linked monocarboxylate transporter, MCT4 or MCT-4 (SLC16A3). It catalyzes the rapid low affinity plasma membrane transport of many monocarboxylates such as lactate, 
pyruvate, branched-chain oxo acids derived from leucine, valine and 
isoleucine, and the ketone bodies acetoacetate, beta-hydroxybutyrate and
 acetate.&nbsp; It is the main transporter that catalyzes lactate efflux from glycolyzing cells (<span id="ref34543912.24265240" class="cite">Halestrap 2013</span>; <span id="ref34553029.33805725" class="cite">Papakonstantinou <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>).&nbsp; Residues binding high affinity inhibitors have been identified (<span id="ref34544054.25437897" class="cite">Nancolas <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>).&nbsp; It forms a complex with binding partner, CD147/BSG, which regulates the transport activity (<span id="ref34544505.26384346" class="cite">Fisel <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>). It  plays a role in aggressive breast cancer subtypes (<span id="ref34548942.29775610" class="cite">Li <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>) as well as other cancers (<span id="ref34549241.30416849" class="cite">Park <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>).&nbsp; MCT4 may be a therapeutic target for colorectal cancer (<span id="ref34549867.29483215" class="cite">Kim <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). MCTs 1 and 4 are present in increased amounts in solid tumors, and inhibitors are potential therapeutics (<span id="ref34551504.32388280" class="cite">Puri and Juvale 2020</span>). Anagliptin promotes apoptosis in mouse colon carcinoma cells via MCT-4/lactate-mediated intracellular acidosis (<span id="ref34554612.35317435" class="cite">Li <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>). Dietary folate deficiency promotes lactate metabolic disorders that sensitize lung cancer metastasis through mTOR-signaling-mediated targets (<span id="ref34556193.36986244" class="cite">Chen <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). Shikonin reduced MCT4 expression and activation, resulting in inhibition 
of aerobic glycolysis in cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs) and overcoming CAF-induced gemcitabine 
resistance in&nbsp;pancreatic cancer (PC). Shikonin is a promising chemosensitizing phytochemical
 agent when used in combination with gemcitabine for PC treatment. The 
results suggest that disrupting the metabolic coupling between cancer 
cells and stromal cells might provide an attractive strategy for 
improving gemcitabine efficacy (<span id="ref34557651.38134861" class="cite">Hu <em>et al.</em> 2024</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MCT4 (SLC16A3) of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.13.7"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.13.7&tcname=">2.A.1.13.7</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Monocarboxylate transporter-5 (MCT5 or SLC16A4; sometimes referred to as MCT4). Lactate transport via the MCT5 is non enzymatically stimulated by carbonic anhydrase II (<span id="ref7003.20300744" class="cite">Becker <em>et al.</em>, 2010</span>). MCTs require an ancillary 1TMS glycoprotein, either Embigin (Q6PCB8; TC# 8.A.23.1.2) or basigin (P35613; TC# 8.A.23.1.1) for plasma membrane localization (<span id="ref7440.20695846" class="cite">Ovens <em>et al.</em>, 2010</span>).&nbsp; Upregulated in some cancers and maintains the metabolic phenotype of 
these cancer cells by mediating lactate efflux together with a proton, 
promoting pH homeostasis (<span id="ref34543558.24921258" class="cite">Baltazar <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>).&nbsp; Also transports the 
chemotheraputic agent, 3-bromopyruvate (<span id="ref34543558.24921258" class="cite">Baltazar <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SLC16A4 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.13.8"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.13.8&tcname=">2.A.1.13.8</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Monocarboxylate transporter, MCT10. Transports thyroid horomones as well as aromatic amino acids (<span id="ref7327.20660303" class="cite">Visser <em>et al.</em>, 2010</span>).&nbsp;Primary and secondary thyroid hormone transporters have been reviewed (<span id="ref8553.21835054" class="cite">Kinne <em>et al.</em>, 2011</span>).<span id="ref7326.20660303" class="cite">&nbsp; </span>Deafness and loss of cochlear hair cells occurs in the absence of 
thyroid hormone transporters, Slc16a2 (Mct8) and Slc16a10 (Mct10) (<a class="reflink" href="../../search/result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref34550342">Sharlin <em>et al.</em> 2018</a>). Tissue-specific functions of thyroid hormone transporters in mice, including MCT8, MCT10 and Oatp1c1 have been reviewed (<span id="ref34553160.31724131" class="cite">Salveridou <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SLC16A10 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.13.9"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.13.9&tcname=">2.A.1.13.9</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Short chain monocarboxylate (lactate) transporter 3, MCT3. MCT1, 3 and 4 require the ancillary protein, basigin (P35613; 8.A.23.1.1) for plasma membrane localization (<a class="reflink" href="../../search/result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref7440">Ovens <em>et al.</em>, 2010</a>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Animals</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>SLC16A8 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=2.A.1.14">2.A.1.14 The Anion:Cation Symporter (ACS) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.14.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.14.1&tcname=">2.A.1.14.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Glucarate porter</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>GudT of <i>Bacillus subtilis</i> </TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.14.10"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.14.10&tcname=">2.A.1.14.10</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Lysosomal sialate transporter (Salla disease and infantile sialate storage disease protein, Sialin, of 419 aas and 12 TMSs (<span id="ref8412.15510212" class="cite">Morin <em>et al.</em>, 2004</span>)). Also transports glucuronic acid and aspartate. Structure-function studies have identify crucial residues and substrate-induced conformational changes (<span id="ref7198.20424173" class="cite">Courville <em>et al.</em>, 2010</span>). Also called SLC17A5. The substrate binding pocket has been identified based on modeling studies (<span id="ref8411.22334707" class="cite">Pietrancosta <em>et al.</em>, 2012</span>).&nbsp; NAAG (N-acetylaspartylglutamate) an abundant neuropeptide in the 
vertebrate nervous system that is released from synaptic terminals in a 
calcium-dependent manner and acts as an agonist at the 
type&nbsp;II metabotropic glutamate receptor mGluR3, is transported into synaptic vesicles
 before it is secreted.&nbsp;<span id="ref10267.23889254" class="cite">Lodder-Gadaczek <em>et al.</em> 2013</span> demonstrate that vesicular uptake
 of NAAG and the related peptide NAAG2 
(N-acetylaspartylglutamylglutamate) is mediated by sialin (SLC17A5). Sialin is probably the only vesicular 
transporter for NAAG and NAAG2, because <span class="highlight">transport</span> of both peptides was not detectable in vesicles isolated from sialin-deficient mice.&nbsp; Sialin also transports nitrate in the plasma membrane of salivary glands (<span id="ref10270.22778404" class="cite">Qin <em>et al.</em> 2012</span>). Sialin interacts with nitrate and participates in the regulation of NO production and cell biological functions for body homeostasis (<span id="ref34555750.36189427" class="cite">Wang and Qin 2022</span>). Sialin mediates the flux of sialic acid from lysosomes to the cytoplasm (<span id="ref34555751.35660266" class="cite">Li <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>). Altered sialin mRNA expression in the main tissues of male type 2 diabetes rats has been documented (<span id="ref34556064.36899088" class="cite">Yousefzadeh <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).&nbsp; Base editing corrects the common Salla disease SLC17A5 c.115C&gt;T variant (<span id="ref34557467.37727271" class="cite">Harb <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SLC17A5 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.14.11"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.14.11&tcname=">2.A.1.14.11</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Plasma membrane, high affinity nicotinate permease, Tna1</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Yeast</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Tna1 of <I>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</I> </TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.14.12"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.14.12&tcname=">2.A.1.14.12</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Plasma membrane, high affinity biotin:H<sup>+</sup> symporter, Vht1</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Yeast</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Vht1 of <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> </TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.14.13"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.14.13&tcname=">2.A.1.14.13</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Broad specificity brain synaptic vesicle anion:Na<sup>+</sup> symporter (transports glutamate, phosphate, chloride, etc.)(BNPI, EAT-4, VGLUT1) Chloride and ketone bodies regulate VGLUT activities (<span id="ref7920.21612282" class="cite">Omote <em>et al.</em>, 2011</span>).&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>BNPI of <em>Rattus norvegicus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.14.14"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.14.14&tcname=">2.A.1.14.14</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p><a id="2.A.1.14.14"></a></p>
<p>Probable D-galactarate (glucarate?):H<sup>+ </sup> symporter, GarP or YhaU.&nbsp; May also function as a glucarate:glycerate antiporter (<span id="ref9310.22705263" class="cite">Moraes and Reithmeier 2012</span>) and a glucose transporter.&nbsp; This sequence is incomplete.<em><br /></em></p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>GarP (YhaU) of <em>E. coli</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.14.15"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.14.15&tcname=">2.A.1.14.15</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Apical membrane renal proximal tubular voltage-driven but Na<sup>+</sup>-independent organic anion transporter, OAT<sub>v</sub>1 (transports p-aminohippurate; probably transports organic anions but not cations and not inorganic phosphate.  It may catalyze excretion of various drugs, xenobiotics, and their metabolites) (<span id="ref2578.12740363" class="cite">Jutabha <em>et al</em>., 2003</span>)</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>OAT<sub>v</sub>1 of <em>Sus scrofa</em> (Q7YQJ7)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.14.16"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.14.16&tcname=">2.A.1.14.16</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The broad specificity brain synaptic vesicle anion transporter, VGLUT-2 (transports glutamate in a &Delta;&psi;-dependent fashion requiring Cl<sup>-</sup>, but phosphate by a Na<sup>+</sup>-dependent mechanism via a different pathway/mechanism (<span id="ref3639.17046815" class="cite">Juge <em>et al</em>., 2006</span>).&nbsp;VGLUT1-3 concentrate glutamate into synaptic vesicles before its exocytotic release. Two distinct roles for Cl<sup>-</sup> in both allosteric activation and permeation have been proposed (<span id="ref34548760.30040066" class="cite">Chang <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). The 3-D structure has been solved at 3.8 &Aring; resolution revealing mechanisms of substrate recognition and allosteric activation by low pH and Cl<sup>-</sup>. It shows how the activities of VGLUTs are coordinated by changes in proton and chloride concentration during the synaptic vesicle cycle (<span id="ref34551814.32439795" class="cite">Li <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>VGLUT2 of <em>Rattus norvegicus</em> (Q9JI12)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.14.17"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.14.17&tcname=">2.A.1.14.17</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Pantothenate:H<sup>+</sup> symporter, Liz1 (mutants cause abnormal mitosis due to a defect in ribonucleotide reductase) (<span id="ref3926.15075270" class="cite">Stolz <em>et al</em>., 2004</span>)</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Yeast</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Liz1 of <i> Schizosaccharomyces pombe</i> (O43000)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.14.18"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.14.18&tcname=">2.A.1.14.18</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Pantothenate:H<sup>+</sup> symporter, Fen2</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Yeast</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Fen2 of <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> (P25621)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.14.19"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.14.19&tcname=">2.A.1.14.19</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Plasma membrane, high affinity vitamin H transporter 1 (H<sup>+</sup>:biotin symporter), Vht1 (<span id="ref4330.12557275" class="cite">Stolz, 2003</span>)</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Yeast</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Vht1 of <i>Schizosaccharomyces pombe</i> (O13880)</TD></TR><TR
