It is found in synaptic vesicles and chromafin granules (<span id="ref5202.18375752" class="cite">Sawada <em>et al</em>., 2008</span>)) and is associated with disseminated superficial actinic porokeratosis (DSAP), a rare autosomal dominant genodermatosis (<span id="ref34544890.25180256" class="cite">Cui <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>). It plays a key role in purinergic signaling through its ability to transport nucleotides using the pmf. It catalyzes Cl<sup>-</sup>-dependent transport activity involving essential arginines in the transmembrane region. Ketoacids inhibit these transporters through modulation of Cl<sup>- </sup>activation, but Cl<sup>-</sup> and the arginine residues are not important for ATP binding (<span id="ref34549315.30649354" class="cite">Iwai <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>). High expression of SLC17A9 correlates with a poor prognosis for colorectal cancer (<span id="ref34550549.30236596" class="cite">Yang <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SLC17A9 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.14.22"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.14.22&tcname=">2.A.1.14.22</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The chloroplast thylakoid Na<sup>+</sup>:phosphate symporter, ANTR1 (512aas) (<span id="ref6307.18353780" class="cite">Pav&oacute;n <em>et al.,</em> 2008</span>). Residues essential for function have been identified (<span id="ref7292.20565143" class="cite">Ruiz-Pav&oacute;n <em>et al.</em>, 2010</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Plants</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ANTR1 of <em>Arabidopsis thaliana </em>(O82390)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.14.23"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.14.23&tcname=">2.A.1.14.23</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Vesicular glutamate transporter #3 (VGLUT3) [Its absence in mice causes sensorineural deafness and seizures]. 70% identical to VGLUT2 (TC# 2.A.1.14.16) (<span id="ref8408.12097496" class="cite">Gras <em>et al.</em>, 2002</span>). VGLUT1-3 concentrate glutamate into synaptic vesicles before its exocytotic release and contribute to the regulation of serotonergic transmission and anxiety (<span id="ref8417.20147547" class="cite">Amilhon <em>et al.</em>, 2010</span>). It may catalyze uptake of the neurotransmitter coupled with H<sup>+</sup> export and K<sup>+</sup> uptake (<span id="ref34545064.26912364" class="cite">Farsi <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>VGLUT3 of <em>Mus musculus </em>(Q8BFU8)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.14.24"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.14.24&tcname=">2.A.1.14.24</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Intestinal mucosal sodium/phosphate symporter, SLC17A4. Brain-specific Na<sup>+</sup>-dependent inorganic phosphate cotransporter; Solute carrier family 17 member 7).<span><strong> </strong></span>Several proteins must be retrieved to the synaptic vesicle before it can export neurotransmitters, and cargo retrieval is a collective cargo-driven process, dependent on VGluT1 (<span>Pan <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>).&nbsp; The amino-terminal and carboxyl-terminal regions of VGLUT2 in membranes face the cytoplasm (<span>Jung <em>et al.</em> 2006</span>). It is involved in nervous system diseases (<span id="ref34551103.32158532" class="cite">Du <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). <span class="highlight">VGLUT1</span> and 
VGLUT2, selectively label and define functionally distinct neuronal 
subpopulations at each relay level of the neural hierarchies comprising 
spinal and trigeminal sensory systems (<span id="ref34551104.30273635" class="cite">Zhang <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). An overview of the physiologic sites for VGLUT regulation that can modulate glutamate release in an over-active synapse or in a disease state has been presented (<span id="ref34551631.32474835" class="cite">Pietrancosta <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SLC17A7 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.14.31"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.14.31&tcname=">2.A.1.14.31</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Vesicular glutamate transporter 2 (VGluT2) (Differentiation-associated BNPI) (Differentiation-associated Na<sup>+</sup>-dependent inorganic phosphate cotransporter) (Solute carrier family 17 member 6, SLC17A6). It has 582 aas with 12 probable TMSs. It is expressed in different nerve fibre populations that selectively contact pulmonary neuroepithelial bodies (<span id="ref34554755.14677070" class="cite">Brouns <em>et al.</em> 2004</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SLC17A6 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.14.32"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.14.32&tcname=">2.A.1.14.32</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><address>Vesicular glutamate transporter 3 (VGluT3) (Solute carrier family 17 member 8). Loss in mice produces circadian-dependent hyperdopaminergia and amiliorates motor disfunction and dopa-mediated dyskinesias in a model
 of Parkinson's Disease (<span id="ref34544941.26558771" class="cite">Divito et al. 2015</span>). VGLUT3 is expressed selectively in the inner hair cells (IHCs) and transports the neurotransmitter
glutamate into synaptic vesicles. Mutation of the SLC17A8 gene is
associated with DFNA25 (deafness, autosomal dominant 25), a non-syndromic
hearing loss (ADNSHL) in humans (<span id="ref34545015.26797701" class="cite">Ryu et al. 2016</span>). Glut3 contributes to stress response and related psychopathologies (<span id="ref34551105.28776199" class="cite">Horv&aacute;th et al. 2018</span>). An adeno-associated virus carrying the Slc17a8 gene restored vesicular Glut3 in the inner hair cells of the cochlea, thereby rescuing loss in mice that lacked Glut3 (<span id="ref34557083.37379370" class="cite">Mathiesen <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</address></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SLC17A8 (VGluT3) of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.14.33"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.14.33&tcname=">2.A.1.14.33</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p><!-- test--><p>

																																																																	                                     <p>Glucarate transporter, GudP.  Encoded in an operon with GudD, a glucarate dehydratase (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref9310">Moraes and Reithmeier 2012</a>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>GudP of <em>E. coli</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.14.41"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.14.41&tcname=">2.A.1.14.41</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The Aldohexuronate (glucuronate, galacturonate) uptake porter (<span id="ref10997.11386378" class="cite">Valmeekam <em>et al.</em> 2001</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ExuT of <em>Erwinia chrysanthemi&nbsp; EAT-4 is responsible for loading glutamate into synaptic vesicles, and thus in defining the glutamatergic phenotype of a neuron (<span id="ref34543624.24243022" class="cite">Serrano-Saiz <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>).&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>EAT-4 of <em>Caenorhabditis elegans</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.14.43"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.14.43&tcname=">2.A.1.14.43</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Uncharacterized but putative sulfonate (and other inorganic sulfur-containing compounds) uptake transporter of 537 aas and 12 TMSs.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>UP of <em>Ashbya gossypii</em> (Yeast)<em> (Eremothecium gossypii)</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.14.44"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.14.44&tcname=">2.A.1.14.44</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Vesicular Glutamate transporter, VGlut of 632 aas and 10 TMSs with the N- and C-termini in the cytoplasm (<span id="ref34546373.17394549" class="cite">Fei <em>et al.</em> 2007</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>VGlut of<em> Drosophila melanogaster</em></p>
<p></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.14.45"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.14.45&tcname=">2.A.1.14.45</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>AtPHT4;4, or ANTR2 of 541 aas and 12 TMSs, an ascorbate transporter in the chloroplast 
envelope membrane.&nbsp; It may be required for tolerance to strong light 
stress (<span id="ref34547502.25557369" class="cite">Miyaji <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ANTR2 of <em>Arabidopsis thaliana</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.14.46"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.14.46&tcname=">2.A.1.14.46</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Vesicular glutamate transporter, VGLU-2, of 573 aas and 12 TMSs. In addition to being present in nerve cells, it may play a role in collagen trafficking in the skin. The <em>C. elegans</em> SLC17A6/7/8 family members probaly have diverse functions within and outside the nervous system (<span id="ref34550586.31776169" class="cite">Serrano-Saiz <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>VGLU-2 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.14.47"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.14.47&tcname=">2.A.1.14.47</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS2 of 1379 aas and 12 TMSs in a 6 + 6 TMS arrangement at the C-terminal end of the protein (residues 800 - 1379).&nbsp; The N-terminal 800 residues are strongly hydrophilic (<span id="ref34555299.35811673" class="cite">Wunderlich 2022</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS2 of <em>Plasmodium falciparum</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.14.48"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.14.48&tcname=">2.A.1.14.48</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS general substrate transporter of 451 aas and 12 TMSs, MFS-3-6. It facilitates the export of lactate from the cell under acidic conditions (<span id="ref34555857.36536285" class="cite">Tian <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>).&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS-3-6 of <em>Weizmannia coagulans</em> (strain 2-6) (<em>Bacillus coagulans</em>)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.14.49"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.14.49&tcname=">2.A.1.14.49</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Uncharacterized MFS carrier of 453 aas and probably 12 TMSs in a 6 + 6 TMS arrangement. The encoding gene is responsive to the presence of Ivermectin (<span id="ref34556365.37141255" class="cite">Dube <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>UP of <em>Caenorhabditis elegans</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.14.5"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.14.5&tcname=">2.A.1.14.5</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Phthalate porter, Pht1 of 451 aas and 11 or 12 TMSs.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Pht1 of <em>Pseudomonas putida</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.14.50"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.14.50&tcname=">2.A.1.14.50</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS carrier, a putative drug exporter of 450 aas and 12 TMSs in a 6 + 6 TMS arrangement.&nbsp; It exports polymyxin B, CCCP and verapamil (<span id="ref34556717.37316617" class="cite">Gao <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Polymyxin exporter of <em>Pandoraea pnomenusa</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.14.6"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.14.6&tcname=">2.A.1.14.6</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Na:P<sub>i</sub> symporter, NPT1 or SLC17A1. HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.16.6&tcname=">2.A.1.16.6</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p><a id="2.A.1.16.6"></a> Siderophore iron transporter 1, Str1</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Yeast</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Str1 of <em>Schizosaccharomyces pombe </em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.16.7"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.16.7&tcname=">2.A.1.16.7</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p><a id="2.A.1.16.7"></a></p>
<p>Ferri-siderophore transporter, MirB. Transports hydroxamate siderophores such as triacetylfusarinine C (TAFC) (<span id="ref8945.22903978" class="cite">Raymond-Bouchard <em>et al.</em> 2012</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Fungi</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MirB of<em> Emericella nidulans</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.16.8"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.16.8&tcname=">2.A.1.16.8</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Fusarum iron-related protein, Fir1 of 585 aas and 14 TMSs. Probably an iron-siderophre transporter (<span id="ref34547249.16938445" class="cite">L&oacute;pez-Errasqu&iacute;n <em>et al.</em> 2006</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Fir1 if <em>Gibberella moniliformis </em>(Maize ear and stalk rot fungus)<em> (Fusarium verticillioides)</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.16.9"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.16.9&tcname=">2.A.1.16.9</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Siderophore iron transporter 3, Str3 of 630 aas and 14 TMSs in a 6 + 7 + 1 TMS arrangement. It <span>transports siderophore iron and so plays a role in iron homeostasis (<span id="ref34552137.12888492" class="cite">Pelletier <em>et al.</em> 2003</span>). It also transports heme, and </span>the peroxiredoxin, Tpx1 (Q74887; 192 aas and 0 - 2 possible TMSs), is a binding partner of Str3 (<span id="ref34552138.33140466" class="cite">Normant <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). Under microaerobic conditions, cells deficient in heme biosynthesis and lacking the heme receptor Shu1 exhibit poor hemin-dependent growth in the absence of Tpx1, a cytoplasmic heme binding protein. Tpx1 exhibits an equilibrium constant value of 0.26 muM for hemin. The association of Tpx1 with hemin protects hemin from degradation by H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub>, and the peroxidase activity of hemin is lowered when it is bound to Tpx1 (<span id="ref34552138.33140466" class="cite">Normant <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>).</p>
<p><span><span class="identifier pubmed"><span class="id-label"> </span> </span></span></p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Str3 of <em>Schizosaccharomyces pombe </em>(Fission yeast)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=2.A.1.17">2.A.1.17 The Cyanate Porter (CP) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.17.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.17.1&tcname=">2.A.1.17.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Cyanate transport system, CynT.&nbsp; Encoded with cyanate aminohydrolase, CynS, and carbonic anhydrase, CynX (<span id="ref10201.2094285" class="cite">Anderson <em>et al.</em> 1990; </span><a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref9310">Moraes and Reithmeier 2012</a>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>CynX of <em>E. coli</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.17.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.17.2&tcname=">2.A.1.17.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Glucose transporter, OEOE_0819. Does not transport fructose (<span id="ref8120.22020640" class="cite">Kim <em>et al.</em>, 2011</span>)</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Firmicutes</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>OEOE_0819 of <em>Oenococcus onei</em>&nbsp;(Q04FN1)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.17.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.17.3&tcname=">2.A.1.17.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Inner membrane transport protein, NimT or YeaN of 393 aas and 12 TMSs.&nbsp; It exports 2-nitroimidazole from the cytoplasm, confering resistance to this anitbiotic, and transcription of this gene as well as NimO, within the same operon, is regulated by the repressor, NimR (YeaM) (<span id="ref34550797.25790494" class="cite">Ogasawara <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>NimT or YeaN of <em>Escherichia coli </em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.17.4"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.17.4&tcname=">2.A.1.17.4</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS porter of 390 aas and 12 TMSs</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS porter of <em>Campylobacter peloridis</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=2.A.1.18">2.A.1.18 The Polyol Porter (PP) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.18.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.18.1&tcname=">2.A.1.18.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>D-Arabinitol:H<sup>+</sup> symporter of 425 aas and 12 TMSs, DalT (<span id="ref704.9324246" class="cite">Heuel <em>et al.</em> 1997</span>; <span id="ref34550081.9639934" class="cite">Heuel <em>et al.</em> 1998).</span></p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>DalT of <em>Klebsiella pneumoniae</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.18.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.18.2&tcname=">2.A.1.18.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Ribitol:H<sup>+</sup> symporter of 427 aas and 12 TMSs, RbtT (<span id="ref704.9324246" class="cite">Heuel <em>et al.</em> 1997</span>; <span id="ref34550081.9639934" class="cite">Heuel <em>et al.</em> 1998).</span></p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>RbtT of <em>Klebsiella pneumoniae</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.18.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.18.3&tcname=">2.A.1.18.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Alpha-ketoglutarate permease of 435 aas and 12 TMSs (<span id="ref34550082.9099855" class="cite">Gomez and Cutting 1997</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacilli</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>CsbX of <em>Bacillus subtilis </em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=2.A.1.19">2.A.1.19 The Organic Cation Transporter (OCT) Family (The SLC22A family including OCT1-3, OCTN1-3 and OAT1-5 of <i>H. sapiens</i>)</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><p>This family has been described by <span id='ref10432.23506881' class='cite'>Koepsell 2013.&nbsp; </span>It contains 13 functionally characterized human plasma membrane proteins.The family includes organic cation transporters
(OCTs), organic zwitterion/cation transporters (OCTNs), and organic anion transporters (OATs). The
transporters operate as (1) uniporters which mediate facilitated diffusion (OCTs and some OCTNs), (2) anion
exchangers (OATs), and (3) some Na<sup>+</sup>/zwitterion cotransporters (OCTNs). They participate in small
intestinal absorption and hepatic and renal excretion of drugs, xenobiotics and endogenous compounds
and perform homeostatic functions in the brain and heart. Important endogeneous substrates include
monoamine neurotransmitters, l-carnitine, alpha-ketoglutarate, cAMP, cGMP, prostaglandins and
urate. Mutations in the SLC22 genes cause
specific diseases like primary systemic carnitine deficiency and idiopathic renal hypouricemia and
are correlated with diseases such as Crohn's disease and gout. Drug-drug interactions at individual
transporters may change pharmacokinetics and toxicities of drugs (<span id='ref10432.23506881' class='cite'>Koepsell 2013)</span>. Models of Octs resemble GLUT3 (PDB ID# 5C65) and have an intracellular three/four-helix loop between TMH6 and TMH7 containing putative phosphorylation sites for precise regulation of hOCTs. The models allow prediction of substrate binding sites (<span id='ref34546600.28343125' class='cite'>Dakal <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>). Interactions with therapeutic herbal products, dietary supplements, and clinically important drugs are discussed, and the significance of these transporters in modulating the severity of drug-related side effects and toxicity mechanisms have been reviewed (<span id='ref34548741.30149367' class='cite'>Mor <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). OCTs are highly expressed on the plasma membranes of polarized epithelia, thus, playing a key role in intestinal absorption and renal reabsorption of nutrients (e.g., choline and carnitine), in the elimination of waste products (e.g., trimethylamine and trimethylamine N-oxide), and in the kinetic profile and therapeutic index of several drugs (e.g., metformin and platinum derivatives) (<span id='ref34552157.33114309' class='cite'>Samodelov <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). SLC22 is a family of drug/metabolite exporters (i.e., OAT1) speicific for (1) drugs and natural products, (2) antibiotics (i.e., cefazolin) and antiviral agents (i.ie., adefovir), (3) chemo-theraputic agents (i.e., methotrexate), (4) antioxidants (i.e., uric acid) that decrease oxidative stress and aging, (5) protaglandins (i.e., PG F2a), (6) gut microbial metabolites (i.e., hippuric acid and trimethylamine oxide, TMAO),&nbsp; (7) other compounds including bile acids (<span id='ref34556765.33757768' class='cite'>Granados <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>; <span id='ref34556766.34948211' class='cite'>Zhang <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>). Their functions are similar in flies and mammals.</p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.19.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.19.1&tcname=">2.A.1.19.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The basolateral multivalent, potential-sensitive, organic cation (tetramethyl-ammonium; N'-methylnicotinamide; cationic drugs, xenobiotics, vitamins, neuro-transmitters, etc.) transporter (uni-porter)-1, Oct1.&nbsp; Cysteyl residues essential for transport and substrate binding have been identified (<span id="ref34546147.17567940" class="cite">Sturm <em>et al.</em> 2007</span>). Subtype-specific affinity of rat organic cation transporters rOCT1 and rOCT2
for corticosterone depends on three amino acids within the substrate binding region (<span id="ref34550819.15662045" class="cite">Gorboulev <em>et al.</em> 2005</span>). Differences in metformin and thiamine uptake between human and mouse Oct1 transporters have been demonstrated (<span id="ref34552186.33037045" class="cite">Meyer <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Oct1 of <em>Rattus norvegicus</em> (Q63089)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.19.10"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.19.10&tcname=">2.A.1.19.10</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The apical proximal tubular kidney/placenta organic anion transporter 4, Oat4 (Slc22a11) (transports estrone sulfate (K<sub>m</sub> = 1 &micro;M), dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate (K<sub>m</sub> = 60&micro;M), many anionic drugs, diuretics, bile salts, urate and ochratoxin A). Catalyzes Na<sup>+</sup>-independent efflux, possibly using glutamate as a counter anion in an exchange reaction, especially in the placenta (<span id="ref34544468.26277985" class="cite">Lofthouse <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>).&nbsp; Functions in renal urate reabsorption (<span id="ref34545281.25209865" class="cite">Prestin <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>). Chlorine decreases the expression of the gene encoding this transporter (<span id="ref34555967.36736481" class="cite">Suman <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). hOAT4 is mainly expressed in the 
kidney and placenta, and is essential for the disposition of numerous drugs,
 toxins, and endogenous substances. It is regulated by insulin-like growth factor and portein kinase B (<span id="ref34556877.37487877" class="cite">Yu <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SLC22A11 (Oat4) of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.19.11"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.19.11&tcname=">2.A.1.19.11</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The apical proximal tubular renal urate:anion exchanger, URAT1 (Slc22a12).&nbsp; Catalyzes Na<sup>+</sup>-independent anion efflux (secretion) and reabsorption (<span id="ref2573.12504088" class="cite">Eraly <em>et al</em>., 2003a</span>,<span id="ref2574.12920404" class="cite">b</span>; <span id="ref8139.22000646" class="cite">Anzai and Endou, 2011</span>; <span id="ref34545281.25209865" class="cite">Prestin <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>)&nbsp; Regulated by the PDZK1 protein; <span id="ref2997.15304510" class="cite">Anzai <em>et al</em>., 2004</span>). Also transports orotate, a precursor of pyrimidine biosynthesis (<span id="ref7940.21350910" class="cite">Miura <em>et al.</em>, 2011</span>). Mutations in URAT1 cause hereditary renal hypouricemia/gaut.&nbsp; Residues involved in urea and inhibitor binding have been identified (<span id="ref34545873.27713539" class="cite">Tan <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>). Mutations can cause renal hypouricemia (RHUC), a heterogeneous genetic disorder that is characterized by decreased serum uric acid concentrations and increased fractional excretion of uric acid (<span id="ref34548656.30097038" class="cite">Zhou <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>; <span id="ref34555456.36210123" class="cite">Kaynar <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>). Mutation in transmembrane domain 8 of the human urate transporter 1 (residue K393) disrupts uric acid recognition and transport (<span id="ref34555486.36188325" class="cite">Lan <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>). Pathogenic variants of <em>SLC22A12</em> (URAT1) and <em>SLC2A9</em> (GLUT9) can give rise to renal hypouricemia (<span id="ref34556443.37176161" class="cite">Perdomo-Ramirez <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). Biphenyl carboxylic acid derivatives are potent URAT1 inhibitors (<span id="ref34557541.37959834" class="cite">Hou <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>URAT1/SLC22A12 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.19.12"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.19.12&tcname=">2.A.1.19.12</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The high affinity L-carnitine transporter, CT2, present in the luminal membranes of epididymal epithelia and Sertoli cells of the testis (<span>Enomoto <em>et al.</em>, 2002b</span>).&nbsp; It also catalyzes uptake of the anticancer polyamine analogue, bleomycin-A5 (<span>Aouida <em>et al.</em> 2010</span>). Carnitine transport and metabolism have been reviewed (<span>Nałęcz and Nałęcz 2017</span>). SLC22A16 (CG6126) transports ergothioneine (<span id="ref34556766.34948211" class="cite">Zhang <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SLC22A16 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.19.13"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.19.13&tcname=">2.A.1.19.13</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The organic cation transporter, Oct1 (transports L-carnitine; expressed in vascular tissues of various organs and at sites of lateral root formation) (<span id="ref3946.17521409" class="cite">Lelandais-Briere <em>et al</em>, 2007</span>). It also transports spermine and other polyamines and is induced by them (<span id="ref34550113.26905725" class="cite">Sagor <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>).&nbsp; It protects against the polyamine, cadaverine, which affects root length (<span id="ref34550112.25403917" class="cite">Strohm <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Plants</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Oct1 of <em>Arabidopsis thaliana</em> (Q9CAT6)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.19.14"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.19.14&tcname=">2.A.1.19.14</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a id="2.A.1.19"></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p><a id="2.A.1.19.14"></a></p>
<p><a></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p>Brush border glycosylated urate (Km= 1.2 mM) tranporter, RST. Orthologous to the human URAT1. Inhibited by 50 &mu;M benzbromarone, 1 mM probenecid and 10 mM lactate which may also be transported and trans-stimulate urate uptake. May be orthologous to 2.A.1.19.11 as well (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref6239">Hosoyamada <em>et al</em>., 2004</a>).&nbsp; Involved in urate absorption across the apical membrane, but probably not the primary route (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref9963">Eraly <em>et al.</em> 2008</a>; <span id="ref34545281.25209865" class="cite">Prestin <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>RST/Slc22a12 of <em>Mus musculus</em><br /> (Q8CFZ5)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.19.15"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.19.15&tcname=">2.A.1.19.15</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>The liver multispecific organic anion transporter, NLT or OAT2. Transports salicylate, K<sub>M</sub>=90µM, acetylsalicylate, prostaglandin E2, dicarboxylate, p-aminohippurate, etc. (<span id="ref4144.9650585" class="cite">Sekine <em>et al</em>., 1998</span>)</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Animals</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>NLT of <i>Rattus norvegicus</i> (Q63314)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.19.16"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.19.16&tcname=">2.A.1.19.16</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The organic anion transporter, Oat6 or SLC22a20 of 556 aas and 12 TMSs.&nbsp; Binding and transport rates for 40 anionic substrates have been studied and compared with those for Oat1 (TC# 1.A.1.19.4) (<span id="ref4221.17553798" class="cite">Kaler <em>et al</em>., 2007</span>). Oat6 transports many antiviral agents (<span id="ref4663.18174163" class="cite">Truong <em>et al</em>., 2008</span>). It can bind odorants and is present in the mouse olfactory mucosa; it has been proposed to be an odorant receptor and/or odorant transporter (<span id="ref34549879.26358290" class="cite">Wu <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>). Mouse OAT6 is expressed predominantly in olfactory mucosa but not in kidney or brain (<span id="ref34550108.15369770" class="cite">Monte <em>et al.</em> 2004</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Oat6 of <em>Mus musculus</em> (Q80UJ1)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.19.17"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.19.17&tcname=">2.A.1.19.17</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Kidney organic cation transporter-like 3 ORCTL-3 (OAT10; SLC22A13; Like-3) (<span id="ref5140.18411268" class="cite">Bahn <em>et al</em>., 2008</span>) (transports nicotinate, p-aminohippurate and urate; K<sub>M</sub>=20-40 m&mu;M) via exchange for lactate).&nbsp; Activated by tumorigeneic mutations in this antitumor gene to promote apoptosis (<span id="ref11267.25001539" class="cite">AbuAli and Grimm 2014</span>).&nbsp; Functions in urate reabsorption (<span id="ref34545281.25209865" class="cite">Prestin <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>). Substrate binding and lipid-mediated allostery in the human organic anion transporter 1 have been examined at the atomic-scale (<span id="ref34555931.36739760" class="cite">Janaszkiewicz <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SLC22A13 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.19.18"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.19.18&tcname=">2.A.1.19.18</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Oranic anion transporter, Oat7 (exchanges sulfate conjugates (steroids) and other anions for butyrate) (<span id="ref5413.17393504" class="cite">Shin <em>et al</em>., 2007</span>)</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Animals</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>SLC22A9 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.19.19"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.19.19&tcname=">2.A.1.19.19</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The rat kidney basolateral potential-driven symport carrier, Oct2 (transports tetraethylammonium and many other organic cations) (<span id="ref6157.10600936" class="cite">Sweet and Pritchard 1999</span>).&nbsp; A cysteyl residue critical for substrate binding and transport has been identified (<span id="ref34546147.17567940" class="cite">Sturm <em>et al.</em> 2007</span>). Subtype-specific affinity of rat organic cation transporters rOCT1 and rOCT2
for corticosterone depends on three amino acids within the substrate binding region (<span id="ref34550819.15662045" class="cite">Gorboulev <em>et al.</em> 2005</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Oct2 of <em>Rattus norvegicus </em>(Q9R0W2)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.19.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.19.2&tcname=">2.A.1.19.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The ergothionine/carnitine/hydroxyurea/organic zwitterion transporter, OCTN1 or SVOP (SLC22A4). It is upregulated in polycythemia vera hematopoietic stem and progenitor cells (<span id="ref34552950.33677043" class="cite">Tan and Meier-Abt 2021</span>). It is associated with rheumatoid arthritis (<span id="ref7728.15751072" class="cite">Barton <em>et al.</em>, 2005</span>).&nbsp; Acetylcholine is a physiological substrate, and its transport could be involved in
nonneuronal cholinergic functions (<span id="ref10146.23771822" class="cite">Pochini <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>).&nbsp; OCTN1 and OCTN2 are associated with several
pathologies, such as inflammatory bowel disease, primary carnitine deficiency, diabetes,
neurological disorders, and cancer. It transports TEA, and transoirts acetylcholine better than acetylcarnitine (<span id="ref34544944.26724204" class="cite">Pochini <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SLC22A4 (OCTN1) of <em>Homo sapiens</em> (O14546)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.19.20"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.19.20&tcname=">2.A.1.19.20</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Prostaglandin (PGE2, PGE2&alpha;, and PGD(2)) -specific organic anion transporter. Exhibits Na<sup>+</sup> -independent and saturable transport. Shows narrow substrate selectivity and high affinity (<span id="ref7339.20448048" class="cite">Shiraya <em>et al.</em>, 2010</span>).&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Slc22a22 (OAT-PG) of <em>Mus musculus</em>&nbsp;(Q8R0S9)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.19.21"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.19.21&tcname=">2.A.1.19.21</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC> solute carrier family 22, member 24</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Animals</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>SLC22A24 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.19.22"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.19.22&tcname=">2.A.1.19.22</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>solute carrier family 22, member 14, Slc22a14, is crucial for sperm motility and male fertility in mice. It is expressed
specifically in male germ cells, and mice lacking the Slc22a14 gene show severe male infertility as well as sperm morphological changes (<span id="ref34545997.27811987" class="cite">Maruyama <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SLC22A14 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.19.23"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.19.23&tcname=">2.A.1.19.23</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC> solute carrier family 22, member 31</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Animals</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>SLC22A31 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.19.24"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.19.24&tcname=">2.A.1.19.24</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Solute carrier family 22 member 3 (Extraneuronal monoamine transporter) (EMT) (Organic cation transporter 3) of 556 aas and 12 TMSs.&nbsp; Induction of astrocytic Slc22a3 (EMT) regulates sensory processing through histone serotonylation (<span id="ref34557081.37319217" class="cite">Sardar <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SLC22A3 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.19.25"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.19.25&tcname=">2.A.1.19.25</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Solute carrier family 22 member 7 (liver transporter) (Organic anion transporter 2) (hOAT2), transports cyclic nucleotodes and the anti-viral drug, acyclovir (<span id="ref34544827.23268600" class="cite">Dahlin <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>). Expressed mostly in liver, but also in kidney, brain and red blood cells (<span id="ref34549880.29244191" class="cite">Sager <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). slc22 transporter homologs in flies, worms, and humans clarify the phylogeny of organic anion (OATs) and cation (OCTs) transporters (<span id="ref34545756.15054140" class="cite">Eraly <em>et al.</em> 2004</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SLC22A7 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.19.26"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.19.26&tcname=">2.A.1.19.26</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SLC22 OAT ortholog, Multispecific anion transporter, oat-1 (<span id="ref34550432.10525077" class="cite">George <em>et al.</em> 1999)</span></p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>oat-1 of <em>Caenorhabditis elegans</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.19.27"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.19.27&tcname=">2.A.1.19.27</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Solute carrier family 22 member 10 (Organic anion transporter 5)</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Animals</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>SLC22A10 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.19.28"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.19.28&tcname=">2.A.1.19.28</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Solute carrier family 22 member 23.&nbsp; The rat orthologue may be inactive (<span id="ref8913.21359964" class="cite">Bennett <em>et al.</em> 2011</span>). Human SLC22A23 is expressed in many tissues including brain (brain organic cation transporter (BOCT2) (<span id="ref8913.21359964" class="cite">Bennett <em>et al.</em> 2011</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SLC22A23 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.19.29"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.19.29&tcname=">2.A.1.19.29</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Solute carrier family 22 member 1 (Organic cation transporter 1) (hOCT1).&nbsp; May be a primary polyamine uptake porter (<span id="ref10203.23851697" class="cite">Abdulhussein and Wallace 2013</span>). Amino acids in TMS1 confer major functional differences between human and mouse orthologs of the polyspecific membrane transporter, OCT1. Reduced function alleles of OCT1 associate significantly with high LDL cholesterol levels (<span id="ref34556771.37333090" class="cite">Yee <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SLC22A1 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.19.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.19.3&tcname=">2.A.1.19.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p><a id="2.A.1.19.3"></a></p>
<p>The polyspecific organic cation (L- and D-carnitine, butyryl-L-carnitine, acetyl carnitine, &gamma;-butyro-betaine, glycinebetaine, &beta;-lactam antibiotics with a quaternary nitrogen such as cephaloridine, and others):Na<sup>+ </sup> symporter, OCTN2 (SLC22A5). Carnitine is transporter with high affinity (2 - 20 &mu;M0 (<span id="ref34544935.26607009" class="cite">Ingoglia <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>). Associated with Crohn''s disease (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref7728">Barton <em>et al.</em>, 2005</a>) as well as primary carnitine deficiency.&nbsp; The protein is glycosylated on extracytoplasmic asparagines, and these residues are in a region important for function and turnover (<span id="ref8944.21126579" class="cite">Filippo <em>et al.</em> 2011</span>).&nbsp; OCTN2 maintains the carnitine homeostasis, resulting from
intestinal absorption, distribution to tissues, and renal excretion/reabsorption (<span id="ref10146.23771822" class="cite">Pochini <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>).&nbsp; OCTN1 and OCTN2 are associated with several
pathologies, such as inflammatory bowel disease, primary carnitine deficiency, diabetes,
neurological disorders, and cancer.&nbsp; OCTN2 is activated in a process dependent on Caveolin1 (Q03135) which interacts directly with OCTN2 and by protein kinase C which does not phosphorylate OCTN2 directly (<span id="ref10650.24349196" class="cite">Czeredys <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>). Cholesterol stimulates the cellular uptake of L-carnitine by the carnitine/organic cation transporter novel 2 (OCTN2) (<span id="ref34552391.33334877" class="cite">Zhang <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). A dataset of OCTN2 variant functions and localization has been created, revealing important 
disease-causing mechanisms (<span id="ref34555570.36343260" class="cite">Koleske <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>).&nbsp; Primary carnitine deficiency (PCD) is caused by pathogenic variants of the SLC22A5 gene, which encodes a high affinity carnitine transporter. Carnitine is essential for the transport of acyl-CoA, produced from fatty acids, into the mitochondria where they are oxidised to produce energy (<span id="ref34556841.37475835" class="cite">Khries <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). OctN2 transports doxorubicin (<span id="ref34556923.37453608" class="cite">Yi <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). A novel pathogenic variant in the carnitine 
transporter gene, SLC22A5, is associated with metabolic carnitine 
deficiency and cardiomyopathy features (<span id="ref34557663.38166572" class="cite">Jolfayi <em>et al.</em> 2024</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SLC22A5 (OCTN2) of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.19.30"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.19.30&tcname=">2.A.1.19.30</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Solute carrier family 22 member 2 (Organic cation transporter 2) (hOCT2).&nbsp; Oct2 is a low affinity high efficiency choline transporter, enriched in synaptic vesicles of cholinergic neurons (<span id="ref10541.23958595" class="cite">Nakata <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>).&nbsp; May also transport peptides and peptide derivatives (<span id="ref34544736.26526343" class="cite">Volkov&aacute; <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>). It also transports L-carnitine (<span id="ref34546989.28653367" class="cite">Adeva-Andany <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>). OCT2 is a multispecific transporter with cholesterol-dependent allosteric features. The role of cholesterol recognition/interaction amino acid consensus sequences (CRAC and CARC) in the allosteric binding to 1-methyl-4-phenylpyridinium (MPP<sup>+</sup>) has been reported (<span id="ref34554117.34774844" class="cite">Sutter <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>). Comparisons of the inhibitory potential of elacridar and imazalil on 
metformin uptake with that on MPP uptake revealed substrate-dependent 
differences in hOCT2 and mOct2 for both inhibitors (<span id="ref34555763.36555439" class="cite">Kuehne <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SLC22A2 or Oct2 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.19.31"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.19.31&tcname=">2.A.1.19.31</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Solute carrier family 22 member 6 (Organic anion transporter 1) (hOAT1) (PAH transporter) (hPAHT) (Renal organic anion transporter 1) (hROAT1),&nbsp; Probably orthologous to 2.A.1.19.4. Functions in urate uptake from the circulation across the basolateral membrane of tubular cells (<span id="ref34545281.25209865" class="cite">Prestin <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>).&nbsp; It transports methotrexate (anticancer), acyclovir (antiviral), and adefovir (antiviral) (<span id="ref34550101.25475361" class="cite">Nigam 2015</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SLC22A6 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.19.32"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.19.32&tcname=">2.A.1.19.32</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Solute carrier family 22 member 15 (Fly-like putative transporter 1) (Flipt 1). This system is required for hepatocellular carcinoma proliferation and metastasis (<span id="ref34553708.34128989" class="cite">Fang <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>). SLC22A15 (FLIPT1) prefers zwitterionic compounds over cations and anions. Eight zwitterions transported include ergothioneine, carnitine, 
carnosine, gabapentin, as well as four cations including MPP<sup>+</sup> , thiamine and cimetidine. Carnosine was a 
specific substrate of SLC22A15 among the transporters in the SLC22A 
family. SLC22A15 transport was sodium-dependent 
and exhibited higher Km values for ergothioneine, carnitine, and carnosine 
compared to previously identified transporters for these ligands (<span id="ref34553708.34128989" class="cite"><span id="ref34553709.33124720" class="cite">Yee <em>et al.</em> 2020</span></span>). Many carnitine derivatives (i.e., (R)-3-hydrixybutryl carnitine, hexanoyl carnitine and glutaryl carnitine amoung others) are also transported.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SLC22A15 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.19.33"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.19.33&tcname=">2.A.1.19.33</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Solute carrier family 22 member 25 (Organic anion transporter UST6).&nbsp; Expressed exclusively in liver in both embryo and adult (<span id="ref34545750.15054140" class="cite">Eraly <em>et al.</em> 2004</span>). It may take up a nucleobase-containing compound (<span id="ref34553820.32697042" class="cite">Meixner <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SLC22A25 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.19.34"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.19.34&tcname=">2.A.1.19.34</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Multispecific drug transporter, solute carrier family 22 member 8 (Organic anion transporter 3) (hOAT3).&nbsp; Both OAT1 and OAT3 of humans are inhibited by caffeic acid (Ki ~ 17 &mu;M) (<a class="reflink" href="../../search/result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref11064">Uwai <em>et al.</em> 2011</a>; <a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref10334">Wu <em>et al.</em> 2013</a>).&nbsp; It is the principal uptake system for steviol glucuronide (SVG), the major metabolite derived from steviol, the aglycone of stevioside
and rebaudioside A (<span id="ref34544710.26525112" class="cite">Wang <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>).&nbsp; Also functions in urate uptake from the circulation across the basolateral membrane of renal tubular cells (<span id="ref34545281.25209865" class="cite">Prestin <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>). Inhibition of the proteasome, but not the lysosome, upregulates organic anion transporter 3 (<span id="ref34555767.36549459" class="cite">Fan <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>). See also 2.A.1.19.9.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SLC22A8 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.19.35"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.19.35&tcname=">2.A.1.19.35</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Solute carrier family 22 member 20 (Organic anion transporter 6; OAT6) of 555 aas and 12 probable TMSs. This protein is an apparent anionic odorant transporter in the olfactory epithelium of mice (<span id="ref34550108.15369770" class="cite">Monte <em>et al.</em> 2004</span>; <span id="ref34550109.17094945" class="cite">Kaler <em>et al.</em> 2006</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SLC22A20 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.19.36"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.19.36&tcname=">2.A.1.19.36</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p>Organic cation transporter-like protein, OrcT, of 548 aas and 12 TMSs (<span id="ref34550110.9409773" class="cite">Taylor <em>et al.</em> 1997</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>OrcT of <em>Drosophila melanogaster </em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.19.37"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.19.37&tcname=">2.A.1.19.37</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Organic cation transporter 1 (CeOCT1) of 568 aas and 12 TMSs.&nbsp; It transports tetraethylammonium ions and has broad substrate specificity (<span id="ref34550111.10209228" class="cite">Wu <em>et al.</em> 1999</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Worm</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Oct-1 of <em>Caenorhabditis elegans</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.19.38"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.19.38&tcname=">2.A.1.19.38</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Uncharacterized MFS-type transporter PB1E7.08c</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Yeast</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>SPAPB1E7.08c of <em>Schizosaccharomyces pombe  </em></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.19.39"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.19.39&tcname=">2.A.1.19.39</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Organic cation/carnitine transporter 6 (AtOCT6)</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Plants</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>OCT6 of <em>Arabidopsis thaliana </em></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.19.4"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.19.4&tcname=">2.A.1.19.4</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The polyspecific organic anion, cation and neutral molecule transporter, Oat1 (Slc22a6) (transports neutral compounds such as cardiac glycosides [i.e., ouabain] and steroids [i.e., aldosterone; cortisol; dexamethasone]; cationic compounds such as N-propylajmalinium, and anionic compounds such as p-aminohippurate, dicarboxylates, cyclic nucleotides, prostaglandins, urate, &beta;-lactam antibiotics, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, diuretics, bile salts and steroid conjugates [i.e., estrone-3-sulfate and estradiol-17-glucuronide]) transporter (H<sup>+</sup> symporter or uniporter) Probably catalyzes organic anion (uptake):dicarboxylate (efflux) antiport in the basolateral membrane of kidney proximal tubules) (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref2573">Eraly <em>et al</em>., 2003a</a>,<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref2574">b</a>).  A 3-dimensional model of OAT1 has led to the identification of residues involved in differential transport of substrates such as <em>p</em>-aminohippurate and cidofovir (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref3762">Perry <em>et al</em>., 2006</a>). Oat1 transports many antiviral agents (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref4663">Truong <em>et al</em>., 2008</a>).&nbsp; The human orthologue (Q4U2R8; 563aas) has been shown to be a multispecific organic anion transporter on the basolateral membrane of the proximal tubule in human kidney (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref6313">Hosoyamada <em>et al.</em> 1999</a>). A substrate binding hinge domain is required for transport-related structural changes (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref8872">Egenberger <em>et al.</em>, 2012</a>).&nbsp;Transports environmental toxins and clinically important drugs including anti-HIV therapeutics, anti-tumor drugs, antibiotics, anti-hypertensives, and anti-inflammatories (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref8875">Duan <em>et al.</em>, 2011</a>). hOAT1 has two GXXXG motifs in TMSs 2 and 5 which play critical roles in stability (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref8875">Duan <em>et al.</em>, 2011</a>).&nbsp; Both OAT1 and OAT3 of humans are inhibited by caffeic acid (Ki ~ 17 &mu;M) (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref11064">Uwai <em>et al.</em> 2011</a>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Oat1 of <em>Rattus norvegicus</em> (O35956)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.19.40"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.19.40&tcname=">2.A.1.19.40</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p><!-- test--><p>
																												                                         																																																								                                     <a id="2.A.1.19.40"></a></p>
																																																																	                                     <p>Organic anion transporter, Oat9.  A splice variant with 443 aas and 8 TMSs (Oa9S) was reported to transport L-carnitine (3 &mu;M), cimetidine (16 &mu;M) and salicylic acid (175 &mu;M), but the full length protein of 551 aas and 12 TMSs (Oat9L) was reported to be inactive (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref10064">Tsuchida <em>et al.</em> 2010</a>).  </p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Oat9 of <em>Mus musculus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.19.41"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.19.41&tcname=">2.A.1.19.41</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Organocation transporter, OCTN3.  Identified

SLC22a9.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>OctN3 of <em>Mus musculus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.19.5&tcname=">2.A.1.19.5</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The putative apical polyspecific organic cation transporter (cation:H<sup>+</sup> or cation:cation antiporter), Oct2 (substrates include monoamine neurotransmitters such as dopamine, noradrenaline, adrenaline and 5-hydroxytryptamine) (Oct2 exhibits some properties of an ion channel with an inner diameter of ~4 Å.  Selectivity: Cs<sup>+</sup> &gt; Rb<sup>+</sup> &gt; K<sup>+</sup> &gt; Na<sup>+</sup> %u2248 Li<sup>+</sup> (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref3117">Schmitt and Koepsell, 2005</a>)) Chloride dependent, but a single mutation (R466K) abolishes this dependency (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref3921">Rizwan <em>et al</em>., 2007</a>). Also transports ochratoxin (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref3921">Rizwan <em>et al</em>., 2007</a>) and cisplatin and oxaliplatin (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref5001">Yonezama <em>et al</em>., 2006</a>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Animals</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Oct2 of <i>Sus scrofa</i> (O02713)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.19.50"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.19.50&tcname=">2.A.1.19.50</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Uncharacterized solute carrier family 22 member 15-like of 543 aas and 12 TMSs (<span id="ref34552160.33047351" class="cite">Posavi <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>UP of <em><span class="highlight">Eurytemora affinis</span></em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.19.6"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.19.6&tcname=">2.A.1.19.6</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The polyspecific potential-sensitive organic cation uptake transporter, Oct3 (transport substrates include the neurotoxin 1-methyl-4-phenylpyridinium and monoamine neurotransmitters such as dopamine). Mediates paraquat (herbicide) neurotoxicity (<span id="ref8259.22143804" class="cite">Rappold <em>et al.</em>, 2011</span>). SLC22 transporters involved in drug elimination and organ distribution 
are polyspecific. The cryo-EM structure of SLC22A3 (OCT3) is 
available (<span id="ref34556632.37117104" class="cite">Meyer-T&ouml;nnies and Tzvetkov 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Oct3 of <em>Rattus norvegicus</em> (O88446)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.19.7"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.19.7&tcname=">2.A.1.19.7</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>The polyspecific organic anion (and cation) (anions: p-aminohippurate, ochratoxin A, estrone sulfate, anionic drugs, anionic neurotransmitter metabolites; cation: cimetidine) transporter, Oat3 (slc22a8) (catalyzes organic anion (uptake): dicarboxylate (efflux) antiport in the basolateral membrane of the renal proximal tubule) (<span id="ref2573.12504088" class="cite">Eraly <em>et al</em>., 2003a</span>,<span id="ref2574.12920404" class="cite">b</span>); transports many antiviral agents (<span id="ref4663.18174163" class="cite">Truong <em>et al</em>., 2008</span>).</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Animals</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Oat3 of <i>Rattus norvegicus</i> (Q9R1U7)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.19.8"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.19.8&tcname=">2.A.1.19.8</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p><a id="2.A.1.19.8"></a></p>
<p><a id="2.A.1.19"></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p><a id="2.A.1.19.8"></a></p>
<p>The human organic cation transporter, SLC22A17.&nbsp; The rat orthologue may be inactive (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref8913">Bennett <em>et al.</em> 2011).</a> It is also the cell surface receptor for Lipocalin-2 (LCN2) that plays a key role in iron 
homeostasis and transport. It is able to bind iron-LCN2, 
followed by internalization and release of iron, thereby 
increasing intracellular iron concentration and leading to inhibition of
 apoptosis (<span id="ref34549881.26635366" class="cite">Cabedo Martinez <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>). It also binds iron-free LCN2, followed by 
internalization and its association with an intracellular 
siderophore, leading to iron chelation and iron transfer to the 
extracellular medium, thereby reducing intracellular iron concentrations
and resulting in apoptosis.&nbsp; The SLC22A17/lipocalin-2 receptor plays a role in renal endocytosis of proteins involved in metalloproteins, particularly on iron- and cadmium-binding proteins (<span id="ref34557186.37589051" class="cite">Th&eacute;venod <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).&nbsp; Other renal functions of SLC22A17 include its contribution to osmotic stress adaptation, protection against urinary tract infection, and renal carcinogenesis.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SLC22A17 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.19.9"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.19.9&tcname=">2.A.1.19.9</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The osteosclerosis protein, Roct (organic anion transporter 3, Oat3) (Slc22a8) (catalyzes organic anion (uptake):di-carboxylate (efflux) antiport in the basolateral membrane of the renal proximal tubule) (<span id="ref2573.12504088" class="cite">Eraly <em>et al</em>., 2003a</span>,<span id="ref2574.12920404" class="cite">b</span>); transports glutathione and many antiviral agents (<span id="ref4663.18174163" class="cite">Truong <em>et al</em>., 2008</span>).&nbsp; It is a multispecific drug transporter, critical for the renal handling of common drugs (e.g, antibiotics, antivirals, diuretics) and toxins.&nbsp; Probably handles hydroxylated and glucouronidated metabolites, consistent with the "remote sensing and signaling hypothesis" (<span id="ref10334.23920220" class="cite">Wu <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>).&nbsp; It may also handle dietary flavonoids and antioxidants.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Roct (Oat3) of <em>Mus musculus</em> (O88909)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=2.A.1.2">2.A.1.2 The Drug:H<sup>+</sup> Antiporter-1 (12 Spanner) (DHA1) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.1&tcname=">2.A.1.2.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Pyridoxine, pyridoxal, pyridoxamine, amiloride:H<sup>+</sup> cotransporter (Km (pyridoxine) = 22 &mu;M) (<span id="ref3179.15701794" class="cite">Stolz <em>et al.</em>, 2005</span>). Also takes up thiamine (<span id="ref5007.18201975" class="cite">Vogl <em>et al.</em>, 2008</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Yeast</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bsu1 (Car1) of <em>Schizosaccharomyces pombe</em> (P33532)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.10"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.10&tcname=">2.A.1.2.10</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Quinolone (and other drug):H<sup>+</sup> antiporter, NorA.&nbsp; Many synthetic inhibitors have been identified (<span id="ref34546007.27757014" class="cite">Bhaskar <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>). 1,8-Naphthyridines sulfonamides are NorA efflux pump inhibitors (<span id="ref34553821.33385589" class="cite">Oliveira-Tintino <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>NorA of <em>Staphylococcus aureus</em> (P0A0J7)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.100"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.100&tcname=">2.A.1.2.100</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bcr/CflA family drug resistance efflux transporter of 389 aas and 12 TMSs. Multidrug-resistance in <em>S. aureus</em> is inhibited by the endocannabinoid, anandamide (<span id="ref34555087.35887146" class="cite">Sionov <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MDR exporter of <em>Staphylococcus aureus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.101"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.101&tcname=">2.A.1.2.101</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bmr-like protein SblA of 395 aas and 12 TMSs.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SblA of <em>Staphylococcus aureus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.102"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.102&tcname=">2.A.1.2.102</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>TetA class C (TetA(C)) of 396 aas and 12 TMSs. The TetA(C) of the transposon, Tn10, not only exports tetracycline by a proton antiport mechanism, it also increases susceptibility to cadmium, <span class="highlight">fusaric acid</span>, bleomycin and&nbsp; several classes of cationic aminoglycoside antibiotics (<span id="ref34546847.7711837" class="cite">Griffith <em>et al.</em> 1995</span>).&nbsp; For this reason, it has been used to generate dual counter selection procedures (<span id="ref34546848.24203710" class="cite">Li <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>). It is not certain that this is due to import of these compounds as this increased susceptibility could be due to a secondary effect.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>TetA(C) of <em>E. coli</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.103"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.103&tcname=">2.A.1.2.103</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Tetracycline:H<sup>+</sup> class D, (TetA(D)) antiporter of 286 aas and 12 TMSs.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>TetA(D) of <em>E. coli</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.104"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.104&tcname=">2.A.1.2.104</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS carrier of 490 aas and 12 TMSs, MfsD14a or Hiat1 (<span>Hippocampus abundant transcript 1 protein)</span> is a member of the SLC18 family.&nbsp; It is 76% identical to 2.A.1.2.30. Mutant mice (<em>Mus musculus</em>, strain 129S6Sv/Ev) were generated with the Mfsd14a gene disrupted with a LacZ reporter gene. Mutant mice are viable and healthy, but males are sterile due to a 100-fold reduction in the number of spermatozoa in the vas deferens. Male mice have adequate levels of testosterone and show normal copulatory behaviour. The few spermatozoa that are formed show rounded head defects similar to those found in humans with globozoospermia. Spermatogenesis proceeds normally up to the round spermatid stage, but the subsequent structural changes associated with spermiogenesis are severely disrupted with failure of acrosome formation, sperm head condensation and mitochondrial localization to the mid-piece of the sperm. Mfsd14a expression occurs in Sertoli cells, suggesting that MFSD14A may transport a solute from the bloodstream that is required for spermiogenesis (<span id="ref34547450.27107036" class="cite">Doran <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>). MFSD14A and MFSD14B are intracellular neuronal membrane-bound proteins,
 expressed in the Golgi and ER, and their levels of expression are affected by both 
starvation and a high fat diet to varying degrees in the mouse brain (<span id="ref34551089.28179877" class="cite">Lekholm <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>). It is associated with milk production in buffalo and sheep 
breeds, as well as growth of chickens and goats, and drastically affect s
sperm morphogenesis (<span id="ref34556456.37138914" class="cite">Luo <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). The functional InDel polymorphism (rs1089950828) reflects growth traits in domestic sheep populations (<span id="ref34556456.37138914" class="cite">Luo <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MfsD14a of<em> Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.105"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.105&tcname=">2.A.1.2.105</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFSD9 of 474 aas and 12 TMSs. In the mouse, this protein and MFS4a localize to neurons in the brain; their mRNA expression levels are affected by diet (<span id="ref34547464.29049335" class="cite">Perland <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>). This protein is in the SLC18 family (<span id="ref34555002.35901096" class="cite">Gyimesi and Hediger 2022</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFSD9 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.106"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.106&tcname=">2.A.1.2.106</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p><!-- test--><p>
																												                                         																																																								                                     
																																																																	                                     Uncharacterized MFS-type transporter YvmA</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Bacilli</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>yvmA of <em>Bacillus subtilis </em></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.107"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.107&tcname=">2.A.1.2.107</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS porter of 399 aas and 12 TMSs, HepP, involved in the uptake of glycoside(s), with a specific physiological role in production of heterocyst exopolysaccharide, HEP (<span id="ref34547687.22753066" class="cite">L&oacute;pez-Igual <em>et al.</em> 2012</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>HepP of <em>Anabaena</em> or <em>Nostoc</em> sp. (strain PCC 7120)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.108"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.108&tcname=">2.A.1.2.108</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative spermine uptake porter of 552 aas and 12 TMSs, SPBC409.08.&nbsp; Spermine and the spermine-precursor, spermidine, are implicated in ageing as they are involved in autophagy-dependent lifespan extension (<span id="ref34548764.30072377" class="cite">Ellis <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SPBC409.08 of <em>Schizosaccharomyces pombe</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.109"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.109&tcname=">2.A.1.2.109</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS porter of 414 aas and 12 TMSs.&nbsp; It has been suggested that it could be a citrate efflux porter (<span id="ref34549528.28348231" class="cite">Braakman <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS porter of <em>Prochlorococcus marinus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.11"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.11&tcname=">2.A.1.2.11</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Monoamine transporter; drug (doxorubicin, ethidium bromide-6-G):H<sup>+</sup> antiporter</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Animals</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>VMAT1 of <I>Rattus norvegicus</i> </TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.110"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.110&tcname=">2.A.1.2.110</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Florfenicol-chloramphenicol resistance drug exporter, FloR of 404 aas and 12 TMSs (<span id="ref34549947.15980376" class="cite">Braibant <em>et al.</em> 2005</span>). This system in <em>V. cholerae</em> (98.8% identical) exports chlorampenicol (<span id="ref34557716.38180462" class="cite">Saha <em>et al.</em> 2024</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>FloR of <em>Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica </em>serovar Typhimurium str. DT104</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.111"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.111&tcname=">2.A.1.2.111</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Zinc-induced facilitator-like protein 1, ZIFL1 or Tpo1p&nbsp; of 478 aas and 12 TMSs.
