activated in response to this herbicide. Tpo1p is required to reduce the intracellular concentration of 
2,4-D (<span id="ref34550114.19440702" class="cite">Cabrito <em>et al.</em> 2009</span>). <span>K<sup>+</sup> may be its physiological substrate, and it </span>may play a dual role in polar auxin transport and drought stress tolerance<span> (<span id="ref34550115.23524662" class="cite">Remy <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>). </span><span><span>It is also involved in auxin efflux and acts as a positive 
regulator of shootward transport at the root apex. Possibly, it may mediate proton 
efflux from the vacuolar compartment (</span></span><span><span><span><span id="ref34550115.23524662" class="cite">Remy <em>et al.</em> 2013</span></span>).</span></span></p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Tpo1 of <em>Arabidopsis thaliana</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.112"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.112&tcname=">2.A.1.2.112</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Uncharacterized protein of 904 aas with 16 TMSs in a 6 + 6 + 3 + 1 TMS arrangement, where the last 300 aas comprise the non-MFS integral membrane domain with at least 4, and maybe as many as 6 TMSs. It is <span>involved in resistance to the antifungal drugs 
miconazole, tioconazole, clotrimazole and ketoconazole as well as to 
quinidine </span><span>&nbsp; (<span id="ref34550743.23629708" class="cite">Costa <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>; <span id="ref34550744.27148215" class="cite">Costa <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>).&nbsp; It also plays a role in biofilm formation. </span><span>Compared to the wild type, the <em>C. glabrata</em> <em>∆qdr2</em> mutant showed lower adhesion 
activity and higher fluconazole susceptibility when assessed as a 
biofilm. The mutant also showed decreased metabolic activity during 
biofilm formation and grew more slowly under 
neutral-basic pH conditions. The qdr2 deletion in <em>C. glabrata</em> resulted in
 an impaired ability to maintain pH homeostasis, which led in turn to a 
reduction of cell growth and of adherence to an artificial matrix (<span id="ref34550745.31519064" class="cite">Widiasih Widiyanto <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>). </span>Mitochondrion-targeted antifungal drugs have been reviewed (<span id="ref34556449.37195189" class="cite">Qin <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MDR pump of <em>Candida glabrata </em>(Yeast)<em> (Torulopsis glabrata)</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.116"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.116&tcname=">2.A.1.2.116</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MDR efflux pump, Bcr/CflA, of 411 aas and 12 TMSs.&nbsp; Confer's chloramphenicol resistance (<span id="ref34550749.31291955" class="cite">Yang <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Brc of <em>Myxococcus xanthus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.117"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.117&tcname=">2.A.1.2.117</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Uncharacterized protein of 510 aas and 12 TMSs.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>UP of <em>Fistulifera solaris</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.118"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.118&tcname=">2.A.1.2.118</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Na<sup>+</sup> (K<sup>+</sup> or Li<sup>+</sup>)/H<sup>+</sup> antiporter and multidrug:Na<sup>+</sup> anitporter, MdrP of 424 aas and 12 TMSs.&nbsp; It exports ethidium and norfloxacin in exchange for Na<sup>+</sup> taken up (<span id="ref34551608.30061877" class="cite">Abdel-Motaal <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). Zhang, Abdel-Motaal et al, 2020).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MdrP of <em>Planococcus maritimus</em><a class="labs-docsum-title" href="https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/30061877/?from_term=Abdel-Motaal%2C+H.%2C+Meng%2C+L.%2C+Zhang%2C+Z.&amp;from_sort=date&amp;from_pos=1"><em></em></a></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.119"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.119&tcname=">2.A.1.2.119</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>AaMFS1 is an efflux pump for the transmembrane transport of tenuazonic acid (TeA) (<span id="ref34554443.35175146" class="cite">Sun <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>).&nbsp; See 4.C.1.1.19 for relevant information about the TeA synthetase that makes TeA before exporting it (<span id="ref34554443.35175146" class="cite">Sun <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>).  including cycloheximide but also azoles such as fuconazole, 
ketoconazole and itraconazole (<span id="ref34555148.11065353" class="cite">Calabrese <em>et al.</em> 2000</span>). It mediates efflux of histatin 5, a salivary human antimicrobial peptide, and

This efflux pump is a
 proton-driven transporter that can reduce the intracellular 
tetracycline concentration. In normal conditions, the expression of <em>kpsrmfs</em> was at a low level, while artificial overexpression of it led to 
increased endogenous reactive oxygen species (ROS) production. By comparing the functions of adjacent genes of <em>kpsrmfs</em>, another four genes that can confer similar 
phenotypes, indicating a special regulon that regulates cell growth..&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>KpsrMFS of <em>Klebsiella pneumoniae</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.13"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.13&tcname=">2.A.1.2.13</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Vesicular acetylcholine:H<sup>+</sup> antiporter, UNC-17/VAChT.&nbsp; Mutants grow slowly and are uncoordinated, but the defects can be corrected by mutation of two interacting monotopic protein, synaptobrevin-1/SNB-1 (109 aas and 1 C-terminal TMS; <span id="ref34547728.16604067" class="cite">Sandoval <em>et al.</em> 2006</span>) and SUP-1 (103 aas and 1 C-terminal TMS (<span id="ref9148.23051648" class="cite">Mathews <em>et al.</em> 2012</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Unc17 of <em>Caenorhabditis elegans</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.14"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.14&tcname=">2.A.1.2.14</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative arabinose efflux porter, AraJ.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>AraJ of <em>E. coli</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.15"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.15&tcname=">2.A.1.2.15</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Arabinose (but not xylose) and isopropyl &beta;-D-thio-galactopyranoside:H<sup>+</sup> antiporter, YdeA (<span id="ref11179.22952739" class="cite">Koita and Rao 2012</span>). Overexpression of the gene for YdeA allows export of Lacto-<em>N</em>-triose (LNT II) and lacto-<em>N</em>-tetraose (LNT), human milk oligosaccharides (<span id="ref34555050.35426313" class="cite">Sugita and Koketsu 2022</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>YdeA of <em>E. coli</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.16"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.16&tcname=">2.A.1.2.16</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Polyamines (spermine, spermidine, putrescine); paraquat; methylglyoxal bis(guanylhydrazone):H<sup>+</sup> antiporter (in the plasma membrane) (activated by phosphorylation) (<span id="ref3113.15637075" class="cite">Uemura <em>et al</em>., 2005</span>)</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Yeast</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>TPO1 (YLL028w) of <em>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.17"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.17&tcname=">2.A.1.2.17</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Fluconazole:H<sup>+</sup> antiporter</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Yeast</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Flr1 of <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> </TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.18"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.18&tcname=">2.A.1.2.18</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Lactose and melibiose (>>IPTG) efflux pump, SotB</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>SotB of <i>Erwinia chrysanthemi</i> </TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.19"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.19&tcname=">2.A.1.2.19</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p><a id="2.A.1.2.19"></a></p>
<p>The multidrug (chloramphenicol, tetracycline, norfloxacin, doxorubicin, trimethoprim, acriflavin, ethidium bromide, tetraphenylphosphonium, TPP, benzalkonium, ciprofloxacin, thiamphenicol, IPTG) resistance exporter, MdfA (catalyzes both electrogenic and electroneutral transport) (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref2817">Adler and Bibi, 2004</a>). Can function as a Na<sup>+ </sup> (K<sup>+</sup>)/H<sup>+ </sup> antiporter (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref3915">Lewinson and Bibi 2001</a>; <a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref3914">Higgins, 2007</a>). Is known to provide resistance to a wide variety of dissimilar toxic compounds, including neutral, cationic and zwitterionic substances.&nbsp; Crystals that diffracted to 3.4 &Aring; resolution and belonged to the hexagonal space group P6122 have been obtained (<span id="ref34547070.28695852" class="cite">Nagarathinam <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>). For review of MdfA see <a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref4163">Lewinson <em>et al</em>., 2006</a>. The conformational switch accompanying transport is induced by the promiscuous binding of substrates and/or inhibitors to the binding pocket (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref6969">Fluman <em>et al.</em>, 2009</a>). MdfA normally extrudes monovalent cationic drugs in exchange for a single proton, but it transports divalent cationic drugs poorly. It can be mutated to antiport a divalent cationic drug for 2 protons (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref9210">Tirosh <em>et al.</em>, 2012</a>). Transporters acting across the inner and outer membranes have synergistic effects with each other, but transporters acting across the same membrane are usually additive but can be synergistic under special circumstances, owing to a bifurcation controlled by the barrier constant (<span id="ref34550993.32039579" class="cite">Saha <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). Promiscuity in the geometry of electrostatic interactions between&nbsp; MdfA and cationic substrates has been demonstrated (<span id="ref34551079.15557318" class="cite">Adler and Bibi 2005</span>). With respect to ethidium bromide, the inner membrane transporter MdfA is synergistic to the TolC-dependent efflux across the outer membrane (<span id="ref34550993.32039579" class="cite">Saha <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). The conformational behavior of MdfA in response to substrate binding has been studied (<span id="ref34552898.33771471" class="cite">Bahrenberg <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>). Overexpression of the gene for MdfA allows export of Lacto-<em>N</em>-triose (LNT II) and lacto-<em>N</em>-tetraose (LNT), human milk oligosaccharides (<a class="reflink" href="https://tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref34555050">Sugita and Koketsu 2022</a>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MdfA of <em>E. coli</em> (P0AEY8)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.2&tcname=">2.A.1.2.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Cycloheximide:H<sup>+</sup> antiporter</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Yeast</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>CyhR of <i>Candida maltosa</i></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.20"></A><A 2001</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MdtG of <em>E. coli</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.21"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.21&tcname=">2.A.1.2.21</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The norfloxacin/enoxacin resistance protein, MdtH or YceL (<span id="ref1912.11566977" class="cite">Nishino and Yamaguchi 2001</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The vesicular acetylcholine transporter, VAChT (pumps acetylcholine into synaptic vesicles).&nbsp; The acetyl choline and vesamicol binding sites have been identified (<span 2010</span>). The SLC18 family has been reviewed (<span id="ref34551233.23506877" class="cite">Lawal and Krantz 2018</span>). VAChT in the brain is an important presynaptic cholinergic biomarker (<span id="ref34557377.37615234" class="cite">Hu <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SLC18A3 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.29"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.29&tcname=">2.A.1.2.29</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The vesicular monoamine transporter, VMAT2 (pumps dopamine, norepinephrine, serotonin and histamine into synaptic vesicles) (<span id="ref34546162.27836486" class="cite">Cliburn <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>). VMAT2 physically and functionally interacts with the enzymes responsible for dopamine synthesis (<span id="ref7223.19903816" class="cite">Cartier <em>et al.</em>, 2010</span>).&nbsp; Molecular hinge points mediating alternating access have been identified (<span id="ref9819.23530208" class="cite">Yaffe <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>). The substituted amphetamine, 3,4-methylenedioxy-methamphetamine (MDMA, 
ecstasy), is a widely used drug of abuse that induces non-exocytotic 
release of serotonin, <span class="highlight">dopamine</span>,
 and norepinephrine through their cognate transporters as well as 
blocking the reuptake of neurotransmitter by the same transporters (<span id="ref34545769.27638414" class="cite">Sealover <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>). The slc18a2 gene is expressed at high levels in neuroepithelial cells (<span id="ref34555075.35710785" class="cite">Pan <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>). Synaptic vesicle proteins are selectively delivered to axons in mammalian neurons (<span id="ref34555951.36729040" class="cite">Watson <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). VMAT2 may play a role in Parkinson's disease (<span id="ref34556493.37089789" class="cite">Zhou <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). Dopaminergic cell protection and alleviation of neuropsychiatric disease symptoms are aleviated by VMAT2 expression (<span id="ref34557291.37740715" class="cite">Lee <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>VMAT2 (SLC18A2) of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.3&tcname=">2.A.1.2.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Chloramphenicol:H<sup>+</sup> antiporter, CmlA; Cmr; MdfA.&nbsp; Multidrug exporter that also catalyzes efflux of arabinose (but not xylose) and&nbsp; isopropyl &beta;-thiogalactoside (<span id="ref11179.22952739" class="cite">Koita and Rao 2012</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>CmlA of <em>Pseudomonas aeruginosa</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.30"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.30&tcname=">2.A.1.2.30</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The hippocampus abundant transcript-like 1 protein, HIATL1 or MFSD14B, of 506 aas and 12 TMSs (putative drug exporter) is a SLC18 family member. There is a correlation between a risk for colorectal cancer, alcohol consumption and variants in the 9q22.32/HIATL1 gene (<span id="ref34551546.27723779" class="cite">Gong <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>). MFSD14A (HIAT1) and MFSD14B (HIATL1) are in the mouse central nervous system throughout the adult brain (<span id="ref34551089.28179877" class="cite">Lekholm <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>). Expression of SLC22A18 regulates oxaliplatin resistance (<span id="ref34555023.35411243" class="cite">Kim <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>), and in cases of oxaliplatin resistance due to low SLC22A18 expression, 
resistance can be overcome by treatment with an ERK inhibitor (<span id="ref34555023.35411243" class="cite">Kim <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>). Two ammonia transporters, HIAT1alpha and HIAT1beta, in the American Horseshoe Crab, <em>Limulus polyphemus</em>, have been identified and characterized (<span id="ref34555802.36577451" class="cite">Sachs <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>). This gene is associated with milk production in buffalo and sheep breeds, as well as growth of chickens and goats, and drastically affect sperm formation (<span id="ref34556456.37138914" class="cite">Luo <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). The functional InDel polymorphism (rs1089950828) reflects growth traits in domestic sheep populations (<span id="ref34556456.37138914" class="cite">Luo <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>HIATL1 of <em> Homo sapiens </em> (NP_115947)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.31"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.31&tcname=">2.A.1.2.31</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The multidrug transporter, QDR2, required for resistance to quinidine, barban, cisplatin, and bleomycin; may play a role in potassium uptake.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>QDR2 of <em>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</em> (P40474)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.32"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.32&tcname=">2.A.1.2.32</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>The chloramphenicol resistance protein, Chl<sup>R</sup></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Chl<sup>R</sup> of <i>Streptomyces lividans</i> (P31141)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.33"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.33&tcname=">2.A.1.2.33</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>The Hol1 MFS transporter (Mutation allows the uptake of histidinol and other cations (<span id="ref4268.8955402" class="cite">Wright <em>et al</em>., 1996</span>). The N-terminal 200 residues show 22% identity with 2.A.1.2.1 and 2.A.1.2.16).</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Yeast</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Hol1 of <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> (P53389)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.34"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.34&tcname=">2.A.1.2.34</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The MDR efflux pump, PmrA (exports fluoroquinolone and other compounds) and other components including the antimicrobial peptide, colistin (<span id="ref10845.17350332" class="cite">Martinez-Garriga <em>et al.</em> 2007; </span><span id="ref5067.18312276" class="cite">Pamp <em>et al</em>., 2008</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PmrA of <em>Streptococcus pneumoniae</em> (P0A4K4)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.35"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.35&tcname=">2.A.1.2.35</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The caffeine resistance protein 5 (Caf5) (<span id="ref4269.14758541" class="cite">Benko <em>et al.</em>, 2004</span>)</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Caf5 of <em>Schizosaccharomyces pombe</em> (O94528)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.36"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.36&tcname=">2.A.1.2.36</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>The multidrug resistance protein Aqr1 (YNL065w) (exports short chain monocarboxylates but not more hydrophobic acids such as octonate and quinidine. The two halves of the protein each have an N-terminal. 150 residue hydrophilic region found in many fungi followed by a 200 residue, 6 TMS, transmembrane region. This suggests that an intragenic duplication event gave rise to 12 TMS proteins independently of most other MFS carriers, but this has not been demonstrated, possibly because of extensive sequence divergence of the second half.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Fungi</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Qdr3 of <em><span> Saccharomyces cerevisiae </span></em><span>(P38227)<br Two proton translocation pathways have been proposed (<span id="ref5381.17587868" class="cite">Bapna <em>et al</em>., 2007</span>), but&nbsp;<span id="ref7098.20472749" class="cite">Schaedler and van Veen, 2010</span> have provided evidence that a flexible cation binding site in LmrP is associated with variable proton coupling. Basic residues R260 and K357 affect the conformational dynamics of LmrP (<span id="ref8880.22761697" class="cite">Wang and van Veen, 2012</span>).&nbsp; Basic residues, R260 and K357 control the conformational dynamics of the protein<span id="ref8880.22761697" class="cite"> (Wang and van Veen 2012</span>).&nbsp; Also specifically catalyzes Ca<sup>2+</sup>:3H<sup>+</sup> antiport with an affinity of 7 &mu;M (<span id="ref9193.22723704" class="cite">Zhang <em>et al.</em> 2012</span>). Two carboxylates (Asp-235 and Glu-327) are critical for Ca<sup>2+</sup> binding.&nbsp; Protonation drives major conformational switches (<span id="ref10462.24316739" class="cite">Masureel <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>). The system exhibits plasticity in proton interactions, which is a consequence of the
flexibility in the location of key residues that are responsible for proton/multidrug antiport (<span id="ref34546200.27917857" class="cite">Nair <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>).</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Gram-positive bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>LmrP of <em>Lactococcus lactis</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.50"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.50&tcname=">2.A.1.2.50</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS porter</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Slime molds</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS porter of <em>Dictyostelium purpureum</em> (F0ZU09)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.51"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.51&tcname=">2.A.1.2.51</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Chloramphenicol resistance pump, CraA (43% identical to MdfA of <em>E. coli</em>) (<span id="ref8036.19581458" class="cite">Roca <em>et al.</em>, 2009</span>). It is a broad specificity transporter exporting chloramphenicol, thiamphenicol, florfenicol, ethidium, dequalinium, chlorhexidine, benzalkonium, mitomycin C and TPP<sup>+</sup>. Glu-38 is essential for activity (<span id="ref34553120.30783664" class="cite">Foong <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>CraA of <em>Acinetobacter baumannii</em>&nbsp;(A3M9E9)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.52"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.52&tcname=">2.A.1.2.52</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Puromycin resistance MDR protein, MdtM (<span id="ref8068.21173244" class="cite">Soo <em>et al.</em>, 2011</span>).&nbsp; Also catalyzes bile salt:H<sup>+</sup> antiport, and binds cholate and deoxycholate to the protein with micromolar affinity. Functions as an MDR pump (<span id="ref1912.11566977" class="cite">Nishino and Yamaguchi 2001</span>). Acts synergistically with AcrAB-TolC (<span id="ref34544663.24684269" class="cite">Paul <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>). The ortholog has been characterized in <em>Salmonella enterica</em> serovar Typhi, and specific residues have been shown to be important for transport and stability (<span id="ref34553507.33983672" class="cite">Shaheen <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MdtM of <em>E. coli</em>&nbsp;(P39386)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.53"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.53&tcname=">2.A.1.2.53</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MDR pump, SLC22A18 in lung cancer cells (<span id="ref8285.22237119" class="cite">Lei <em>et al.</em>, 2012</span>). It has 424 aas and 12 TMSs. Allelic loss in the absence of mutations in 
the polyspecific transporter gene BWR1A on 11p15.5 in hepatoblastoma has
 been shown (<span id="ref34551496.15239143" class="cite">Albrecht <em>et al.</em> 2004</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SLC22A18 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.54"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.54&tcname=">2.A.1.2.54</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>LigA-like protein</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>LigA-like protein of <em>Streptomyces coelicolor</em> (Q9KYE9)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.55"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.55&tcname=">2.A.1.2.55</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Peptide exporter (Ala-Gln and Ala-branched chain amino and dipeptides) (<span id="ref8405.20067529" class="cite">Hayashi <em>et al.</em>, 2010</span>).&nbsp; May also export arabinose (but not xylose) and function as an MDR pump (<span id="ref11179.22952739" class="cite">Koita and Rao 2012</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>YdeE of <em>E. coli&nbsp;</em>(P31126)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.56"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.56&tcname=">2.A.1.2.56</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>NCL7 or MFSD8. Neuronal ceroid lipofuscinosis, NCL, a neuro-degenerative genetic disease, is caused by mutations in at least 8 different human genes, one of which, CLN7 (MFSD8), is associated with late infantile NCL. CLN7 is localized to lysosomes (<span id="ref8420.20826447" class="cite">Sharifi <em>et al.</em>, 2010</span>).&nbsp; Loss of this putative lysosomal <span class="highlight">transporter</span> in the brain leads to lysosomal dysfunction, impaired constitutive autophagy and neurodegeneration late in the disease (<span id="ref34544928.26681805" class="cite">Brandenstein <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>). An in-frame deletion in the MFSD8 gene gave rise to neuronal ceroid lipofuscinosis type 7 (<span id="ref34549782.30249282" class="cite">Hosseini Bereshneh and Garshasbi 2018</span>). In <em>D. discoideum</em>, it interacts with cathepsin D (CtsD), as well as human orthologs of CLN3 (Cln3) and CLN5 (Cln5) (<span id="ref34551537.32087303" class="cite">Huber <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). In humans the defect can also affect cardiac conducting cells and cardiomyocytes as well as basophilic degeneration of myocardium. (<span id="ref34555028.31726844" class="cite">Iannaccone Farka&scaron;ov&aacute; <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>).&nbsp; Moreover, loss of Mfsd8 alters the secretome during <em>Dictyostelium</em> aggregation (<span id="ref34557407.37742391" class="cite">Huber <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>NCL7 of <em>Homo sapiens</em>&nbsp;(Q8NHS3)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.57"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.57&tcname=">2.A.1.2.57</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS-type polyamine transporter SLC18B1 or VPAT (Solute carrier family 18 member B1) of 456 aas and 12 TMSs.&nbsp; Polyamines synthesized in neurons and astrocytes are stored in secretory
 vesicles and released upon depolarization. Vesicular storage 
is mediated in an ATP-dependent, reserpine-sensitive process.&nbsp; <span class="highlight">SLC18B1</span> is the fourth member of the SLC18 transporter family, which includes 
vesicular monoamine transporters and a vesicular acetylcholine 
transporter. Proteoliposomes containing purified human <span class="highlight">SLC18B1</span> protein actively transport spermine and spermidine in exchange of H<sup>+</sup>. <span class="highlight">The SLC18B1</span> protein is predominantly expressed in the hippocampus and is associated with vesicles in astrocytes. <span class="highlight">SLC18B1</span> gene knockdown decreased both <span class="highlight">the amount of the SLC18B1</span> protein and the spermine/spermidine contents of astrocytes (<span id="ref34550581.25355561" class="cite">Hiasa <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>).&nbsp; Slc18b1 knock out mice have reduced polyamine content in the brain These mice have impaired short and long term 
memory in novel object recognition, radial arm maze and 
self-administration paradigms (<span id="ref34550580.31800589" class="cite">Fredriksson <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>). Moreover, Slc18b1 KO mice have 
altered expression of genes involved in Long Term Potentiation, 
plasticity, calcium signalling and synaptic functions, and expression of components of GABA and glutamate signalling are alterred. These mutants show partial resistance to diazepam, manifested as lowered reduction in locomotion after diazepam treatment. 
Possibly, removal of Slc18b1 leads to reduction of polyamine 
contents in neurons, resulting in reduced GABA signalling due to 
a long-term reduction in glutamatergic signalling (<span id="ref34550580.31800589" class="cite">Fredriksson <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>).&nbsp; Polyamine release and vesicular polyamine transporter, SLC18B1; VPAT,. expression in megakaryoblastic cells and plateletshas been documented (<span id="ref34557919.38527572" class="cite">Uehara <em>et al.</em> 2024</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>C6orf192 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.58"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.58&tcname=">2.A.1.2.58</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Protein ZINC INDUCED FACILITATOR 1</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Plants</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>ZIF1 of <em>Arabidopsis thaliana</em></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.59"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.59&tcname=">2.A.1.2.59</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Uncharacterized MFS-type transporter C330.07c; YJ87</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Yeast</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>YJ87 of <em>Schizosaccharomyces pombe </em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.6"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.6&tcname=">2.A.1.2.6</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>(Benomyl, cycloheximide, methotrexate, fluconazole, etc.):H<sup>+</sup> antiporter, CaMDR1 (<span id="ref6983.20348384" class="cite">Basso <em>et al.</em>, 2010</span>; <span id="ref7178.9580031" class="cite">Cannon <em>et al.</em>, 1998</span>). MDR1 catalyzes efflux of commonly used azoles. The central cytoplasmic loop is critical for MDR function, but does not impart substrate specificity (<span id="ref8697.22587419" class="cite">Mandal <em>et al.</em>, 2012</span>). The structural basis for polyspecificity of MDR MFS transporters, based on studies with Mdr1, is the extended capacity brought by residues located at the periphery of a binding core to accomodate compounds differing in size and type (<span id="ref34549645.29341887" class="cite">Redhu <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). Each domain in the protein is arranged in a pseudo-symmetric fold of two tandems of 3-TMSs that alternatly expose the drug-binding site towards the inside or the outside of the yeast to promote drug binding and release. <span id="ref34554851.35628792" class="cite">Sharma <em>et al.</em> 2022</span> provided information on these motifs by having screened a library of 64 drug transport-deficient mutants and their corresponding suppressors spontaneously addressing the deficiency. They found that five strains recovered the drug-resistance capacity by expressing CaMdr1 with a secondary mutation. The pairs of debilitating/rescuing residues are distributed either in the same TMS or 3-TMS repeat, at the hinge of 3-TMS repeat tandems, and between the N- and C-domains. Most of these mutants belong to different signature motifs, highlighting a mechanistic role and interplay thought to be conserved among MFS proteins. Results point to the specific role of TMS 11 in the interplay between the N- and C-domains in the inward- to outward-open conformational transition (<span id="ref34554851.35628792" class="cite">Sharma <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Yeast</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>CaMDR1 of <em>Candida albicans</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.60"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.60&tcname=">2.A.1.2.60</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>YajR of 454 aas and 12 TMSs.&nbsp; The 3-D structure in the outward-facing conformation is available at 3.15&Aring; resolution, and the cytoplasmic C-terminal YAM domain has been solved to 1.07&Aring; resolution.&nbsp; This 65 aa YAM domain is thought to control the conformational states of the protein (<span id="ref10549.23950222" class="cite">Jiang <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>; <span id="ref11270.24952155" class="cite">Jiang <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>YajR of <em>E. coli</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.61"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.61&tcname=">2.A.1.2.61</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SPX domain-containing membrane protein At1g63010, called <span class="highlight">Vacuolar</span> <span class="highlight">Phosphate Transporter</span> 1 (VPT1), It transports phosphate &gt; sulphate &gt; nitrate &gt; chloride and malate.&nbsp; The <em>vpt1</em> mutant plants were stunted and consistently 
retained less Pi than wild type plants, especially when grown in medium 
containing high levels of Pi. In seedlings, VPT1 was expressed primarily
 in younger tissues under normal conditions, but was strongly induced by
 high-Pi conditions in older tissues, suggesting that VPT1 functions in 
Pi storage in young tissues and in detoxification of high Pi in older 
tissues. As a result, disruption of VPT1 rendered plants hypersensitive 
to both low-Pi and high-Pi conditions, reducing the adaptability of 
plants to changing Pi availability (<span id="ref34547243.26554016" class="cite">Liu <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Plants</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>VPT1 or At1g63010 of <em>Arabidopsis thaliana</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.62"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.62&tcname=">2.A.1.2.62</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p>Putative MDR pump, YdhC or PunC.&nbsp; It has been reporte to export arabinose but not xylose (<span id="ref11179.22952739" class="cite">Koita and Rao 2012</span>). However, it also takes up adenosine, adenine, deoxyadenosine, and other purine nucleosides and nucleobases such as inosine and guanosine as sole nitrogen sources. It also takes up various sulfonamides such as sulfathiazole, sulfadiazine and sulfamethoxazole.&nbsp; Expression of the <em>punC</em> gene is reglulated by the positive transcription factor, PunR (YdhB) (<span id="ref34553872.34413462" class="cite">Rodionova <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PunC (YdhC) of <em>Escherichia coli </em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.63"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.63&tcname=">2.A.1.2.63</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Probable drug/proton antiporter YHK8</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Fungi</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>YHK8 of <em>Saccharomyces cerevisiae  </em></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.64"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.64&tcname=">2.A.1.2.64</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Polyamine exporter 4 (<span id="ref10637.20159658" class="cite">Igarashi and Kashiwagi 2010).</span></p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Fungi</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>TPO4 of <em>Saccharomyces cerevisiae </em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.65"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.65&tcname=">2.A.1.2.65</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p><!-- test--><p>
																												                                         																																																								                                     
																																																																	                                     Inner membrane transport protein YdhP</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>YdhP of <em>Escherichia coli </em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.66"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.66&tcname=">2.A.1.2.66</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Polyamine exporter 3 (<span id="ref10637.20159658" class="cite">Igarashi and Kashiwagi 2010</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Fungi</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>TPO3 of <em>Saccharomyces cerevisiae </em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.67"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.67&tcname=">2.A.1.2.67</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Polyamine exporter 2 (<span id="ref10637.20159658" class="cite">Igarashi and Kashiwagi 2010</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Fungi</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>TPO2 of <em>Saccharomyces cerevisiae </em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.68"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.68&tcname=">2.A.1.2.68</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Tetracycline resistance protein, class B (TetA(B)) (Metal-tetracycline/H<sup>+</sup> antiporter).&nbsp; Mutants defective in either transport or tetracycline binding have been isolated (<span id="ref34544217.26143388" class="cite">Wright and Tate 2015</span>). Several amino acid substitutions (i.e., D190C, E192C and S201C) alter the specificity of the porter so that it prefers deoxycycline (3x) and minochcline (6x) over tetracycline (<span id="ref34550236.16000721" class="cite">Sapunaric and Levy 2005</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>TetA of <em>Escherichia coli</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.69"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.69&tcname=">2.A.1.2.69</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p><!-- test--><p>

It is a tetracycline exporter-like protein.&nbsp; This protein is found in the inner nuclear membrane (<span id="ref34549977.31142202" class="cite">Cheng <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>) and is a disease protein in humans (<span id="ref34550739.31906755" class="cite">Bagchi <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). Its gene shows increased expression with increased energy consumption (<span id="ref34550739.31906755" class="cite">Bagchi <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). It may <span>confers cellular resistance to apoptosis induced by the non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, indomethacin and diclofenac. </span><span style="font-weight: normal;">A microdeletion proximal to the <em>mfsD10</em> gene is associated with mild Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome (<span id="ref34555029.22438245" class="cite">Hannes <em>et al.</em> 2012</span>).<br /></span></p>

<p><a id="2.A.1.2.77"></a></p>
<p>CefT confers phenylacetate resistance (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref9282">Fern&aacute;ndez-Aguado <em>et al.</em> 2012</a>).&nbsp; It has been reported to be a hydrophilic beta-lactam transporter that is involved in
 the secretion of hydrophilic beta-lactams containing an &alpha;-aminoadipic 
acid side chain (isopenicillin N, penicillin N and deacetylcephalosporin
 C) (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref9283">Cesareo <em>et al.</em> 2007</a>; <a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref9284">Ull&aacute;n <em>et al.</em> 2002</a>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Fungi</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>CefT of <em>Acremonium chrysogenum</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.78"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.78&tcname=">2.A.1.2.78</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p>

<p><a id="2.A.1.2.78"></a></p>
<p>The PaaT (PenT) exporter.&nbsp; <span class="highlight">PaaT</span> is 
involved in penicillin production, possibly through the translocation
 of side-chain precursors (phenylacetate and phenoxyacetate) 
from the cytosol to the peroxisomal lumen across the peroxisomal 
membrane of <em>P. <span class="highlight">chrysogenum.&nbsp; </span></em><span class="highlight">It has a Pex19 (peroxisome biogenesis factor 19) binding sequence (residues 258 - 269) accounting for its peroxysomal location</span> (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref9282">Fern&aacute;ndez-Aguado <em>et al.</em> 2012; encoded by a gene adjacent to one encoding a peroxiredoxin (an electron donor and antioxidant; <span id="ref10128.23397885" class="cite">Hanschmann <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><em>Deinococcus/Thermus</em></p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>UP of <em>Deinococcus peraridilitoris</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.82"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.82&tcname=">2.A.1.2.82</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Uncharacterized MFS permease of 402 aas and 12 TMSs</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Spirochaetes</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>UP of <em>Leptospira interrogans</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.83"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.83&tcname=">2.A.1.2.83</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MmrA MFS protein. Homologous to drug exporter. RppA and MmrA are involved in amino acid uptake and efflux of antimicrobial agents including streptomycin, ethidium bromide and norfloxacin (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref10347">Kimura <em>et al.</em> 2004</a>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MXAN_5906 of <em>Myxococcus xanthus</em>.  </p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.84"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.84&tcname=">2.A.1.2.84</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Probable siderophore-specific exporter of 407 aas and 12 TMSs, MxcK.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MxcK of <em>Stigmatella aurantiaca</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.85"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.85&tcname=">2.A.1.2.85</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Peroxysomal phenylacetate/phenoxyacetate transporter, PaaT (CefT) of 564 aas (<span id="ref9282.23053082" class="cite">Fern&aacute;ndez-Aguado <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Fungi</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PaaT of <em>Penicillium chrysogenum (Penicillium notatum)</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.86"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.86&tcname=">2.A.1.2.86</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Peroxisomal isopenicillin N importer, PenM (<span id="ref10709.15719554" class="cite">Evers <em>et al.</em> 2004</span>; <span id="ref10710.24480587" class="cite">Fern&aacute;ndez-Aguado <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Fungi</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PenM of <em>Penicillium chrysogenum (Penicillium notatum)</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.87"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.87&tcname=">2.A.1.2.87</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Purine efflux porter of 392 aas, CepA.&nbsp; 2-aminopurine and purine nucleoside analogues. May show increased resistance to the antibiotics nalidixic acid and 
ampicillin (<span id="ref34545974.24535744" class="cite">Sim <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Actinobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>CepA of <em>Corynebacterium glutamicum</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.88"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.88&tcname=">2.A.1.2.88</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS porter of 442 aas</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Euryarchaea</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS porter of <em>Pyrococcus furiosus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.89"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.89&tcname=">2.A.1.2.89</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS porter of 454 aas</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Actinobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS porter of <em>Streptomyces coelicolor</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.9"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.9&tcname=">2.A.1.2.9</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>(Hydrophobic uncoupler e.g., CCCP, benzalkonium, SDS and other drugs):H<sup>+</sup> antiporter, EmrD (<span id="ref1912.11566977" class="cite">Nishino and Yamaguchi 2001</span>). The 3-d structure (3.5 &Aring; resolution) has been determined (<span id="ref8760.16675700" class="cite">Yin <em>et al.</em>, 2006)</span>.&nbsp; conformational dynamics studies have revealed details of the transport pathway and some motions of <span class="highlight">EmrD</span> at an atomic level (<span id="ref11181.22434745" class="cite">Baker <em>et al.</em> 2012</span>).&nbsp; Probably exports arabinose but not xylose (<span id="ref11179.22952739" class="cite">Koita and Rao 2012</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Gram-negative bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>EmrD of <em>E. coli</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.90"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.90&tcname=">2.A.1.2.90</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>UMF4F of 405 aas and 12 TMSs</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Firmicutes</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>UMF4F of <em>Aectobacterium woodii</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.91"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.91&tcname=">2.A.1.2.91</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS permease of 554 aas and 12 TMSs</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Fungi</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative MFS carrier of <em>Metarhizium robertsii (Metarhizium anisopliae)</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.92"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.92&tcname=">2.A.1.2.92</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The CefM
protein of 482 aas and 12 TMSs. Probably involved in the translocation of penicillin N from the lumen of peroxisomes (or
peroxisome-like microbodies) to the cytosol, where it is converted into cephalosporin C (<span id="ref34544425.18840096" class="cite">Teijeira <em>et al.</em> 2009</span>).&nbsp; A null mutant
accumulates&nbsp; penicillin N, is unable to synthesize deacetoxy- and deacetyl-cephalosporin C as well as cephalosporin C, and shows impaired differentiation into arthrospores (<span id="ref34544425.18840096" class="cite">Teijeira <em>et al.</em> 2009</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>CefM of <em>Acremonium chrysogenum (Cephalosporium acremonium)</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.93"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.93&tcname=">2.A.1.2.93</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Uncharacterized MFS permease of 433 aas and 12 TMSs</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>UP of <em>Lactobacillus buchneri </em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.94"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.94&tcname=">2.A.1.2.94</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Uncharacterized MFS permease of 445 aas and 12 TMSs</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>UP of <em>Microbacterium maritypicum </em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.95"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.95&tcname=">2.A.1.2.95</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Blt of 422 aas and 12 TMSs.&nbsp; Exports antibiotics such as fluoroquinolones and chloramphenicol (<span id="ref3180.16237035" class="cite">Vardy <em>et al.</em> 2005</span>)</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Blt of <em>Mycobacterium smegmatis</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.96"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.96&tcname=">2.A.1.2.96</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ZIF2 (Zinc-Induced Facilitator 2) of 484 aas and 12 TMSs localises primarily at the tonoplast of root cortical cells and is a functional <span class="highlight">transporter</span> able to mediate Zn efflux from the cytoplasm (<span id="ref34544891.24832541" class="cite">Remy <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>).&nbsp; Activity is controlled by alternative RNA splicing.&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ZIF2 of <em>Arabidopsis thaliana</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.97"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.97&tcname=">2.A.1.2.97</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bcr/CflA family drug exporter, MSMEG_2991 of 428 aas and 12 TMSs. A pmf-dependent <span class="highlight">multidrug</span> efflux pump that expels diverse groups of antibiotics including ciprofloxacin. May also be involved in biofilm enhancement (<span id="ref34545291.27190152" class="cite">Bansal <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bcr-like exporter of <em>Mycobacterium smegmatis</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.98"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.98&tcname=">2.A.1.2.98</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Uncharacterized MFS transporter of 427 aas and 12 TMSs.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>UP of <em>Aeropyrum camini</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.2.99"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.2.99&tcname=">2.A.1.2.99</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative siderophore exporter, SbnD of 418 aas and 12 TMSs (<span id="ref34546447.28197063" class="cite">Marklevitz and Harris 2016</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SbnD of <em>Staphylococcus aureus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=2.A.1.20">2.A.1.20 The Sugar Efflux Transporter (SET) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.20.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.20.1&tcname=">2.A.1.20.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Sugar efflux transporter A, SetA.&nbsp; Exports lactose, glucose, aromatic glucosides and galactosides, cellobiose, maltose, &alpha;-methylglucoside and isopropyl &beta;-thiogalactosides (IPTG); amino-glycosides, streptomycin and kanamycin are weakly expelled (<span id="ref735.10438463" class="cite">Liu <em>et al.</em> 1999</span>).&nbsp; Regulated by SgrR (a transcriptional regulator of <em>sgrS</em>) and SgrS (a small RNA that represses trascription of <em>setA</em>).&nbsp; These two regulatory genes are upstream of the <em>setA</em> gene.&nbsp; Uses a <em>pmf</em>-dependent mechanism of energization.&nbsp; Induced in response to glucose-phosphate stress which occurs when a sugar phosphates accumulate in the cytoplam (<span id="ref11178.20971900" class="cite">Sun and Vanderpool 2011</span>). Overexpression of the gene for SetA allows export of Lacto-<em>N</em>-triose (LNT II) and lacto-<em>N</em>-tetraose (LNT), human milk oligosaccharides (<span id="ref34555050.35426313" class="cite">Sugita and Koketsu 2022</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SetA (YabM) of <em>E. coli</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.20.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.20.2&tcname=">2.A.1.20.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Sugar efflux system, SetB, for lactose and glucose, but not IPTG or galactose (<span id="ref735.10438463" class="cite">Liu <em>et al.</em> 1999</span>). Overexpression of the gene for SetB allows export of Lacto-<em>N</em>-triose (LNT II) and lacto-<em>N</em>-tetraose (LNT), human milk oligosaccharides (<a class="reflink" href="../../search/result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref34555050">Sugita and Koketsu 2022</a>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SetB (YeiO) of <em>E. coli</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.20.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.20.3&tcname=">2.A.1.20.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Arabinose (but not xylose) exporter, SetC (<span id="ref11179.22952739" class="cite">Koita and Rao 2012</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SetC (YicK) of <em>E. coli</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.20.4"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.20.4&tcname=">2.A.1.20.4</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Efflux system for arabinose and IPTG (>>lactose), SotA  </TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>SotA of <i>Erwinia chrysanthemi</i> </TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=2.A.1.21">2.A.1.21 The Drug:H<sup>+</sup> Antiporter-3 (12 Spanner) (DHA3) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.21.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.21.1&tcname=">2.A.1.21.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The macrolide (erythromycin; oleandomycin; azithromycin; telithromycin) efflux pump, MefA, of 405 aas and 12 TMSs (<span id="ref34547420.15705635" class="cite">Cant&oacute;n <em>et al.</em> 2005</span>; <span id="ref34547419.21419605" class="cite">Bley <em>et al.</em> 2011</span>). <span id="ref34548737.30108557" class="cite">Iannelli <em>et al.</em> 2018</span> suggested that MefA can function with an ATPase, MsrD (TC# 3.A.1.121.6), and therefore function as an ABC drug exporter.&nbsp; However, the data presented seem inconsistent with this suggestion. The two genes encoding these two proteins are adjacent to each other, suggesting that they may function together (<span id="ref34548737.30108557" class="cite">Iannelli <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). Predicted transmembrane proteins with homology to MefA do not complement a <em>mefA </em>deletion in the MefA-MsrD macrolide efflux system in <em>Streptococcus pneumoniae</em> (<span id="ref34554183.34823574" class="cite">Fox <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>). Note: MsrD is an ATPase of the ABC superfamily, so it can not be certain that MefA and MsrD function together. Coupling of an MFS carrier with an ABC-type energizer is very rare, maybe non-existent.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MefA of <em>Streptococcus pyogenes</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.21.10"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.21.10&tcname=">2.A.1.21.10</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS porter</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Archaea</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS porter of <em>Sulfolobus islandicus</em> (D2PCQ8)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.21.11"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.21.11&tcname=">2.A.1.21.11</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS porter</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS porter of <em>Stackebrandtia nassauensis</em> (D3Q871)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.21.12"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.21.12&tcname=">2.A.1.21.12</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Multidrug-efflux transporter, Rv1258c/MT1297, of 419 aas and 12 TMSs. Both Rv1634 and Rv1258c are believed to play major roles in drug 
resistance by altering the protein pump that is required to remove the 
active drugs from the bacterial cell (<a class="reflink" href="http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref34549719">Panja <em>et al.</em> 2019</a>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Rv1258c of <em>Mycobacterium tuberculosis</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.21.13"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.21.13&tcname=">2.A.1.21.13</a></TD><TD><b><font valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.21.14"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.21.14&tcname=">2.A.1.21.14</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Uncharacterized MFS-type transporter Mb0038c</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Actinobacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Mb0038c of <em>Mycobacterium bovis </em></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.21.15"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.21.15&tcname=">2.A.1.21.15</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS Homologue</p></TD><TD><b><font valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.21.16"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.21.16&tcname=">2.A.1.21.16</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS Homologue</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Actinobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS homologue of <em>Streptomyces coelicolor </em>(Q9X8T4)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" This protein localizes to neurotransmitter-containing vesicles and has a nucleotide binding site (<span id="ref34543960.19390693" class="cite">Yao and Bajjalieh 2009</span>). The SV2 family is comprised of three 
paralogues: SV2A, SV2B, and SV2C. They are present in secretory vesicles, including 
synaptic vesicles, and are critical to neurotransmission. Structural and
 functional studies suggest that SV2 proteins may play several roles to 
promote proper vesicular function. Among these roles are their potential
 to stabilize the transmitter content of vesicles, to maintain and 
orient the releasable pool of vesicles, and to regulate vesicular 
calcium sensitivity to ensure efficient, coordinated release of the 
transmitter (<span id="ref34551547.31394034" class="cite">Stout <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>). SV2A plays a role in neuronal excitability and as
 such is the specific target for the antiepileptic drug levetiracetam as well as seletracetam and brivaracetam. 
SV2 proteins also act as the target by which potent neurotoxins, 
particularly botulinum, gain access to neurons and exert their toxicity.
 Both SV2B and SV2C are increasingly implicated in diseases such as 
Alzheimer's disease and Parkinson's disease. Despite 
decades of intensive research, their exact functions were elusive in 2019 (<span id="ref34551547.31394034" class="cite">Stout <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>), but the systems may transport galactose.The human (Q70J3) and rat orthologs are 99% identical. The structure, function, and disease relevance of GP2 (SV2) transporters have been reviewed (<span id="ref34551547.31394034" class="cite">Stout <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>).&nbsp; More than one percent of people have epilepsy worldwide. Levetiracetam 
(LEV) is a successful new-generation antiepileptic drug (AED), and its 
derivative, brivaracetam (BRV), shows improved efficacy. Synaptic 
vesicle glycoprotein 2a (SV2A), a membrane transporter in the 
synaptic vesicles (SVs), has been identified as a target of LEV and BRV.
 SV2A also serves as a receptor for botulinum neurotoxin (BoNT) (<span id="ref34557916.38637505" class="cite">Yamagata <em>et al.</em> 2024</span>).&nbsp; The structural basis for antiepileptic drugs and botulinum neurotoxin recognition of SV2A have been ellucidated (<span id="ref34557916.38637505" class="cite">Yamagata <em>et al.</em> 2024</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SV2 of <em>Rattus norvegicus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.22.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.22.2&tcname=">2.A.1.22.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Synaptic vesicle glycoprotein 2B of 556 aas</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Glycoprotein 2B of <em>Tribolium castaneum</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.22.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.22.3&tcname=">2.A.1.22.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>AgaP of 537 aas</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals (Insects)</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>AgaP of <em>Anopheles gambiae</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.22.4"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.22.4&tcname=">2.A.1.22.4</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Uncharacterized protein of 537 aas</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>UP of <em>Acyrthosiphon pisum</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.22.5"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.22.5&tcname=">2.A.1.22.5</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Uncharacterized protein of 561 aas</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>UP of <em>Trichoplax adhaerens (Trichoplax reptans)</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.22.6"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.22.6&tcname=">2.A.1.22.6</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Synaptic vesicle 2C, SV2C or SLC22B3, of 727 aas and 11 TMSs. Botulinum neurotoxins (BoNTs) inhibit neurotransmitter release by selectively cleaving core components of the vesicular fusion machinery. The synaptic vesicle proteins Synaptotagmin-I and -II act as receptors for BoNT/B and BoNT/G. <span>Mahrhold <em>et al.</em> 2006</span> showed that BoNT/A also interacts with a synaptic vesicle protein, the synaptic vesicle glycoprotein 2C (SV2C), but not with the homologous proteins SV2A and SV2B. Binding of BoNT/A occurs at the membrane juxtaposed region preceding transmembrane domain 8. A peptide comprising the intravesicular domain between transmembrane domains 7 and 8 specifically reduces the neurotoxicity of BoNT/A at phrenic nerve preparations, demonstrating the physiological relevance of this interaction (<span>Mahrhold <em>et al.</em> 2006</span>). The interactions of SV2C with BoNT have been reviewed (<span id="ref34551550.31783045" class="cite">Li <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). SV2C is implicated in diseases such as Alzheimer's disease and Parkinson's disease (<span id="ref34551547.31394034" class="cite">Stout <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>). It seems to play roles in vesicle trafficking, exocytosis and neurotransmission (<span id="ref34551551.28774501" class="cite">Hu <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SV2C of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.22.7"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.22.7&tcname=">2.A.1.22.7</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Synaptic vesicle glycoprotein 2B, SV2B or SLC22B2, of 683 aas and 12 TMSs in a 6 +&nbsp; 1 + 5 TMS arrangement.&nbsp; SV2B, ephrin B1 and the receptors of angiotensin II are expressed in 
the podocyte, and their expressions were altered in 
anti-nephrin antibody-induced nephropathy. These proteins may be involved in the development of proteinuria (<span id="ref34551548.19662599" class="cite">Kawachi <em>et al.</em> 2009</span>). SV2B and SV2C may be involved in the pathogenesis of epilepsy as well as other neurodegenerative diseases (<span id="ref34551549.27752944" class="cite">L&ouml;scher <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>) such as Alzheimer's disease and Parkinson's disease (<span id="ref34551547.31394034" class="cite">Stout <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>). Defective lysosomal acidification may provide a prognostic marker and therapeutic target for neurodegenerative diseases (<span id="ref34556578.37287072" class="cite">Lo and Zeng 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SV2B of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=2.A.1.23">2.A.1.23 The Conjugated Bile Salt Transporter (BST) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.23.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.23.1&tcname=">2.A.1.23.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Conjugated bile salt:H<sup>+</sup> symporter, CbsT1 of 452 aas and 12 TMSs. id="ref34552342.11739773" class="cite">Elkins <em>et al.</em> 2001</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>CbsT1 of <em>Lactobacillus color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>UP of <em>Entamoeba histolytica</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=2.A.1.25">2.A.1.25 The Peptide/Acetyl-Coenzyme A/Drug Transporter (PAT) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.25.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.25.1&tcname=">2.A.1.25.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The endoplasmic reticular/Golgi acetyl-CoA:CoA antiporter 1, ACATN/ACATN1 (SLC33A1).&nbsp; Allows acetylation of sialic acid residues in gangliosides and lysine residues in membrane proteins.&nbsp; It is associated with neurodegenerative disorders such as sporadic amyotrophic laterial sclerosis (ALS) and Spastic Paraplegia 42, and it is essential for motor neuron viability (<span id="ref9820.23506891" class="cite">Hirabayashi <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>). Abnormal concentrations of acetylated amino acids in cerebrospinal fluid are observed in acetyl-CoA transporter deficiency (<span id="ref34555256.35999711" class="cite">&Scaron;ikić <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SLC33A1 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.25.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.25.2&tcname=">2.A.1.25.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Cell wall degradation product (peptides and glycopeptides including N-acetylglucosaminyl &beta;-1,4-anhydro-N-acetyl-muramyl-tri or tetra-peptide) as well as penicillin derivative uptake porter, AmpG (<span id="ref34543695.12426329" class="cite">Cheng and Park 2002</span>). The AmpG permease is also required for AmpC beta-lactamase induction (<span id="ref34550350.15728916" class="cite">Chahboune <em>et al.</em> 2005</span>; <span id="ref34550351.18535144" class="cite">Park and Uehara 2008</span>). <span class="highlight">AmpG</span> mediates a dynamic relationship between serine beta-lactamase induction and biofilm-formation (<span id="ref34550352.29566229" class="cite">Mallik <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>AmpG of <em>E. coli</em> (P0AE16)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.25.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.25.3&tcname=">2.A.1.25.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The AmpG peptidoglycan degradation product uptake porter is part of the peptidoglycan recycling pathway (<span id="ref5129.18390650" class="cite">Garcia and Dillard, 2008</span>). It also plays a role in peptidoglycan remodeling, recycling, and toxic fragment release as well as pathogenesis (<span id="ref34550353.30766523" class="cite">Schaub and Dillard 2019</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>AmpG of <em>Neisseria gonorrhoeae</em> (Q5F6G0)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.25.4"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.25.4&tcname=">2.A.1.25.4</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative peptide/acetyl-CoA transporter of 560 aas and 12 TMSs.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Uncharacterized protein of <em>Saccharomyces cerevisiae </em>(Baker's yeast)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.25.5"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.25.5&tcname=">2.A.1.25.5</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p><a id="2.A.1.25.5"></a></p>
<p><a></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p><a id="2.A.1.25.5"></a></p>
<p>Transporter of meuropeptides, N-acetylglucosamine anhydrous N-acetylmuramyl peptides, AmpG (<span id="ref8919.21192796" class="cite">Kong <em>et al.</em> 2010</span>).&nbsp; Necessary for induction of ampC, &beta;-lactamase, and ampicillin resistance (<span id="ref9157.20713660" class="cite">Zhang <em>et al.</em> 2010</span>). Amino acyl residues essential for proper mRNA production and for catalytic activity have been identified (<span id="ref34546986.27959942" class="cite">Li <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>AmpG of <em>Pseudomonas aeruginosa </em><span id="ref8919.21192796" class="cite"><br /></span></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.25.6"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.25.6&tcname=">2.A.1.25.6</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Uptake transporter, AmpG, of 433 aas and 12 TMSs, specific for muropeptides, fragments of the peptidoglycan cell walls of bacteria (<span id="ref34550540.28446907" class="cite">Ruscitto <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>AmpG of <em><span class="highlight">Tannerella forsythia</span></em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.25.7"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.25.7&tcname=">2.A.1.25.7</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative acetyl-CoA:CoA antiporter, ACT or AT1, of 590 aas and 12 or 13 TMSs in a 6 or 7 + 6 TMS arrangement (<span id="ref34555299.35811673" class="cite">Wunderlich 2022</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ACT lf <em>Plasmodium falciparum</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=2.A.1.26">2.A.1.26 The Drug:H+ Antiporter-4 (DHA4) Family Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD color=#3333CC><p>Multidrug resistance efflux porter, BC3310 of 396 aas and 12 TMSs.&nbsp; Exports ethidium bromide, sodium dodecyl sulfate and silver nitrate.&nbsp; D105 in TMS4 is essential for activity (<span id="ref34544694.26528249" class="cite">Kroeger <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>BC3310 of <em>Bacillus cereus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=2.A.1.27">2.A.1.27 The Phenyl Propionate Permease (PPP) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.27.1"></A><A
