al.</em> 1998</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>HcaT (YfhS) of <em>E. coli</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.27.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.27.2&tcname=">2.A.1.27.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS permease of 406 aas and 12 TMSs.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS porter of <em>Methylobacterium nodulans</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.27.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.27.3&tcname=">2.A.1.27.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative metabolite transporter of 393 aas and 12 TMSs.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Porter of <em>Sulfurimonas denitrificans (Thiomicrospira denitrificans</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=2.A.1.28">2.A.1.28 The Feline Leukemia Virus Subgroup C Receptor (FLVCR)/Heme Importer Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.28.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.28.1&tcname=">2.A.1.28.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Cell surface receptor (C-receptor) for anemia-inducing feline leukemia virus subgroup C (FLCVR, Slc49A1 or Mfsd7d) of 555 aas and 12 TMSs. It may function in choline transport (<span id="ref34556339.37100056" class="cite">Kenny <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>) or haem export in haemopoietic cells (<span id="ref4358.16487711" class="cite">Latunde-Dada <em>et al</em>., 2006</span>;&nbsp;<span id="ref7761.21238504" class="cite">Khan and Quigley, 2011</span>) and may cause Diamond-Blackfan anemia when defective (<span id="ref4841.18258918" class="cite">Keel <em>et al</em>., 2008</span>). Mutations of FLVCR1 in posterior column ataxia and retinitis pigmentosa result in the loss of heme export activity (<span id="ref8556.22483575" class="cite">Yanatori <em>et al.</em>, 2012</span>). Heme accumulation causes toxicity (<span id="ref34551312.23506900" class="cite">Khan and Quigley 2018</span>).&nbsp; FLVCR1 is co-induced upon iron insufficiency in the placenta with the LDL receptor-related protein 1 (LRP1) heme receptor, and these two proteins may be important for neonatal iron status (<span id="ref11284.24947444" class="cite">Cao <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>).&nbsp; FLVCR1 is required for erythroid and &alpha;&beta;-, CD4 and CD8 T- cell development (<span id="ref34543715.25582857" class="cite">Philip <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>). A splice-site variant of FLVCR1 produces retinitis pigmentosa without posterior column ataxia (<span id="ref34549630.29192808" class="cite">Yusuf <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). Protocols suitable for purification of FLVCR1a, antibody generation and structural characterization of the transporter have been reported (<span id="ref34551292.32278001" class="cite">Chiabrando <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). FLVCR1-related disease is a rare cause of retinitis pigmentosa and hereditary sensory autonomic neuropathy (<span id="ref34553108.32822874" class="cite">Grudzinska Pechhacker <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). More recently, integrative genetic analyses identified FLVCR1 as a plasma-membrane choline transporter in mammals (<span id="ref34556339.37100056" class="cite">Kenny <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>C-receptor of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.28.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.28.2&tcname=">2.A.1.28.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The MFS-Domain7 protein of 516 aas and 12 TMSs. The MFS-D7 mRNA is expressed in many human tissues, especially in lungs and testis, but its transport substrate is not known (<span id="ref34551312.23506900" class="cite">Khan and Quigley 2018</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFSD7 of <em>Mus musculus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.28.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.28.3&tcname=">2.A.1.28.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Unknown major facilitator of 407 aas and 12 TMSs.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>UMF of <em>Coriobacterium glomerans</em> (F2NBU7)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.28.4"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.28.4&tcname=">2.A.1.28.4</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The Fowler syndrome-associated protein, feline leukemia virus subgroup C receptor-related protein 2, FLVCR2, or SLC49A2, is probably a heme importer (<span id="ref7682.20823265" class="cite">Duffy <em>et al.</em>, 2010</span>). Mutations of SLC49A2&nbsp; are observed in Fowler syndrome, a rare proliferative vascular disorder of the brain (<span id="ref34551312.23506900" class="cite">Khan and Quigley 2018</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>FLVCR2 of <em>Homo sapiens </em>(Q9UPI3)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.28.5"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.28.5&tcname=">2.A.1.28.5</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS porter of 401 aas and 12 TMSs.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS porter of <em>Leptospira biflexa</em> (B0SL69)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.28.6"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.28.6&tcname=">2.A.1.28.6</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Electrogenic DIRC2 (Disrupted in renal carcinoma 2) or SLC49A4.&nbsp; It is glycosylated and proteolytically processed (<span id="ref8418.21692750" class="cite">Savalas <em>et al.</em>, 2011</span>)) and is targeted to lysosomes via an N-terminal dileueine motif. It is implicated in hereditary renal carcinomas (<span id="ref34551312.23506900" class="cite">Khan and Quigley 2018</span>). DIRC2 is an electrogenic lysosomal metabolite transporter which is 
subjected to and presumably modulated by limited proteolytic processing (<span id="ref8418.21692750" class="cite">Savalas <em>et al.</em> 2011</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>DIRC2 of <em>Homo sapiens</em>&nbsp;(Q96SL1)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.28.7"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.28.7&tcname=">2.A.1.28.7</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Feline leukemia virus subgroup C receptor-related protein 1</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>FLVCR1 of <em>Felis catus  </em></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.28.8"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.28.8&tcname=">2.A.1.28.8</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFSD7, FLVCR2 or SLC49A3 of 560 aas and 12 TMSs. It is the feline leukemia virus subgroup C receptor-2 (FLVCR2), a member of the 
SLC49 family of four paralogous genes in humans (<span id="ref34551312.23506900" class="cite">Khan and Quigley 2018</span>). It is a cell surface heme transporter, 
essential for erythropoiesis and systemic iron homeostasis. Mutations of SLC49A2, encoding FLVCR1, are noted in patients with Fowler syndrome (<span id="ref34551312.23506900" class="cite">Khan and Quigley 2018</span>). FLVCR2 is 30% identical to FLVCR1 (TC# 2.A.1.28.1).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>FLCR2 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=2.A.1.29">2.A.1.29 The Potential Heme Import (HemeI) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.29.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.29.1&tcname=">2.A.1.29.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Archaeal open reading frame  </TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Archaea</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Orf of <i>Archaeoglobus fulgidus</i> </TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.29.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.29.2&tcname=">2.A.1.29.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Archaeal open reading frame  </TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Archaea</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Orf of <i>Aeropyrum pernix</i> </TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.29.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.29.3&tcname=">2.A.1.29.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacterial unknown major facilitator</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>UMF3 member of <em>Frankia </em>sp. Eul1c (E3J3E7)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=2.A.1.3">2.A.1.3 The Drug:H<sup>+</sup> Antiporter-2 (14 Spanner) (DHA2) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.1&tcname=">2.A.1.3.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The main boron exporter in yeast, Atr1 (<span id="ref6501.19414602" class="cite">Kaya <em>et al.</em> 2009</span>) (Aminotriazole, 4-nitroquinoline-N-oxide, etc.):H<sup>+</sup> antiporter. Also exports L-cysteine (<span id="ref7182.16820466" class="cite">Yamada <em>et al.</em>, 2006</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Yeast</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Atr1 of <em>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.10"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.10&tcname=">2.A.1.3.10</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Methylenomycin:H<sup>+</sup> antiporter</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Gram-positive bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>MmrB of <I>Bacillus subtilis</i> </TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A color=#3333CC><p>The Tet38 tetracycline-resistance protein of 450 aas and 14&nbsp; TMSs of <em>S. aureus</em> (<span id="ref2996.15774883" class="cite">Truong-Bolduc <em>et al</em>., 2005</span>). Tet38 has distinct functions, including drug efflux and host cell attachment and internalization mediated by interaction with host cell CD36. <span id="ref34553968.33619028" class="cite">Truong-Bolduc <em>et al.</em> 2021 </span>identified key amino acids involved in different functions. Cysteine substitutions of arginine 106, situated at the junction of TMS 4 and external loop L2, and glycine 151 of motif C on TMS 5, resulted in 8- to 16-fold reductions in Tet38-mediated resistance to tetracycline, with minimal effect on A549 host cell internalization. In contrast, two three-amino-acid deletions, F411P412G413, in external loop L7, situated between TMSs 13 and 14, and D38D39L40, in external loop L1, situated between TMS 1 and 2, led to decreased tetracycline resistance, but only the former affected <em>S. aureus</em> internalization and impaired binding to CD36 (<span id="ref34553968.33619028" class="cite">Truong-Bolduc <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Tet38 of <em>Staphylococcus aureus</em> (AAV80464)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.23"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.23&tcname=">2.A.1.3.23</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>The NorB multidrug resistance pump (exports hydrophilic quinolones, ethidium bromide, cetrimide, sparfloxacin, moxifloxacin and tetracycline) (<span id="ref2996.15774883" class="cite">Truong-Bolduc <em>et al</em>., 2005</span>)</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>NorB of <i>Staphylococcus aureus</i>  (BAB42529)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.24"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.24&tcname=">2.A.1.3.24</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The VceAB multidrug (hydrophobic compounds including deoxycholate (DOC), antibiotics, such as chloramphenicol and nalidixic acid, and the proton motive force uncoupler, cyanide carbonyl m-chlorophenylhydrazone (CCCP)) resistance pump (functions with outer membrane VceC (TC#1.B.17.3.6) or OprM (2.A.6.2.21), an OMF family member; The C-terminal domain of the <em>Pseudomonas aeruginosa</em> OprM and the

CCCP and valinomycin inhibited drug resistance (<span id="ref6631.19564371" class="cite">Ram&oacute;n-Garc&iacute;a <em>et al.</em>, 2009</span>).&nbsp; P55 also exports malachite green, ethidium bromide, isoniazid and ethambutol (<span id="ref9336.21762531" class="cite">Bianco <em>et al.</em> 2011</span>).&nbsp; It functions together with the outer membrane lipoprotein porin, LprG (P9WK45; TC# 9.B.138.1.1), also called P27 and Lpp-27 (<span id="ref9336.21762531" class="cite">Bianco <em>et al.</em> 2011; <span id="ref4760.18156250" class="cite">Farrow and Rubin 2008</span></span>).&nbsp; MFS55 is required together with LprG for normal colony morphology and sliding motility, possibly due to alterred cell wall composition (<span id="ref4760.18156250" class="cite">Farrow and Rubin 2008</span>). MFS transporter Rv1410 and the periplasmic lipoprotein, LprG, transport triacylglycerides (TAGs) that seal the mycomembrane.&nbsp;<span id="ref34557479.37833269" class="cite">Remm <em>et al.</em> 2023 </span>reported a 2.7&nbsp;&Aring; structure of a mycobacterial Rv1410 homologue, which adopts an outward-facing conformation and exhibits unusual transmembrane helix 11 and 12 extensions that protrude ~20&nbsp;&Aring; into the periplasm. A small, very hydrophobic cavity suitable for lipid transport is constricted by a functionally important ion-lock likely involved in proton coupling. Combining mutational analyses and MD simulations, the authors proposed that TAGs are extracted from the core of the inner membrane into the central cavity via lateral clefts present in the inward-facing conformation. The functional role of the periplasmic helix extensions is to channel the extracted TAG into the lipid binding pocket of LprG (<span id="ref34557479.37833269" class="cite">Remm <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>P55 drug efflux pump of<em> Mycobacterium tuberculosis </em>(P71678)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.36"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.36&tcname=">2.A.1.3.36</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>EmrKY-TolC MDR efflux pump (<span id="ref1912.11566977" class="cite">Nishino and Yamaguchi 2001</span>). (also exports cysteine (<span id="ref7182.16820466" class="cite">Yamada <em>et al.</em>, 2006</span>)) (similar to 2.A.1.3.2)</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>EmrKY-TolC of <em>E. coli</em><br />EmrK (MFP) (C5W790)<br />EmrY (MFS) (C5W789)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.37"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.37&tcname=">2.A.1.3.37</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The uridine/deoxyuridine/5-fluorouridine uptake transporter, UriP (llmg_0856) (480aas; 14TMSs) (<span id="ref7503.20595258" class="cite">Martinussen <em>et al.</em>, 2010</span>)</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>UriP of <em>Lactococcus lactis </em>(A2RJJ9)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.38"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.38&tcname=">2.A.1.3.38</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS porter of unknown function</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS porter of<em> Streptomyces viridochromogenes</em> (D9X7X8)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.39"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.39&tcname=">2.A.1.3.39</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The antimicrobial efflux pump, LmrS. Exports&nbsp;linezolid and tetraphenylphosphonium chloride (TPCL) &gt; sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS), trimethoprim, and chloramphenicol. (most similar to LmrB (2.A.1.3.30)) (<span id="ref7683.20855745" class="cite">Floyd <em>et al.</em>, 2010</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>LmrS of <em>Staphylococcus aureus</em> (Q5HE38)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.4"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.4&tcname=">2.A.1.3.4</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>(Mono- and divalent organocation):H<sup>+</sup> antiporter. Transmembrane helix 12 of QacA lines the bivalent cationic drug binding pocket (<span id="ref7026.17951386" class="cite">Hassan <em>et al.</em>, 2007</span>). Two sites, D34 and D411 are involved in substrate recognition, while E407 facilitates substrate efflux as a protonation site and plays a role as a substrate recognition site for the transport of dequalinium, a divalent quaternary ammonium compound (<span id="ref34549722.30910733" class="cite">Majumder <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>). TMS 12 and its external flanking loop are required for the structural and functional integrity of QacA, and they contain amino acids directly involved in their interactions with substrates (<span id="ref34556367.37100459" class="cite">Dashtbani-Roozbehani <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). Cryo-EM structures of QacA from <em>S. aureus</em> revealed a novel extracellular loop with an allosteric role (<span id="ref34556881.37458117" class="cite">Majumder <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Gram-positive bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>QacA of <em>Staphylococcus aureus</em> (P0A0J9)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.40"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.40&tcname=">2.A.1.3.40</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The phenazine resistance pump. It also exports D-alanyl-griseoluteic acid; possibly in conjunction with a chaperone protein, EhpR. The crystal structure of EhpR is known (<span id="ref7941.21849072" class="cite">Yu <em>et al.</em>, 2011</span>). Note: Phenazines are toxic redox active secondary metabolites that many bacteria secrete. It may be&nbsp; involved in the export of griseoluteic acid, an intermediate in the biosynthesis of the broad-spectrum phenazine antibiotic, D-alanylgriseoluteic acid (<span id="ref34553500.34180603" class="cite">Dagher <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>EhpJ of <em>Panloea</em> (<em>Enterobacter</em>) <em>agglomerans</em> (O32600)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.43"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.43&tcname=">2.A.1.3.43</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p><a id="2.A.1.3.43"></a></p>
<p>MFS efflux pump, AmvA (AedF). Mediates drug, dye, detergent, antibiotic and disinfectant resistance (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref8035">Rajamohan <em>et al.</em>, 2010</a>; <span id="ref9950.21430390" class="cite">Hassan <em>et al.</em> 2011</span>). 98.6% identical to AdeF (2.A.1.3.46).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>AmvA of <em>Acinetobacter baumannii</em>&nbsp;(C4PAW9)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.44"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.44&tcname=">2.A.1.3.44</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MDR pump, AdeF (AmvA) exports ethidium, DAPI, and chlorhexidine (<span id="ref9950.21430390" class="cite">Hassan <em>et al.</em> 2011</span>). 98.6% identical to AmvA (2.A.1.3.45).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>AdeF of <em>Acinetobacter baumannii</em>&nbsp;(A3M6E0)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.46"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.46&tcname=">2.A.1.3.46</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The phenicol (florfenicol/chloramphenicol) exporter, FexB (<span id="ref8600.22096043" class="cite">Liu <em>et al.</em>, 2012</span>)</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Firmicutes&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>FexB of <em>Enterococcus faecium&nbsp;</em>(G9FS16)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.47"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.47&tcname=">2.A.1.3.47</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The trichothecene efflux pump, TRI12 (<span id="ref8735.10485289" class="cite">Alexander <em>et al.</em>, 1999</span>; <span id="ref8736.10805582" class="cite">Wuchiyama <em>et al.</em>, 2000</span>). Trichothecenes are plant growth promoters and bio-control agents (See also Fang et al. (<span id="ref8737.22614820" class="cite">2012</span>)). TRI12 secretes toxic trichothecene compounds like T-2 toxin, nivalenol and deoxynivalenol.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Fungi</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>TRI12 of <em>Fusarium sporotrichioides</em>&nbsp;(Q9C1B3)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.48"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.48&tcname=">2.A.1.3.48</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Multidrug-efflux transporter Rv1634/MT1670 of 471 aas and 14 TMSs.&nbsp; Both Rv1634 and Rv1258c are believed to play a major role in drug resistance by altering the protein pump that is required to remove the active drug compounds from the bacterial cell (<span id="ref34549719.30799437" class="cite">Panja <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>). Ciprofloxacin and norfloxacin are substrates, to which <em>M. tuberculosis</em> strains have become resistant. The expulsion of the drugs to the outside the bacterial cell occurs through the alternating-access mechanism of N and C-terminal domains (<span id="ref34553988.34601761" class="cite">Singh and Akhter 2021</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Rv1634 of <em>Mycobacterium tuberculosis</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.49"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.49&tcname=">2.A.1.3.49</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p><!-- test--><p>
																												                                         																																																								                                     
																																																																	                                     Multidrug resistance protein Stp (Spectinomycin tetracycline efflux pump)</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Stp of <em>Myconbacterium tuberculosis</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.5"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.5&tcname=">2.A.1.3.5</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>(Pristinamycin I and II, rifamycin, etc.):H<sup>+</sup> antiporter</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Gram-positive bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Ptr of <i>Streptomyces pristinaespiralis</i> </TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.50"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.50&tcname=">2.A.1.3.50</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Multidrug resistance protein 3 (Multidrug-efflux transporter 3) or Brm3, of 512 aas and 14 TMSs. Resistance to puromycin, tosofloxacin, norfloxacin, acriflavin, ethidium, and tetraphenyl phosphonium, but not ofloxacin, nalidixic acid or <span style="font-size: 9pt; font-family: ">carbonyl cyanide </span><span style="font-size: 9pt; font-style: italic; font-family: ">m</span><span style="font-size: 9pt; font-family: ">-chlorophenylhydrazone (<span id="ref34551075.9023234" class="cite">Ohki and Murata 1997</span>). </span>A spontaneous <em>B. subtilis</em> mutant isolated in the presence of a high concentration of
 puromycin acquired a multidrug-resistant phenotype due to high level expression of the <em><span class="highlight">bmr3</span></em> gene (<span id="ref34551076.15489457" class="cite">Ohki and Tateno 2004</span>), and selection for improved synthesis of menaquinone-7 also caused increased expression (<span id="ref34551077.32109677" class="cite">Cui <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacilli</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bmr3 of <em>Bacillus subtilis </em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.51"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.51&tcname=">2.A.1.3.51</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Probable transport protein HsrA (High-copy suppressor of RspA)</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>HsrA of <em>Escherichia coli </em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.52"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.52&tcname=">2.A.1.3.52</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Drug resistance protein YOR378W.&nbsp; Does not export boron (<span id="ref34544390.21621519" class="cite">Bozdag <em>et al.</em> 2011</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Fungi</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>YOR378W of <em>Saccharomyces cerevisiae </em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.53"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.53&tcname=">2.A.1.3.53</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Azole resistance protein 1</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Fungi</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>AZR1 of <em>Saccharomyces cerevisiae  </em></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.54"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.54&tcname=">2.A.1.3.54</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Protein SGE1 (10-N-nonyl acridine orange resistance protein) (Crystal violet resistance protein)</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Fungi</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>SGE1 of <em>Saccharomyces cerevisiae  </em></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.55"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.55&tcname=">2.A.1.3.55</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p><!-- test--><p>
																												                                         																																																								                                     
																																																																	                                     Uncharacterized MFS-type transporter YubD</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Bacilli</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>YubD of <em>Bacillus subtilis </em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.56"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.56&tcname=">2.A.1.3.56</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative MFS drug exporter of 461 aas and 14 TMSs.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Porter of <em>Paenibacillus polymyxa</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.57"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.57&tcname=">2.A.1.3.57</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p><!-- test--><p>
																												                                         																																																								                                     
																																																																	                                     Uncharacterized MFS-type transporter YwoD</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Bacilli</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>YwoD of <em>Bacillus subtilis </em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.58"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.58&tcname=">2.A.1.3.58</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p><!-- test--><p>
																												                                         																																																								                                     
																																																																	                                     Uncharacterized MFS-type transporter YfiU</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Bacilli</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>YfiU of <em>Bacillus subtilis </em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.59"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.59&tcname=">2.A.1.3.59</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MDR efflux pump, NorC (<span id="ref9945.16495280" class="cite">Truong-Bolduc <em>et al.</em> 2006</span>). Proposed to be a quinolone resistance exporter, NorB (<span id="ref34546447.28197063" class="cite">Marklevitz and Harris 2016</span>). The 3-d x-ray structure at 3.6 &Aring; resolution has been solved in an outward open configuration (<span id="ref34553693.34226658" class="cite">Kumar <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>). The structure shows that NorC specifically interacts with an organic cation, tetraphenylphosphonium. Multidrug-resistance in <em>S. aureus</em> is inhibited by the endocannabinoid, anandamide (<span id="ref34555087.35887146" class="cite">Sionov <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Firmicutes</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>NorC (NorB) of <em>Staphylococcus aureus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.6"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.6&tcname=">2.A.1.3.6</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Me<sup>2+</sup>·tetracycline:2H<sup>+</sup> or 2K<sup>+</sup> antiporter <br>   (the optimal Me<sup>2+</sup> = Co<sup>2+</sup>)  (Also transports Na<sup>+</sup> or K<sup>+</sup>out in exchange for 2H<sup>+</sup>.)</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>TetK of <i>Staphylococcus aureus</i> (P02983)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.60"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.60&tcname=">2.A.1.3.60</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p><a id="2.A.1.3.60"></a></p>
<p>MDR efflux pump, SdrM.&nbsp; Exports norfloxacin, acriflavin and ethidium bromide (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref9946">Yamada <em>et al.</em> 2006</a>). Multidrug-resistance in <em>S. aureus</em> is inhibited by the endocannabinoid, anandamide (<span id="ref34555087.35887146" class="cite">Sionov <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Firmicutes</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SdrM of <em>Staphylococcus aureus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.61"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.61&tcname=">2.A.1.3.61</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MDR efflux pump, MdeA.&nbsp; Exports quaternary ammonium compounds and antibiotics (<span>Huang <em>et al.</em> 2004</span>). Also exports hoechst 33342, doxorubicin, daunorubicin, tetraphenyl phosphonium, ethidium bromide and rhodamine 6G (<span>Yamada <em>et al.</em> 2006</span>). Multidrug-resistance in <em>S. aureus</em> is inhibited by the endocannabinoid, anandamide (<span id="ref34555087.35887146" class="cite">Sionov <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Firmicutes</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MdeA of <em>Staphylococcus aureus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.62"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.62&tcname=">2.A.1.3.62</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MDR efflux pump, AedC (<span id="ref9950.21430390" class="cite">Hassan <em>et al.</em> 2011</span>).&nbsp; Shown to export chloramphenicol and tetracycline.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>AedC of <em>Acinetobacter baumannii</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.63"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.63&tcname=">2.A.1.3.63</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Iron homeostasis protein, AedD; may function in siderophore export (<span id="ref9950.21430390" class="cite">Hassan <em>et al.</em> 2011</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>AedD of <em>Acinetobacter baumannii</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.64"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.64&tcname=">2.A.1.3.64</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Uptake permease for cholate (steroid) metabolites, CamM of 513 aas and 14 TMSs.&nbsp; Uptake of 3,7(R),12(S)-trihydroxy-9-oxo-9,10-seco-23,24-bisnorchola-1,3,5(10)-trien-22-oate was observed (<span id="ref10275.23024344" class="cite">Swain <em>et al.</em> 2012</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Actinobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>CamM of <em>Rhodococcus jostii</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.65"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.65&tcname=">2.A.1.3.65</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ThMFS1 of 563 aas and 14 TMSs.&nbsp; Catalyzes export of fungicides causing tolerance.&nbsp; It exports trichodermin, but it is not the only exporter of this secondary metabolite (<span id="ref10277.22661043" class="cite">Liu <em>et al.</em> 2012</span>). Trichothecenes are the sesquiterpenes secreted by <em>Trichoderma</em> spp. residing in the rhizosphere.
These compounds have been reported to act as plant growth promoters and bio-control agents (<span id="ref34546034.27816530" class="cite">Chaudhary <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Fungi</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS1 of <em>Trichoderma harzianum (Hypocrea lixii)</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.66"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.66&tcname=">2.A.1.3.66</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS permease of 413 aas and 12 TMSs. Encoded within the SoxR regulon; possibly a drug exporter (<span id="ref34544864.25162599" class="cite">Naseer <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS permease of<em> Pseudomonas aeruginosa</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.67"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.67&tcname=">2.A.1.3.67</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS porter of 462 aas and 14 TMSs</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><em>Deinococcus/Thermus</em></p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS porter of<em> Deinococcus radiodurans</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.68"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.68&tcname=">2.A.1.3.68</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The PfMFS transporter (551 aas; 14 putative TMSs) is involved in the acid resistance and intracellular pH homeostasis of <em>Penicillium funiculosum</em> (<span id="ref11279.24959657" class="cite">Xu <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>).  This protein (AIJ02309) was not in UniProt when enterred into TCDB, and its closest orthologue, PmMFS of <em>Penicillium marneffei,</em> is therefore presented here. These two proteins are 82% identical.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Fungi</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PfMFS of <em>Talaromyces (Penicillium) funiculosum</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.69"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.69&tcname=">2.A.1.3.69</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Drug resistance pump, YMR279c of 540 aas.&nbsp; When overexpressed, confers boron resistance, but is not induced by boron (<span id="ref34544390.21621519" class="cite">Bozdag <em>et al.</em> 2011</span>).&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>YMR279c of <em>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</em> (Baker's yeast)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.7"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.7&tcname=">2.A.1.3.7</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Actinorhodin:H<sup>+</sup> antiporter, ActVa or ActA (<span id="ref4126.17338074" class="cite">Tahlan <em>et al</em>., 2007</span>)</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Gram-positive bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>ActVa of <i>Streptomyces coelicolor</i> </TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.70"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.70&tcname=">2.A.1.3.70</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Probable exporter of aromatic compounds of 559 aas and 16 putative TMSs in an apparent 4 + 4 + 4 + 4 arrangement. May function in aromatic compoound detoxification.&nbsp; Regulated by a MarR-like transcriptional regulator that is encoded in the same operon. A ten-fold induction occurs in response to aromatic aldehydes such as benzaldehyde (<span id="ref34544872.17675388" class="cite">Fiorentino <em>et al.</em> 2007</span>). The same MarR protein controls transcription of a gene encoding an NADH-dependent alcohol dehydrogenase (Sso2536).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Sso1351 of <em>Sulfolobus solfataricus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.71"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.71&tcname=">2.A.1.3.71</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative multidrug-resistance exporter of 553 aas and 14 putative TMSs, KNQ1. It is a drug efflux permease for several toxic compounds that in
multiple copies confer increased dithiothreitol resistance. KNQ1 does not export dithiothreitol or function in recombinant protein secretion. KNQ1 gene amplification or deletion resulted in enhanced transcription of
iron transport genes, suggesting,&nbsp; a role
in iron homeostasis on which dithiothreitol tolerance may depend (<span id="ref34546380.17428309" class="cite">Marchi <em>et al.</em> 2007</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>KNQ1 of <em>Kluyveromyces lactis</em> (Yeast)<em> (Candida sphaerica)</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.72"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.72&tcname=">2.A.1.3.72</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Riboflavin transporter of 456 aas and 14 TMSs, RibZ (<span id="ref34546395.25938806" class="cite">Guti&eacute;rrez-Preciado <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>RibZ of <em>Peptoclostridium difficile (Clostridium difficile)</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.73"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.73&tcname=">2.A.1.3.73</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Multidrug resistance Mfs1 protein of 583 aas and 14 TMSs.&nbsp; Exports natural mycotoxins and a variety of fungicides in <em>Mycosphaerella graminicola</em> (<span id="ref34546715.17107817" class="cite">Roohparvar <em>et al.</em> 2007</span>). Etridiazole (EDZ) is a thiadiazole-containing fungicide commonly used to control Pythium and Phytophthora spp. Studies have shown that EDZ is teratogenic. A zebrafish (Danio rerio; ZF) model has been used to explore the molecular pathways associated with EDZ toxicity, and itwas concluded that there are several (<span id="ref34557549.37894748" class="cite">Vasamsetti <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MDR exporter, Mfs1 of <em>Zymoseptoria tritici </em>(Speckled leaf blotch fungus) <em>(Septoria tritici)</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.74"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.74&tcname=">2.A.1.3.74</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Polyamine/cationinc amino acid exporter, CmgA.&nbsp; Exports L-lysine, L-arginine, L-citrulline, the diamine/polyamine, putrescine, cadaverine, and possibly spermdine and spermine (<span id="ref34547080.25449016" class="cite">Nguyen <em>et al.</em> 2015</span> ;<span id="ref34547078.27350619" class="cite">Lubitz <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>CmgA of <em>Corynebacterium glutamicum</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.75"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.75&tcname=">2.A.1.3.75</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Erythromycin/macrolide export system of 499 aas and 14 TMSs, ErmB (<span id="ref34547418.25008823" class="cite">Zhou <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>).&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ErmB of <em>Streptococcus pyogenes</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.76"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.76&tcname=">2.A.1.3.76</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS transporter of 530 aas and 14 TMSs, SgvT1.&nbsp; Exports griseoviridin and viridogrisein (etamycin) (<span id="ref34547494.29065880" class="cite">Xie <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SgvT1 of <em>Streptomyces griseoviridis</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.77"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.77&tcname=">2.A.1.3.77</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Drug resistance efflux porter, SgvT3 of 464 aas and 14 TMSs. (<span id="ref34547494.29065880" class="cite">Xie <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SgvT3 of<em> Streptomyces griseoviridis</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.78"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.78&tcname=">2.A.1.3.78</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Drug resistance pump, EfpA of 530 aas and 14 TMSs.&nbsp; May function with IniABC (see TC# 9.B.282), shown to influence resistance to several drugs (<span>Colangeli <em>et al.</em> 2007</span>).&nbsp; <span style="font-weight: normal;">Structures of the essential drug efflux pump EfpA from <em>Mycobacterium tuberculosis</em> reveal the mechanisms of substrate transport and small-molecule inhibition (<span id="ref34557756.38260587" class="cite">Wang <em>et al.</em> 2024</span>).<br /></span></p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>EfpA of Mycobacterium tuberculosis</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.79"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.79&tcname=">2.A.1.3.79</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Multidrug resistance MFS exporter, MFS54 of 538 aas and 14 TMSs. A fungal mutant lacking AaMFS54 produced fewer conidia and showed increased sensitivity to many potent oxidants (potassium superoxide and singlet-oxygen generating compounds) as well as&nbsp; xenobiotics (2,3,5-triiodobenzoic acid and 2-chloro-5-hydroxypyridine), and fungicides (clotrimazole, fludioxonil, vinclozolin, and iprodione) (<span id="ref34548925.30279684" class="cite">Lin <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). Virulence assays on citrus leaves inoculated by spraying with spores revealed that <em>AaMFS54</em> mutant induced less severe lesions than wild-type.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS54 of <em>Alternaria alternata</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.8"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.8&tcname=">2.A.1.3.8</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Cephamycin:H<sup>+</sup> antiporter</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Gram-positive bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>CmcT of <i>Nocardia lactamdurans</i> </TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.80"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.80&tcname=">2.A.1.3.80</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Uncharacterized EmrB/QacA-like durg resistance transporter of 540 aas and 14 TMSs. The gene encoding this protein is adjacent to a 3 component putative ABC drug exporter of TC# 3.A.1.122.32.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>U-MFS porter of <em>Cellulomonas flavigena </em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.81"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.81&tcname=">2.A.1.3.81</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>multidrug (tetracycline, kanamycin, rhodamin 6G, ampicillin, acriflavine, ethidium bromide, and tetraphenylphosphonium chloride) resistance exporter, MdeA, of 453 aas and 14 TMSs (<span id="ref34550523.23462018" class="cite">Kim <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MdeA of <em>Streptococcus mutans</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.82"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.82&tcname=">2.A.1.3.82</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Multidrug resistance transporter protein of 519 aas and 14 TMSs. It exports 2-thiocyanatopyridine derivatives (<span id="ref34550742.31546596" class="cite">Nunvar <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MDR pump of <em>Burkholderia cenocepacia (Burkholderia cepacia)</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.83"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.83&tcname=">2.A.1.3.83</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>AflT efflux pump of 514 aas and 14 TMSs (<span id="ref34551175.15094053" class="cite">Yu <em>et al.</em> 2004</span>).&nbsp; Its gene is <span>part of the gene cluster that mediates the biosynthesis of aflatoxins (<span id="ref34551174.15006741" class="cite">Yu <em>et al.</em> 2004</span>). <br /></span></p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>AflT of <em>Aspergillus parasiticus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.84"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.84&tcname=">2.A.1.3.84</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Trichothecene efflux pump, Tri12, of 590 aas and 14 TMSs (<span id="ref34553144.11976083" class="cite">Lee <em>et al.</em> 2002</span>). It may function as a phospholipid flippase, and five flippases (FgDnfA, B, C1, C2 and D have been identified&nbsp; (<span id="ref34553145.32881238" class="cite">Yun <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). FgDnfA is critical for normal vegetative growth while the other flippases are dispensable. FgDnfA and FgDnfD are crucial for fungal pathogenesis, and a remarkable reduction in deoxynivalenol (DON) production was observed in DeltaFgDNFA and DeltaFgDNFD strains. Deletion of the FgDNFB gene increased DON production to about 30 fold. FgDnfA and FgDnfD play positive roles in the regulation of trichothecene (TRI) gene (TRI1, TRI4, TRI5, TRI6, TRI12, and TRI101) expression and toxisome reorganization, while FgDnfB acts as a negative regulator of DON synthesis. FgDnfB and FgDnfD have redundant functions in the regulation of phosphatidylcholine transport, and double deletion of FgDNFB and FgDnfD showed defects in fungal development, DON synthesis, and virulence. Thus, the distinct and specific functions of flippase family members in <em>F. graminearum</em> have been determined, and FgDnfA, FgDnfD, and FgDnfB have specific spatiotemporal roles during toxisome biogenesis (<span id="ref34553145.32881238" class="cite">Yun <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). This protein is 76% identical to the protein with TC# 2.A.1.3.47, and they probably catalyze the same reaction(s).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Tri12 of <em>Gibberella zeae </em>(Wheat head blight fungus)<em> (Fusarium graminearum)</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.85"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.85&tcname=">2.A.1.3.85</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><em>Acinetobacter baumannii</em> ATCC17978 MDR pump (A1S_0188) of the DHA2 family in the MFS (<span id="ref9950.21430390" class="cite">Hassan <em>et al.</em> 2011</span>). It is of 463 aas with 14 TMSs. There are 6 DHA2 members in <em>A. baumannii</em>. One of these, called AadT, exports a variety of drugs (<span id="ref34556540.37252766" class="cite">Naidu <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MDR pump AedA of <em>Acinetobacter baumannii</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.3.9"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.3.9&tcname=">2.A.1.3.9</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Lincomycin:H<sup>+</sup> antiporter</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Gram-positive bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>LmrA of <i>Streptomyces lincolnensis</i></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=2.A.1.30">2.A.1.30 The Putative Abietane Diterpenoid Transporter (ADT) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.30.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.30.1&tcname=">2.A.1.30.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative abietane uptake permease (in a gene cluster for degradation of abietane diterpenoids), DitE, of 547 aas and 12 TMSs (<span id="ref752.10850995" class="cite">Martin and Mohn 2000</span>). <span class="highlight">Abietane</span> diterpenoids are defense compounds synthesized by trees that are 
abundant in natural environments and occur as significant pollutants 
from pulp and paper production (<span id="ref34546650.17586638" class="cite">Smith <em>et al.</em> 2007</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.31.8&tcname=">2.A.1.31.8</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Nickel resistance membrane nickel efflux protein NirA of 432 aas and 12 TMSs.&nbsp; This protein is 99.7% identical to a trunkated homolog from <em>Klebsiella oxytoca</em> (<span id="ref34544792.18600044" class="cite">Park <em>et al.</em> 2008</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>NirA of <em>Enterobacter cloacae</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=2.A.1.32">2.A.1.32 The Putative Aromatic Compound/Drug Exporter (ACDE) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.32.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.32.1&tcname=">2.A.1.32.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative aromatic compound/drug exporter. Enhances expression of the sigma X gene that functions to modify the cell envelope (<span id="ref755.10960106" class="cite">Turner and Helmann, 2000</span>). <em>yitG</em>&nbsp;is reported to be a mutator gene that inhibits transition base substitutions (<span id="ref7745.15109717" class="cite">Sasaki and Kurusu, 2004</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacilli</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>YitG of <em>Bacillus subtilis</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.32.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.32.2&tcname=">2.A.1.32.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Bacillibactin exporter, YmfE (199aas; 6TMSs) (<span id="ref5291.18502870" class="cite">Miethke <em>et al</em>., 2008</span>) (resembles the 2<sup>nd</sup> half of YitG of <I>B. subtilis</I> (2.A.1.32.1). The sequence provided under acc# O31763 is only a fragment of the full length gene.</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>YmfE of <I>Bacillus subtilis</I> (O31763)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.32.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.32.3&tcname=">2.A.1.32.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p>Putative copper/multidrug efflux protein, YfmO.&nbsp; The <em>yfmPO</em> operon is 
autoregulated by the MerR homologue, YfmP (a repressor). The <em>copZA</em> operon encodes CopA, a copper ATPase (TC# 3.A.3.5.18) which is induced by a copper dependent mechanism. Since a <em>yfmP </em>null mutant had poor <em>copZA</em> induction but elevated 
levels of the <span class="highlight">YfmO</span> efflux pump, YfmO could catalyze copper efflux and be 
responsible for reduced <em>copZA</em> induction. Consistent with this model, a <em>yfmP <span class="highlight">yfmO</span></em> double mutant showed normal induction by copper (<span id="ref11300.14663075" class="cite">Gaballa <em>et al.</em> 2003</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacilli</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>YfmO of <em>Bacillus subtilis </em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=2.A.1.33">2.A.1.33 The Putative YqgE Transporter (YqgE) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><p>These proteins are most closely related to TC#s 2.A.1.21 and 2.A.1.46, and therefore may be MDR exporters.</p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.33.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.33.1&tcname=">2.A.1.33.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS homologue, YqgE. It is cotranscribed with<em> ftsI</em>, encoding the peptidoglycan transpeptidase that crosslinks peptidoglycan strands, releasing free D-alanine. Possibly YqgE is a D-alanine uptake porter. Its expression causes a decrease in the amount of sigma W synthesis, the sigma factor for genes involved in detoxification and antimicrobial synthesis (<span id="ref755.10960106" class="cite">Turner and Helmann 2000</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria; Archaea</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>YqgE of <em>Bacillus subtilis </em>(P54487)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.33.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.33.2&tcname=">2.A.1.33.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>YqgE homologue</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>YqgE homologue of <em>Bacteroides ovatus </em>(A7LYG9)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.33.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.33.3&tcname=">2.A.1.33.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>YqgE homologue (encoded near an &alpha;-glucuronidase; GH31 family; divergently transcribed). Therefore could be an uptake system for glucouronides.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Archaea</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>YqgE homologue of <em>Sulfolobus tokodaii </em>(Q96XI6)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.33.4"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.33.4&tcname=">2.A.1.33.4</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Uncharacterized protein of 385 aas and 12 TMSs.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>UP of Candidatus <em>Beckwithbacteria bacterium</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=2.A.1.34">2.A.1.34 The Sensor Kinase-MFS Fusion (SK-MFS) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.34.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.34.1&tcname=">2.A.1.34.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Sensor kinase (N-terminal 400 residues)/MFS fusion protein. The N-terminal domain resembles the sensor kinase of 414 aas of <em>Anaeromyxobacter</em> sp. KJ (ACG71775). The C-terminal MFS domain most resembles those of TC family 2.A.1.2 (DHA1).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Fusion protein of <em>Bordetella pertussis</em> (Q7VWI9)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.34.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.34.2&tcname=">2.A.1.34.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS carrier with N-terminal hydrophilic domain with 3 putative TMSs of about 2880 aas. It <span>mediates high-affinity (550 nM K<sub>m</sub>) intracellular uptake of the rare oligo-element molybdenum.&nbsp; It is probably a molybdate (</span><span>the oxianion molybdate)/anion uptake porter (<span id="ref34551090.21464289" class="cite">Tejada-Jim&eacute;nez <em>et al.</em> 2011</span>). In mammals, it is expressed in the </span>brain and may play a role in energy homeostasis (<span id="ref34551539.27272503" class="cite">Perland <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>).</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Molybdate uptake porter of <em>Homo sapiens<br /></em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Bch2 of <i>Rhodobacter capsulatus</i> </TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=2.A.1.42">2.A.1.42 The Lysophospholipid Transporter (LplT) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.42.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.42.1&tcname=">2.A.1.42.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The lysophospholipid (LPL) transporter, LplT (<span id="ref3065.15661733" class="cite">Harvat <em>et al</em>., 2005</span>).&nbsp; Substrates include lyso-PE, lyso-cardiolipin, diacylcardiolipin, fully-deacylated cardiolipin and lyso-phosphatidylglycerol, but not lysophosphatidylcholine, lysophosphatidic acid or phosphatidic acid (<span id="ref34545128.26613781" class="cite">Lin <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>). Reacylation by acyltransferase/acyl-acyl 
carrier protein synthetase then occurs on the inner leaflet of the membrane.Thus, a fatty acid chain is not required for LplT 
transport. A "sideways sliding" 
mechanism was proposed to explain how a conserved membrane-embedded &alpha;-helical 
interface excludes diacylphospholipids from the LplT binding site to 
facilitate efficient flipping of lysophospho-lipids across the cell 
membrane (<span id="ref34545128.26613781" class="cite">Lin <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>). Thus, a fatty acid chain is not required for LplT 
transport. Fruther, LplT cannot transport lysophosphatidic acid, 
and its substrate binding was not inhibited by either orthophosphate or 
glycerol 3-phosphate, indicating that either a glycerol or ethanolamine 
headgroup is the chemical determinant for substrate recognition. Diacyl 
forms of PE, phosphatidylglycerol, or the tetra-acylated form of 
cardiolipin could not serve as competitive inhibitors .A "sideways sliding" 
mechanism was proposed to explain how a conserved membrane-embedded &alpha;-helical 
interface can exclude diacylphospholipids from the LplT binding site. A dual substrate-accessing mechanism, in which LplT recruits LPLs to its substrate-binding site via two routes, either from its extracellular entry site, or through a membrane-embedded groove between transmembrane helices, and it then moves them towards the inner membrane leaflet (<span id="ref34548998.30373772" class="cite">Lin <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>LplT of <em>E. coli</em> (NP_417312)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.42.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.42.2&tcname=">2.A.1.42.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The lysophospholipid transporter-2-acyl glycerophosphoethanolamine acyl transferase/acyl ACP synthetase (LplT-Pls-ACS) fusion protein (<span id="ref3065.15661733" class="cite">Harvat <em>et al</em>., 2005</span>).&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The fused LplT-PlsC-ACS of <em>Bradyrhizobium japonicum</em> (BAC47589)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=2.A.1.43">2.A.1.43 The Putative Magnetosome Permease (PMP) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.43.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.43.1&tcname=">2.A.1.43.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>The putative magnetosomal permease, MamH (<span id="ref2648.13129949" class="cite">Schubbe <em>et al</em>., 2003</span>)</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>MamH of <i>Magnetospirillum gryphiswaldense</i> (Q6NE63)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.43.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.43.2&tcname=">2.A.1.43.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a id="2.A.1.43"></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p><a id="2.A.1.43.2"></a></p>
<p>The magnetosome permease fused to a C-terminal YedZ-like domain, MamZ (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref6838">von Rozycki <em>et al.</em>, 2004</a>). This protein has 649 aas and 18 TMSs with a C-terminal YedZ domain and is therefore in the YedZ superfamily as well as the MFS. The two MFS proteins in the magnetosome membrane, MamZ and MamH (44% identical to MamZ), appear to overlap in function as deletion of their two genes have additive effects (<span id="ref34547224.23889511" class="cite">Raschdorf <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>). Magnetosome biogenesis has been reviewed ().</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PMP of <em>Magnetospirillum magneticum</em> (Q2W8K5)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=2.A.1.44">2.A.1.44 The L-Amino Acid Transporter-3 (LAT3) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><p>This family is also called the SLC43 family.</p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.44.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.44.1&tcname=">2.A.1.44.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The L-amino acid transporter-3, LAT3 (transports neutral amino acids such as L-leucine, L-isoleucine, L-valine, and L-phenylalanine by a Na<sup>+</sup>-independent, electroneutral, facilitated diffusion process; it also transports amino acid alcohols and thyroid hormones such as 3,3'-T2) (Prostate cancer up-regulated gene product) (<span id="ref34550564.31739345" class="cite">Krause and Hinz 2019</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SLC43A1 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.44.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.44.2&tcname=">2.A.1.44.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>L-amino acid transporter-4 (LAT4) has the same specificity and is 57% identity to LAT3.  Na<sup>+</sup>, Cl<sup>-</sup> and pH independent; not trans-stimulated; it has been reported to have two kinetic components, a low affinity component sensitive to NEM, and a high affinity component insensitive to NEM. It is found in the basolateral membrane of epithelial cells in the distal tubule and collecting duct of the kidney and the crypt cells in the intestine (<span id="ref3067.15659399" class="cite">Bodoy <em>et al</em>., 2005</span>). It can transport throid hormones such as 3,3'-T2 (<span id="ref34550565.31739345" class="cite">Krause and Hinz 2019</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SLC43A2 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.44.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.44.3&tcname=">2.A.1.44.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC> solute carrier family 43, member 3</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Animals</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>SLC43A3 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.44.4"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.44.4&tcname=">2.A.1.44.4</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Similar to MFS transporter Fmp4; of 614 aas and 12 TMSs in a 6 + 6 TMS arrangement where the two 6 TMS units are separated by a large hydrophilic domain.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS porter of <em>Leptosphaeria maculans</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=2.A.1.45">2.A.1.45 The 2,4-diacetylphloroglucinol (PHL) Exporter (PHL-E) Family </A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><p>This family is most closely related to TC# 2.A.1.15.</p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR (Spinster) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal protein, <em>spin1</em> or <em>spns1</em> gene product (involved in synaptic growth regulation; interacts with Bcl-2/Bcl-xL, affecting programmed cell death) (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref3070">Nakano <em>et al</em>., 2001</a>; <a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref3069">Sanyal and Ramaswami, 2002</a>; <a class="reflink" 2012</span>), but polymorphisms in <em>spns1</em> are associated with alterred triglyceride levels (<span id="ref34551555.22942098" class="cite">V&auml;stermark <em>et al.</em> 2012</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Spinster of <em>Drosophila melanogaster</em> (AAG43825)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.49.10"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.49.10&tcname=">2.A.1.49.10</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS multidrug exporter of 429 aas and 12 TMSs.&nbsp; Exports capreomycin and ethidium bromide, and deletion mutants grow faster than wild type cells (<span id="ref34543795.25697715" class="cite">Zhang <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font
