valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.49.11"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.49.11&tcname=">2.A.1.49.11</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Uncharacterized protein of 656 aas and 12 TMSs</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>UP of <em>Chlamydomonas reinhardtii (Chlamydomonas smithii)</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.49.12"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.49.12&tcname=">2.A.1.49.12</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Spinster 3, SPNS3 (SLC63A3), of 512 aas and 12 TMSs.&nbsp; The evolutionary conservation, predicted structure and neuronal expression have been characterized (<span id="ref34551557.28878041" class="cite">Perland <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>). It probably exports sphigosine-1- phosphate.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SPNS3 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.49.13"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.49.13&tcname=">2.A.1.49.13</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS porter, MFR1, of 853 aas and 12 TMSs in an apparent 6 + 2 + 4 TMS arrangement.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFR1 of <em>Plasmodium falciparum </em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.49.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.49.2&tcname=">2.A.1.49.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p><a id="2.A.1.49.2"></a></p>
<p>The spinster homologue, Spin1 or Spns1 (SLC63A1) of 528 aas and 12 TMSs. It interacts with Bc1-2/Bc1-XL to induce a caspase-independent autophagic cell death (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref3068">Yanagisawa <em>et al</em>., 2003</a>). It is a spingosine-1-phosphate (S1P) (or sphingolipid) exporter (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref8961">Nijnik <em>et al.</em> 2012</a>). S1P is important for lymphocyte trafficking, immune responses, 
vascular and embryonic development, cancer, bone homeostasis (<span id="ref34551556.30196234" class="cite">Zhu <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). S1P 
is produced intracellularly and then secreted into the circulation to 
engage in the above physiological or pathological processes by 
regulating the proliferation, differentiation and survival of target 
cells. SPNS2 acts as a mediator of 
intracellular S1P release. The SPNS1-dependent lysosomal lipid transport pathway enables cell survival under choline limitation (<span id="ref34556418.37075117" class="cite">Scharenberg <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). The orphan lysosomal transmembrane protein SPNS1 is critical for cell survival under choline limitation. SPNS1 loss leads to intralysosomal accumulation of lysophosphatidylcholine (LPC) and lysophosphatidylethanolamine (LPE). SPNS1 is a proton gradient-dependent transporter of LPC species from the lysosome for their re-esterification into phosphatidylcholine in the cytosol (<span id="ref34556418.37075117" class="cite">Scharenberg <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Spin1 of <em> Homo sapiens </em> (Q9H2V7)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.49.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.49.3&tcname=">2.A.1.49.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p><!-- test--><p>
																												                                         																																																								                                     <a id="2.A.1.49.3"></a></p>
																																																																	                                     <p>Probable sphingosine-1-phosphate (or sphingolipid) transporter, spinster homologue 3 (by similarity).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Plants</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Spinster homologue 3 of <em>Arabidopsis thaliana</em>&nbsp;(F4IKF6)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.49.4"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.49.4&tcname=">2.A.1.49.4</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p>Protein Spinster homologue 2 (Spns2 or protein two of hearts).&nbsp; Exports sphingosine-1-P (S1P) and the immunomodulating agent, FTY720 (<span id="ref11073.21084291" class="cite">Hisano <em>et al.</em> 2011</span>;<span id="ref8961.22664872" class="cite"> Nijnik <em>et al.</em> 2012</span>).&nbsp; S1P is a secreted lipid mediator that functions in vascular development. In the yolk syncytial layer, Spns2 functions in S1P secretion,
thereby regulating myocardial precursor migration (<span id="ref34544201.19074308" class="cite">Kawahara <em>et al.</em> 2009</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Spns2 of <em>Danio rerio </em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.49.5"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.49.5&tcname=">2.A.1.49.5</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p><a id="2.A.1.49.5"></a></p>
<p><a></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p>Probable sphingosine-1-phosphate or sphingolipid transporter, Spinster homologue 1 (by similarity).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Plants</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>At5g65687 of <em>Arabidopsis thaliana </em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.49.6"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.49.6&tcname=">2.A.1.49.6</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p><a id="2.A.1.49.6"></a></p>
<p><a></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p>Sphingosine-1-phosphate/dehydrosphingosine-1-P transport protein, Spinster 2, SPNS2 of 549 aas and 12 TMSs. It is involved in immune development and lymphocyte trafficing (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref8961">Nijnik <em>et al.</em> 2012; <span id="ref8962.22406534" class="cite">Fukuhara <em>et al.</em> 2012</span></a>). The functions and the mechanisms of SPNS2 in the pathogenesis of cancer have been reviewed (<span id="ref34552173.33144184" class="cite">Fang <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SPNS2 of <em>Homo sapiens </em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.49.7"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.49.7&tcname=">2.A.1.49.7</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p><!-- test--><p>
																												                                         																																																								                                     <a id="2.A.1.49.7"></a></p>
																																																																	                                     <p><a></a></p><!-- test--><p>
																												                                         																																																								                                     <a id="2.A.1.49.7"></a></p>
																																																																	                                     <p>Bacterial Spinster homologue; possible sphingosine-1-phosphate transporter (by similarity only).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Spinster homologue of <em>Myxococcus xanthus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.49.8"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.49.8&tcname=">2.A.1.49.8</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p><!-- test--><p>
																												                                         																																																								                                     <a id="2.A.1.49.8"></a></p>
																																																																	                                     <p>Bacterial spinster homologue.  Possible sphingosine-1-phosphate transporter (by similarity only).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Acidobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Spinster homologue of <em>Terriglobus saanensis</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.49.9"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.49.9&tcname=">2.A.1.49.9</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The cis, cis muconate transporter of 508 aas.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals (Insects)</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MucK of <em>Bombyx mori</em> (Silk moth)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=2.A.1.5">2.A.1.5 The Oligosaccharide:H<sup>+</sup> Symporter (OHS) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.5.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.5.1&tcname=">2.A.1.5.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-size: 7.5pt; font-family: Verdana;">&beta;- and &alpha;-galactopyranoside:H<sup>+</sup>&nbsp;symporter, LacY. Transports
lactose, melibiose, thio-&beta;-methyl galactopyranoside (TMG), isopropyl-&beta;-thiogalactoside (IPTG), 4-nitrophenyl-beta-D-galactopyranoside, 4-nitrophenyl-alpha-D-galactopyranoside and galactopyranosyl-1-glycerol. Single point mutations allow transport of sucrose and maltose (<span id="ref34546906.2190983" class="cite">King and Wilson 1990</span>).&nbsp; Crystal structures and modeling reveal the
cytoplasmic open state and the periplasmic open state (PDB ID: 1PV7). </span><span style="font-size: 7.5pt; font-family: Verdana;">A structure with a bound lactose homolog, beta-D-galactopyranosyl-1-thio-beta-D-galactopyranoside, revealed the <span class="highlight">sugar</span>-binding site in a cavity, and residues that play major roles in <span class="highlight">substrate</span> recognition and proton translocation were identified (</span><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><span style="font-size: 7.5pt; font-family: Verdana;">Abramson&nbsp;</span></span><em><span style="font-size: 7.5pt; font-family: Verdana;">et al.</span></em><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><span style="font-size: 7.5pt; font-family: Verdana;">, 2003</span></span><span style="font-size: 7.5pt; font-family: Verdana;">;&nbsp;</span><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><span style="font-size: 7.5pt; font-family: Verdana;">Pendse&nbsp;</span></span><em><span style="font-size: 7.5pt; font-family: Verdana;">et al.</span></em><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><span style="font-size: 7.5pt; font-family: Verdana;">, 2010</span></span><span style="font-size: 7.5pt; font-family: Verdana;">). The
membrane lipid composition determines the topology of LacY (</span><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><span style="font-size: 7.5pt; font-family: Verdana;">Dowhan and
Bogdanov, 2011</span></span><span style="font-size: 7.5pt; font-family: Verdana;">). Smirnova et al. (</span><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><span style="font-size: 7.5pt; font-family: Verdana;">2011</span></span><span style="font-size: 7.5pt; font-family: Verdana;">) have
provided evidence that the opening of the periplasmic cavity in LacY is the
limiting step for sugar binding. Evidence for an alternating sites mechanism of
transport has been summarized (</span><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><span style="font-size: 7.5pt; font-family: Verdana;">Smirnova&nbsp;</span></span><em><span style="font-size: 7.5pt; font-family: Verdana;">et al.</span></em><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><span style="font-size: 7.5pt; font-family: Verdana;">, 2011</span></span><span style="font-size: 7.5pt; font-family: Verdana;">). Eames
and Kortemme (</span><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><span style="font-size: 7.5pt; font-family: Verdana;">2012</span></span><span style="font-size: 7.5pt; font-family: Verdana;">) have shown that when
considering expression of the&nbsp;<em>lac</em>&nbsp;operon, LacY function (H<sup>+</sup> co-transport)
and not protein production is the primary origin of cost fitness. Homology
threading of several MFS porters based on the LacY 3-d structure has been
reported (</span><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><span style="font-size: 7.5pt; font-family: Verdana;">Kasho&nbsp;</span></span><em><span style="font-size: 7.5pt; font-family: Verdana;">et al.</span></em><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><span style="font-size: 7.5pt; font-family: Verdana;">, 2006</span></span><span style="font-size: 7.5pt; font-family: Verdana;">). The
alternating-access mechanism has been suggested to arise from inverted
topological repeats (</span><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><span style="font-size: 7.5pt; font-family: Verdana;">Radestock and Forrest, 2011;&nbsp;Madej&nbsp;</span></span><em><span style="font-size: 7.5pt; font-family: Verdana;">et al.</span></em><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><span style="font-size: 7.5pt; font-family: Verdana;">&nbsp;2012</span></span><span style="font-size: 7.5pt; font-family: Verdana;">), but
this proposal has been contested (</span><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><span style="font-size: 7.5pt; font-family: Verdana;">V&auml;stermark and Saier 2014;&nbsp;V&auml;stermark&nbsp;</span></span><em><span style="font-size: 7.5pt; font-family: Verdana;">et al.</span></em><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><span style="font-size: 7.5pt; font-family: Verdana;">&nbsp;2014</span></span><span style="font-size: 7.5pt; font-family: Verdana;">).
Mechanistic features of LacY have been summarized (</span><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><span style="font-size: 7.5pt; font-family: Verdana;">Kaback 2015</span></span><span style="font-size: 7.5pt; font-family: Verdana;">).</span> Insertion into the membrane depends on YidC (TC# 2.A.9.3.1) and may occur in a stepwise, stochastic manner employing multiple coexisting pathways to complete the folding process (<span id="ref34546905.28627175" class="cite">Serdiuk <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>). The glucose Enzyme IIA (Crr) protein binds LacY to allosterically inhibit its activity, promoting inducer exclusion (<span id="ref34547040.8830713" class="cite">Hoischen <em>et al.</em> 1996</span>; <span id="ref34547039.25675534" class="cite">Hariharan <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>). Protonated LacY binds D-galactopyranosides specifically, inducing an 
occluded state that can open to either side of the membrane (<span id="ref34547431.24453216" class="cite">Kumar <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>). LacY can form amyloid-like fibrils under destabilizing conditions (<span id="ref34547120.28493669" class="cite">Stroobants <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>). Multiple conformations of LacY have been solved (<span id="ref34548899.30108145" class="cite">Kumar <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>).&nbsp; Direct interactions between LacY and its lipid environment uniquely contribute to its membrane protein organization and function (<span id="ref34551428.32363862" class="cite">Vitrac <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). The lactose permease purified from <em>E. coli</em> exhibiting varied phospholipid compositions has the same topology and function as in its membrane of origin (<span id="ref34552514.31383935" class="cite">Vitrac <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>LacY of <em>E. coli</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.5.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.5.2&tcname=">2.A.1.5.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Raffinose:H<sup>+</sup> symporter, RafB, can be mutated to transport maltose (<span id="ref6837.18008022" class="cite">Van Camp <em>et al.</em>, 2007</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>RafB of <em>E. coli</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.5.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.5.3&tcname=">2.A.1.5.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Sucrose:H<sup>+</sup> symporter, CscB, also transports maltose (<span id="ref6493.19294451" class="cite">Peng <em>et al.</em> 2009</span>). CscB recognizes not just sucrose but also fructose and lactulose, but 
glucopyranosides are not transported and do not inhibit sucrose 
transport (<span id="ref34547432.22106930" class="cite">Sugihara <em>et al.</em> 2011</span>). Direct interactions between LacY and its lipid environment uniquely 
contribute to its membrane protein organization and function (<span id="ref34551428.32363862" class="cite">Vitrac <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>CscB of <em>E. coli</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.5.4"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.5.4&tcname=">2.A.1.5.4</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Melibiose:H<sup>+</sup> symporter, MelY (<span id="ref2433.12775706" class="cite">Shinnick <em>et al</em>., 2003</span>). Transports melibiose and lactose, but not TMG, which does however bind to the transporter (<span id="ref5639.18177889" class="cite">Tavoulari and Frillingos, 2008</span>)</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MelY of <em>Enterobacter cloacae</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.5.6"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.5.6&tcname=">2.A.1.5.6</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS transporter specific for fructooligosaccharides, FosT, of 412 aas and 12 TMSs (<span id="ref34550987.18978057" class="cite">Schouler <em>et al.</em> 2009</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>FosT of <em>E. coli</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=2.A.1.50">2.A.1.50 The Proton Coupled Folate Transporter/Heme Carrier Protein (PCFT/HCP) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.50.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.50.1&tcname=">2.A.1.50.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The apical intestinal and choroid plexus proton-coupled, high affinity folate transporter, the hereditary folate malabsorption (HFM) protein, PCFT/HCP1 (<a>Shin <em>et al.</em> 2010</a>).&nbsp; Also reported to mediate heme-iron uptake from the gut lumen with duodenal epithelial cells (<a>Shayeghi <em>et al</em>., 2005</a>; <a>Latunde-Dada <em>et al</em>., 2006</a>; <a>Subramanian <em>et al</em>., 2008</a>, <a>Shin <em>et al.</em>, 2012b</a>), but it shows a higher affinity for folate than heme) (<a>Qiu <em>et al.</em>, 2006</a>). Responsible for folate uptake by choroid plexus epithelial cells (<a>Wollack <em>et al</em>., 2007</a>) and placenta (<a>Yasuda <em>et al</em>., 2008</a>). The rat orthologue (Q5EBA8) catalyzes H<sup>+</sup>-dependent folate uptake in the intestine (<a>Inoue <em>et al</em>., 2008</a>; <a>Zhao and Goldman, 2007</a>; <a>Qiu <em>et al.</em>, 2006</a>; <a>Shin <em>et al.</em>, 2012</a>). Evidence for a 12 TMS topology with a renetrant loop between TMSs 2 and 3 has been presented (<a>Zhao <em>et al.</em>, 2010</a>; <a>Qiu <em>et al.</em>, 2006</a>; <a>Zhao <em>et al.</em>, 2011; <span>Wilson <em>et al.</em> 2014</span></a>).&nbsp; Downregulated in Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) in heart, liver, and brain, causing malabsorption (<a>Bukhari <em>et al.</em>, 2011</a>). An IGXXG motif in TMS5 is important for folate binding and a GXXXG motif is involved in dimerization (<a>Zhao <em>et al.</em>, 2012</a>). It is inhibited by bicarbonate, bisulfite, nitrite and other anions (<a>Zhao <em>et al.</em> 2013</a>).&nbsp; Its role in antifolate cancer chemotherapy has been reviewed (<a>Matherly <em>et al.</em> 2014</a>). TMSs 3
and 6 may provide critical interfaces for formation of hPCFT oligomers, facilitated by
the GXXXG motifs in TMS2 and TMS4 (<span>Wilson <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>).&nbsp; The extracellular gate has been identified (<span>Zhao <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>), and mechanistic aspects have been considered (<span>Date <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>). Residues in the seventh and eighth TMSs play roles in the translocation pathway and folate binding (<span>Aluri <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>). The mutation, N411K-PCFT, is responsible for HFM (<span>Aluri <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). PCFT is ubiquitously expressed in solid tumors to which it delivers antifolates, particularly pemetrexed, into cancer cells in a concentrative fashion (<span>Zhao <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). Substitutions have been identified that lock and unlock PCFT into an inward-open conformation (<span id="ref34549640.30858177" class="cite">Aluri <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>). The nanodisc lipid composition influences the cell-free expression of PCFT (<span id="ref34554124.34793461" class="cite">Do <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>). Iron deficiency promotes hepatocellular carcinoma metastasis, and the loss of SLC46A1 expression leads to iron deficiency in liver tumor tissues (<span id="ref34555076.35811443" class="cite">Wang <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>). Cell-free expression of PCFT in the presence of nanodiscs has been reported (<span id="ref34555103.35773596" class="cite">Do and Jansen 2022</span>). Biological and therapeutic applications of the proton-coupled folate transporter have been reviewed (<span id="ref34555458.36239195" class="cite">Matherly <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SLC46A1 or PCFT of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.50.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.50.2&tcname=">2.A.1.50.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Thymic stromal cotransporter, TSCOT (<span id="ref4013.10706709" class="cite">Kim <em>et al</em>. 2000</span>)</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Animals</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>SLC46A2 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.50.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.50.3&tcname=">2.A.1.50.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC> solute carrier family 46, member 3</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Animals</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>SLC46A3 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.50.4"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.50.4&tcname=">2.A.1.50.4</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Multidrug efflux transporter, MET, of 507 aas and 12 TMSs (<span id="ref34545751.22972675" class="cite">Chahine <em>et al.</em> 2012</span>).&nbsp; Exposure to dietary methotrexate was associated with increased fluid 
secretion rate and increased flux of methotrexate, but not salicylate. 
Exposure to methotrexate in the diet resulted in increases in the 
expression of a <span class="highlight">multidrug</span> <span class="highlight">efflux</span> <span class="highlight">transporter</span> gene (<span class="highlight">MET</span>; CG30344) in the Malpighian tubules. There were also increases in expression of genes for either a <em>Drosophila </em><span class="highlight">multidrug</span> resistance-associated protein (dMRP; CG6214; TC# 3.A.1.208.39) or an organic anion 
transporting polypeptide (OATP; CG3380; TC# 2.A.60.1.27), depending on the concentration 
of methotrexate in the diet.&nbsp; MET probably does not export methotrexate (<span id="ref34545755.22786636" class="cite">Chahine <em>et al.</em> 2012</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MET of <em>Drosophila melanogaster</em> (Fruit fly)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=2.A.1.51">2.A.1.51 The Uncharacterized Major Facilitator-7 (UMF7) Family </A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><p>This family may include aromatic acid porters.</p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.51.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.51.1&tcname=">2.A.1.51.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Putative permease</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Putative transporter of <i>Azoarcus</i> sp. <em>Legionella pneumophila</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.53.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.53.2&tcname=">2.A.1.53.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The valine uptake permease, PhtJ (required for maximal growth in macrophages and <em>Acanthamoeba castellanii</em>) (Chen et al., 2008)</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Gamma proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PhtJ of <em>Legionella pneumophila</em> (YP_095910)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.53.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.53.3&tcname=">2.A.1.53.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The MFSD1 (SMAP4) transporter (465 aas; 12 TMSs).&nbsp; Expression is increased in mice by amino acid starvation and decreased by a high fat diet (<span id="ref34546273.27981419" class="cite">Perland <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>). This lysosomal transporter is essential for liver homeostasis and critically depends on its accessory subunit GLMP (<span id="ref34550408.31661432" class="cite">Massa L&oacute;pez <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>). MFSD1 is not N-glycosylated but contains a dileucine-based sorting motif needed for its transport to lysosomes. Mfsd1 knockout mice develop splenomegaly and severe liver disease. GLMP (406 aas and at least 2 TMSs, N- and C-terminal) physically interacts with MFSD1 and is a critical accessory subunit. GLMP is essential for the maintenance of normal levels of MFSD1 in lysosomes and vice versa. Glmp knockout mice mimic the phenotype of Mfsd1 knockout mice (<span id="ref34550408.31661432" class="cite">Massa L&oacute;pez <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>).&nbsp; The two lysosomal integral membrane proteins MFSD1 and GLMP form a tight complex that confers protection of both interaction partners against lysosomal proteolysis.&nbsp;<span id="ref34552064.32959924" class="cite">L&oacute;pez <em>et al.</em> 2020</span> refined the molecular interaction of the two proteins and found that the luminal domain of GLMP alone, but not its transmembrane domain or its short cytosolic tail, conveys protection and mediates the interaction with MFSD1. The interaction is essential for the stabilization of the complex. N-glycosylation of GLMP is essential for protection. The interaction of both proteins&nbsp;&nbsp; starts in the endoplasmic reticulum, and quantitatively depends on each other. Both proteins can affect their intracellular trafficking to lysosomes. MFSD1 can form homodimers both in vitro and in vivo (<span id="ref34552064.32959924" class="cite">L&oacute;pez <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFSDI/GLMP of <em>Homo sapiens</em> (A6NID9)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.53.4"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.53.4&tcname=">2.A.1.53.4</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Uncharacterized protein of 575 aas and 14 TMSs.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Rhodophyta</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>UP of <em>Cyanidioschyzon merolae</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.53.5"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.53.5&tcname=">2.A.1.53.5</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative amino acid transporter of 478 aas and 12 TMSs, CG8602, isoform A.&nbsp; May play a role in macrophage migration in the <em>Drosophila</em> embryo (Dr. Daria Siekhaus, personal communication).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SG8602A of <em>Drosophila melanogaster</em> (Fruit fly)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.53.6"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.53.6&tcname=">2.A.1.53.6</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS  uptake permease specific for pyrimidines, PhtC of 422 aas and 12 TMSs.&nbsp; Together with PhtD (TC# 2.A.1.53.6), it contributes to protection of <em>L. pneumophila</em> from dTMP starvation, protects the cell from 5-fluorodeoxyuridine (FUdR) toxicity and is required for growth of <em>L. pneumophila</em> in macrophage (<span id="ref34544621.24478086" class="cite">Fonseca <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PhtC of <em>Legionella pneumophila</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.53.7"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.53.7&tcname=">2.A.1.53.7</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS  uptake permease, probably specific for pyrimidines, PhtD of 427 aas and 12 
TMSs.&nbsp; Together with PhtC (TC# 2.A.1.53.6), it contributes to 
protection of <em>L. pneumophila</em> from dTMP starvatioin, protects the cell from 5-fluorodeoxyuridine (FUdR) toxicity and is required for growth of <em>L. pneumophila</em> in macrophage (<span id="ref34544621.24478086" class="cite">Fonseca <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PhtD of<em> Legionella pneumophila</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.53.8"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.53.8&tcname=">2.A.1.53.8</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PhtB of 431 aas</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PhtB of <em>Legionella pneumophila</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.53.9"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.53.9&tcname=">2.A.1.53.9</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PhtE of 430 aas</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PhtE of <em>Legionella pneumophila</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=2.A.1.54">2.A.1.54 The Uncharacterized Major Facilitator-9 (UMF9) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><p>The proteins of this family are related to 2.A.1.54; amino acid/nucleobase porters. valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=2.A.1.57">2.A.1.57 The Ferripyochelin Transporter (FptX) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.57.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.57.1&tcname=">2.A.1.57.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p><a id="2.A.1.25.6"></a></p>
<p><a></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p><a id="2.A.1.25.6"></a></p>
<p><a></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p>The Ferripyochelin uptake permease, FptX (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref5491">Michel <em>et al</em>., 2007</a>).&nbsp; Also transports N-acetylglucosamine anhydrous N-acetylmuramyl peptides and is called AmpP or AmpGh1 (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref8919">Kong <em>et al.</em> 2010</a>).&nbsp; However, it does not play a role in the induction of &beta;-lactam resistance (<span id="ref9157.20713660" class="cite">Zhang <em>et al.</em> 2010</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>FptX or AmpP of <em>Pseudomonas aeruginosa</em> (Q9HWG8)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.57.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.57.2&tcname=">2.A.1.57.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The ferric rhizbactin 1021 uptake porter, RhtX (<span id="ref10093.15126460" class="cite">Cu&iacute;v <em>et al.</em> 2004</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>RhtX of<em> Sinorhizobium meliloti</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.57.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.57.3&tcname=">2.A.1.57.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Iron-yersiniabactin (Ybt) transporter of 467 aas and 12 TMSs, YbtX (<span id="ref34549037.24979062" class="cite">Bobrov <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>). Yersiniabactin can also bind zinc ions with high affinity and feed the Zn<sup>2+</sup> into this MFS transporter, YbtX (<span id="ref34549037.24979062" class="cite">Bobrov <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>). In fact, the siderophore, Ybt, is required for growth under Zn<sup>2+</sup>-deficient conditions in a strain lacking ZnuABC (see 3.A.1.15.5 for the <em>E. coli </em>ortholog). This MFS porter is similar to the Irp8 piscibactin secretion porter of <em>Vibrio anguillarum</em> (<span id="ref34555240.36012135" class="cite">Lages <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>YbtX of&nbsp;<em>Yersinia pestis</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.57.4"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.57.4&tcname=">2.A.1.57.4</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Siderophore transporter, RhtX/FptX family</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Siderophore transporter of <em>Myxococcus xanthus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.57.5"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.57.5&tcname=">2.A.1.57.5</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The iron (Fe<sup>3+</sup>)&middot;pyridine-2,6-bis(thiocarboxylic acid (PDTC)) uptake transporter, PdtE.  Functions with the OMR, PdtK, 1.B.14.8.2 (most similar to 2.A.1.57.4) (<span id="ref3851.17005994" class="cite">Leach and Lewis 2006</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PdtE of <em>Pseudomonas putida</em> (ABC8353)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.57.6"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.57.6&tcname=">2.A.1.57.6</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Major facilitator superfamily domain-containing protein 3, MFSD3. Function unknown. The human ortholog has Uniprotein acc # of Q96ES6 with 412 aas and 12 TMSs.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Mfsd3 of <em>Rattus norvegicus </em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=2.A.1.58">2.A.1.58 The N-Acetylglucosamine Transporter (NAG-T) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.58.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.58.1&tcname=">2.A.1.58.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The N-acetylglucosamine:H<sup>+</sup> symporter, Ngt1 (<span id="ref4101.17192409" class="cite">Alvarez and Konopka, 2007</span>)</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Yeast</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Ngt1 of <em>Candida albicans</em> (Q5A7S4)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.58.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.58.2&tcname=">2.A.1.58.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>May contribute to coordination of muscle contraction as regulatory subunit of a nonessential potassium channel complex.&nbsp; Subunit structure:&nbsp; May form a complex with sup-9 and sup-10 where unc-93 and sup-10 act as regulatory subunits of the two pore potassium channel sup-9.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Unc-93 of <em>Caenorhabditis elegans</em> (Q93380)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.58.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.58.3&tcname=">2.A.1.58.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>UNC93-like protein MFSD11 (Major facilitator superfamily domain-containing protein 11; Protein ET) of 449 aas and 12 TMSs It seems to be involved in intracellular transport in mammals and has been suggested to be a sugar:H<sup>+</sup> symporter (<span id="ref34548805.30265558" class="cite">Zhang <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). It is expressed in testis, small intestine, spleen, prostate, and ovary, and mutations can give rise to ovarian cancer (<span id="ref34551560.12381271" class="cite">Liu <em>et al.</em> 2002</span>).<span style="font-weight: normal;"> Mfsd11 is abundantly expressed in the mouse brain and plays a potential role in energy homeostasis (<span id="ref34551539.27272503" class="cite">Perland <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>).</span> Its transcript is highly enriched in <em>Aedes aegypti</em> during arbovirus infection (<span id="ref34551561.21496127" class="cite">Campbell <em>et al.</em> 2011</span>). UNC93A and SV2 (TC# 2.A.1.22.1) may play a role in virus assembly or budding (<span id="ref34551561.21496127" class="cite">Campbell <em>et al.</em> 2011</span>). TMEM132C, UNC93A and TTLL2 (the latter two genes being adjacent) are associated with pulmonary function (<span id="ref34551562.26430897" class="cite">Son <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>). It may be involved in psoriasis, a common chronic autoimmune inflammatory skin disease (<span id="ref34551563.32125527" class="cite">Li <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFSD11 of <em>Mus musculus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.58.4"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.58.4&tcname=">2.A.1.58.4</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS permease of 467 aas</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Plants</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS permease of <em>Oryza sativa</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.58.5"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.58.5&tcname=">2.A.1.58.5</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Duf895 protein of 450 aas</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Fungi</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Duf895 protein of<em> Verticillium albo-atrum</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.58.6"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.58.6&tcname=">2.A.1.58.6</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS permease of 425 aas</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Slime molds</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS permease of <em>Dictyostellium discoideum</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.58.7"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.58.7&tcname=">2.A.1.58.7</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Unc-93 family homologue B1, Unc-93b1 or Unc93b1, of 597 aas and 12 TMSs, <span>plays
 a role in innate and adaptive immunity by regulating 
nucleotide-sensing Toll-like receptor (TLR) signaling (<span id="ref34551558.25187660" class="cite">Pelka <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>). It is required for the 
transport of a subset of TLRs (including TLR3, TLR7 and TLR9) from the 
endoplasmic reticulum to endolysosomes where they can engage pathogen 
nucleotides (e.g., of viral nucleic acids) and activate signaling cascades. Unc93B1 may play a role in 
autoreactive B-cells removal (<span id="ref34545441.19006693" class="cite">Isnardi <em>et al.</em> 2008</span>).&nbsp; It induces apoptotic cell death and is cleaved by host and viral proteases (<span id="ref34545442.26509685" class="cite">Harris and Coyne 2015</span>). </span>UNC93B1 may play a role in human oral squamous cell carcinomas growth by controlling the secretion of granulocyte macrophage colony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF) (<span id="ref34551213.30935694" class="cite">Wagai <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>). UNC93B1 regulates Toll-like receptor stability independently of endosomal TLR transport (<span id="ref34551559.29768176" class="cite">Pelka <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). A missense variant affecting the C-terminal tail of UNC93B1 in dogs is responsible for a Exfoliative Cutaneous Lupus Erythematosus (ECLE) condition (<span id="ref34552308.32028618" class="cite">Leeb <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>).  Compartmentalization of TLRs in the endosome limits their activation by self-derived nucleic acids and reduces the possibility of autoimmune reactions. UNC93B1 is indispensable for the trafficking of TLRs from the endoplasmic reticulum to the endosome.&nbsp;<span id="ref34552910.33432245" class="cite">Ishida <em>et al.</em> 2021</span> reported two cryo-EM structures of human and mouse TLR3-UNC93B1 complexes and a human TLR7-UNC93B1 complex. UNC93B1 exhibits structural similarity to other MFS porters. Both TLRs interact with the UNC93B1 amino-terminal six-helix bundle through their transmembrane and luminal juxtamembrane regions, but the complexes of TLR3 and TLR7 with UNC93B1 differ in their oligomerization state (<span id="ref34552910.33432245" class="cite">Ishida <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>). The mammalian trafficking chaperone protein UNC93B1 maintains the ER calcium sensor STIM1 in a dimeric state primed for translocation to the ER cortex (<span id="ref34554665.35065962" class="cite">Wang and Demaurex 2022</span>).</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Unc93b1 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.58.8"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.58.8&tcname=">2.A.1.58.8</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS permease of 418 aas and 12 TMSs.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS permease of <em>Entamoeba histolytica</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.58.9"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.58.9&tcname=">2.A.1.58.9</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Unc93A of 457 aas and 12 TMSs.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Unc93A of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=2.A.1.59">2.A.1.59 The Uncharacterized Major Facilitator-10 (UMF10) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><p>These porters are mostly from Archaea but some are from bacteria; they are closely related to 2.A.1.46, possible drug exporters.</p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.59.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.59.1&tcname=">2.A.1.59.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>UMF10a of unknown function, (COG2270).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Archaea</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>UMF10a of <em>Methanococcus aeolicus</em> (A6UVW2)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.59.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.59.2&tcname=">2.A.1.59.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p>

<p><!-- test--></p>
<p>UMF10b of <em>Nostoc punctiforme</em> (B2JBG5)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A permease, LepA</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>LepA of <em>Hydrogenivirga</em> sp.128-5-R1-1 (A8UT57)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.59.5"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.59.5&tcname=">2.A.1.59.5</a></TD><TD><b><font valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=2.A.1.6">2.A.1.6 The Metabolite:H<sup>+</sup> Symporter (MHS) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.6.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.6.1&tcname=">2.A.1.6.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Citrate:H<sup>+</sup> symporter</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>CitA of <i>Klebsiella pneumoniae</i> </TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.6.10"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.6.10&tcname=">2.A.1.6.10</a></TD><TD><b><font      
																																																																	                                     Inner membrane metabolite transport protein YhjE</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>YhjE of <em>Escherichia coli </em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.6.11"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.6.11&tcname=">2.A.1.6.11</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p><a id="2.A.1.6.11"></a></p>
<p><a></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p><a id="2.A.1.6.11"></a></p>
<p>Acetate/haloacid transporter, Dehp2, with a possible atypical topology (<span id="ref10753.19878597" class="cite">Tse <em>et al.</em> 2009</span>).&nbsp; Transports acetate, chloroacetate, bromoacetate, 2-chloropropionate, and possibly, with low affinity, glycolate, lactate and pyruvate (based on weak inhibition results).&nbsp; Inducible by chloroacetate (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref9109">Su and Tsang 2012</a>).&nbsp; This protein is 79% identical to its paralogue, Deh4p (TC# 2.A.1.6.8) which differs in that it shows lower apparent affinity for 2-chloropropionate.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Dehp2 of <em>Burkholderia</em> <em>caribensis</em> (formerly sp. MBA4)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.6.12"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.6.12&tcname=">2.A.1.6.12</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The putative thiazole transporter, ThiU. Regulatyed by TPP riboswitch (<span id="ref9348.12376536" class="cite">Rodionov <em>et al.</em> 2002</span>)</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Pasteurellales</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ThiU of Haemophilus influenzae (P44699)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.6.13"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.6.13&tcname=">2.A.1.6.13</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><span class="recommended-name">Acetate/monochloroacetate permease, Deh4p, of 468 aas and 12 TMSs.&nbsp; Transports various carboxylates.&nbsp; </span><span class="recommended-name"><em>Dehalococcoides mccartyi </em>degrades haloacids (<span id="ref34546077.27668346" class="cite">Su <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>).</span></p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Deh4p of <em>Dehalococcoides mccartyi </em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.6.14"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.6.14&tcname=">2.A.1.6.14</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proline/glycine betaine uptake transporter, ProP, of 466 aas and 12 TMSs. It is not the major proline transporter found in <em>S. aureus</em> (<span id="ref34555844.36652494" class="cite">Lehman <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ProP of <em>Staphylococcus aureus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.6.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.6.2&tcname=">2.A.1.6.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>&alpha;-Ketoglutarate (oxoglutarate):H<sup>+</sup> symporter (<span id="ref11182.1554735" class="cite">Seol and Shatkin 1992; <span id="ref11183.1556144" class="cite">Seol and Shatkin 1992</span></span>).&nbsp; May also export arabinose but not xylose (<span id="ref11179.22952739" class="cite">Koita and Rao 2012</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>KgtP of <em>E. coli</em> (P0AEX3)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.6.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.6.3&tcname=">2.A.1.6.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Dicarboxylate:H<sup>+</sup> symporter.&nbsp; Transports and serves as a chemoreceptor for &beta;-ketoadipate (<span id="ref34544821.7320700" class="cite">Karimian and Ornston 1981</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PcaT of <em>Pseudomonas putida</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.6.4"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.6.4&tcname=">2.A.1.6.4</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>(Proline/glycine-betaine):(H<sup>+</sup>/Na<sup>+</sup>) symporter, ProP (also transports taurine, ectoine, pipecolate, proline-betaine, N,N-dimethylglycine, carnitine, and 1-carboxymethyl-pyridinium) (subject to osmotic activation). Transmembrane helix I and periplasmic loop 1 are involved in osmosensing and osmoprotectant transport (<span id="ref7246.20828170" class="cite">Keates <em>et al.</em>, 2010</span>).  ProP detects the increase in cytoplasmic cation concentration associated with osmotically induced cell dehydration and mediates osmolyte uptake into bacteria (<span id="ref34552059.32838524" class="cite">Ozturk <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). ProP is a 12-TMS protein with an &alpha;-helical, cytoplasmic C-terminal domain (CTD) linked to TMS XII. The CTD helix associates with the anionic membrane surface to lock ProP in an inactive conformation. The release of the CTD may activate ProP. Molecular dynamics simulations showed specific intrapeptide salt bridges forming when the CTD associated with the membrane. The salt bridge Lys447-Asp455 weakened CTD-lipid interactions at 0.25 M KCl, and gradual stiffening of the membrane with increasing salinity was obseerved. Thus, salt cations may affect CTD release and activate ProP by increasing the order of membrane phospholipids (<span id="ref34552059.32838524" class="cite">Ozturk <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>).  ProP forestalls cellular dehydration by detecting environments with high osmotic pressure and mediating the accumulation of organic osmolytes by bacterial cells. Structural determinants and functional significance of dimerization have been described (<span id="ref34555848.36516499" class="cite">Ozturk <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ProP of <em>E. coli</em> (P0C0L7)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.6.5"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.6.5&tcname=">2.A.1.6.5</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>4-Methyl-<I>o</i>-phthalate:H<sup>+</sup> symporter</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>MopB of <i>Burkholderia cepacia</i> </TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.6.6"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.6.6&tcname=">2.A.1.6.6</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Shikimate:H<sup>+</sup> symporter</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>ShiA of <i>E. coli</i></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.6.7"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.6.7&tcname=">2.A.1.6.7</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>The citrate/tricarballylate:H<sup>+</sup> symporter (CitA or TcuC); probably orthologous to 2.A.1.6.1 (<span id="ref3734.14996793" class="cite">Lewis <em>et al</em>., 2004</span>)</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>TcuC of <i>Salmonella enterica</i> serovar Typhimurium LT2 (P0A2G3)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.6.8"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.6.8&tcname=">2.A.1.6.8</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The acetate/monochloroacetate (haloacid) permease, Deh4p (Km = 5.5 m&mu;M for acetate; 9 m&mu;M for monochloroacetate) (<span id="ref5554.17545323" class="cite">Yu <em>et al</em>., 2007</span>; <span id="ref9109.23022134" class="cite">Su and Tsang 2012</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Deh4 of <em>Burkholderia cepacia</em> or sp. MBA4 (Q7X4L6)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.6.9"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.6.9&tcname=">2.A.1.6.9</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>YdfJ. Can function as an inward rectifying K<sup>+</sup> channel when expressed in animal cells as measured by whole cell patch clamping. Blocked by barium and protopine (<span id="ref7863.21744086" class="cite">Tang <em>et al.</em>, 2011</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>YdfJ of <em>E. coli</em> (P77228)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD Overexpression causes an increased lifespan by 17%. 2000</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>TgsA of<em> E. coli</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.7.15"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.7.15&tcname=">2.A.1.7.15</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Major facilitator superfamily domain-containing protein 4-A, MFSD4A, of 526 aas and 12 TMSs.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MfsD4a of <em>Danio rerio </em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.7.16"></A><A Regulated by heparin utilization regulon.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteroidetes</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>NagP (Q89YS8) of Bacteroides thetaiotaomicron</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.7.19"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.7.19&tcname=">2.A.1.7.19</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Probable glucose transporter encoded by a gene sandwiched in between two genes encoding a glucose 1-dehydrogenase and a gluconolactonase.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Chlamydiae</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Glucose permease of <em>Parachlamydia acanthamoebae</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.7.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.7.2&tcname=">2.A.1.7.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Glucose/galactose porter</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Ggp of <i>Brucella abortus</I> (P0C105)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.7.20"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.7.20&tcname=">2.A.1.7.20</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Uncharacterized MFS protein of 392 aas and 12 TMSs.</p></TD><TD><b><font bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.7.21"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.7.21&tcname=">2.A.1.7.21</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Uncharacterized protein of the MFS of 505 aas and 12 TMSs</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>UP of <em>Chlamydomonas reinhardtii (Chlamydomonas smithii)</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.7.22"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.7.22&tcname=">2.A.1.7.22</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Uncharacterized protein of 494 aas and 12 TMSs.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>UP of <em>Chlamydomonas reinhardtii (Chlamydomonas smithii)</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.7.23"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.7.23&tcname=">2.A.1.7.23</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Na+-dependent glucose transporter 1, Mfsd4b, of 491 aas and 12&nbsp; TMSs.&nbsp; May also serve as a <span> channels for urea in the inner medulla of the kidney.</span></p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Mfsd4b of <em>Xenopus laevis</em> (African clawed frog)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.7.24"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.7.24&tcname=">2.A.1.7.24</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS porter, MFSD4a or SLC60A1, of 514 aas and 12 TMSs. In the mouse, this protein and MFSD9 localize to neurons in the 
brain, and their mRNA expression levels are affected by diet (<a class="reflink" href="http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref34547464">Perland <em>et al.</em> 2017</a>). They are associated with cancer and have anti-tumor activities (<span id="ref34555012.35410462" class="cite">Yang <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>). It may play a role in the excretion of nitrogen metabolites (<span id="ref34555013.34335696" class="cite">Honerlagen <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFSD4a of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.7.25"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.7.25&tcname=">2.A.1.7.25</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Uncharacterized protein of 894 aas and 19 TMSs in a 7 + 12 TMS arrangement.&nbsp; The first 7 TMSs comprise a CFEM domain, while the last 12 TMSs are homologous to MFS porters. There are many such proteins in the NCBI database, most from fungi.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>UP of<em> Leptosphaeria maculans</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.7.26"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.7.26&tcname=">2.A.1.7.26</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Na<sup>+</sup>:glucose co-transporter of 672 aas and about 14 TMSs, SGLT2. <span>It has a Na<sup>+</sup> to glucose coupling ratio of 1:1 (<span id="ref34551535.31081592" class="cite">Brown <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>).</span> <span>Efficient substrate transport in the mammalian kidney 
is provided by the concerted action of a low affinity high capacity and a
 high affinity low capacity Na<sup>+</sup>/glucose cotransporter arranged in series along kidney proximal tubules.</span> Inhibitors are antidiabetic agents (<span id="ref34551532.31942549" class="cite">Li 2019</span>; <span id="ref34551533.32470852" class="cite">Singh and Singh 2020</span>). They are also useful as theraputic agents of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease and chronic kidney disease (<span id="ref34551534.32440840" class="cite">Kanbay <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). Marein, an active component of the <em>Coreopsis tinctoria</em> Nutt plant, ameliorates diabetic nephropathy by inhibiting renal sodium glucose transporter 2 and activating the AMPK signaling pathway (<span id="ref34552290.33152903" class="cite">Guo <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). NHE-3 (TC# 2.A.53.2.18) was markedly downregulated, while the Na<sup>+</sup>-HCO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup>-cotransporter (NBC-1; TC# 2.A.31.2.12) and SGLT2 were upregulated after kidney transplantation (<span id="ref34552753.15034099" class="cite">Velic <em>et al.</em> 2004</span>).  Pharmacological inhibition of hSGLT2 by oral small-molecule inhibitors, such as empagliflozin, leads to enhanced excretion of glucose and is widely used in the clinic to manage blood glucose levels for the treatment of type 2 diabetes.&nbsp;<span id="ref34554081.34880493" class="cite">Niu <em>et al.</em> 2021</span> determined the cryogenic electron microscopic structure of the hSGLT2-MAP17 complex in the empagliflozin-bound state to a resolution of 2.95 &Aring;. MAP17 interacts with transmembrane helix 13 of hSGLT2. Empagliflozin occupies both the sugar-substrate-binding site and the external vestibule to lock hSGLT2 in an outward-open conformation, thus inhibiting the transport cycle (<span id="ref34554081.34880493" class="cite">Niu <em>et al.</em> 2021)</span>. There is no upregulation regarding host factors potentially promoting 
SARS-CoV-2 virus entry into host cells when the SGLT2-blocker 
empagliflozin, telmisartan and the DPP4-inhibitor blocker, linagliptin, 
are used (<span id="ref34554692.35331159" class="cite">Xiong <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>). Canagliflozin, dapagliflozin and ipragliflozin significantly inhibit the growth of different cancer cell lines in the micromolar range; SGLT2 inhibitors have antiproliferation, anti-tumorigenesis, and 
anti-migration effects and may induce apoptosis in cancer cells. Treatment with SGLT2 inhibitors also results in the downregulation
 of selected genes (<span id="ref34555131.35977549" class="cite">Bardaweel and Issa 2022</span>). SGLT2 inhibitor treatment results in symptomatic and functional 
well-being, especially in relieving pain (<span id="ref34555136.36017978" class="cite">Calderon-Rivera <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>). Effects of SGLT2 inhibitors affect the heart and kidney to promote autophagic flux, nutrient deprivation signaling and transmembrane sodium transport (<span id="ref34555176.36017745" class="cite">Zannad <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>). Empagliflozin (EMPA), mainly acting on SGLT2, prevented DNA methylation changes induced 
by high glucose and provided evidence of a new mechanism by which SGLT2i
 can exert cardio-beneficial effects (<span id="ref34555928.36732760" class="cite">Scisciola <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). A diversifiable synthetic platform for the discovery of new carbasugar SGLT2 inhibitors using azide-alkyne click chemistry has been described (<span id="ref34556020.36858530" class="cite">Kitamura <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). SGLT2 is inhibited by empagliflozin (<span id="ref34556195.36990488" class="cite">Raven <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). SGLT2 inhibitors not only suppress hyperglycemia but also reduce renal, heart, and cardiovascular diseases (<span id="ref34556295.37047250" class="cite">Unno <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). In fact, SGLT2 may also be related to other functions, such as bone metabolism, longevity, and cognitive functions based on mouse models (<span id="ref34556295.37047250" class="cite">Unno <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). Complex effects of different SGLT2 inhibitors on alphaKlotho gene expression (see TC family 8.A.49) and protein secretion in renal MDCK and HK-2 cells have been observed (<span id="ref34556323.36967770" class="cite">Wolf <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). Ferulic acid-grafted chitosan (FA-g-CS) stimulates the transmembrane transport of anthocyanins by SGLT1 and GLUT2 (<span id="ref34556916.37431047" class="cite">Ma <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>). SGLT2 Inhibitors are potential anticancer agents (<span id="ref34556957.37509506" class="cite">Basak <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). <span style="font-weight: normal;">Analyses of the effects of SGLT2 inhibitors on renal tubular sodium, water and chloride homeostasis as well as their roles in influencing heart failure outcomes has appeared (<span id="ref34556966.37486998" class="cite">Packer <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).&nbsp; The </span>SGLT2 inhibitor, empagliflozin, alleviates cardiac remodeling and contractile anomalies in a FUNDC1-dependent manner in experimental Parkinson's disease (<span id="ref34557224.37679644" class="cite">Yu <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). Type 2 diabetes guidance proposes offering SGLT2-inhibitor therapy to 
people with established atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) 
or heart failure, but this suggestion has been questioned (<span id="ref34557512.37919773" class="cite">Young <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). SGLT2 inhibition in a non-diabetic rat model of salt-sensitive hypertension 
blunts the development of salt-induced hypertension independent of sex (<span id="ref34557516.37932290" class="cite">Kravtsova <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>GLUT2 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.7.27"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.7.27&tcname=">2.A.1.7.27</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Na<sup>+</sup>/Glucose co-transporter, SGLT1, SLC60A2 or MfsD4B, of 518 aas and 12 TMSs (<span id="ref34551557.28878041" class="cite">Perland <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MfsD4B of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.7.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.7.3&tcname=">2.A.1.7.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Glucose/Mannose/Xylose: H<sup>+</sup> symporter (<span id="ref2513.9457850" class="cite">Paulsen <em>et al.</em>, 1998</span>; G.Gosset, personal communication).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>GlcP of <em>Bacillus subtilis</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.7.4"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.7.4&tcname=">2.A.1.7.4</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Rat kidney Na<sup>+</sup>-dependent glucose (methyl &alpha;-glucoside) transporter, NaGLT1 or SGLT1 (glucose:Na<sup>+</sup>:Na<sup>+</sup>=1:1) (<span id="ref2512.12590146" class="cite">Horiba <em>et al</em>., 2003</span>). Position 170 of Rabbit Na<sup>+</sup>/glucose cotransporter (rSGLT1) lies in the Na<sup>+</sup> pathway, and modulation of polarity/charge at this site regulates charge transfer and carrier turnover (<span id="ref34551528.15240465" class="cite">Huntley <em>et al.</em> 2004</span>). The fine-tuning of glucose uptake mechanisms is rendered by various 
glucose transporters with distinct transport characteristics. In the 
pancreatic islet, facilitative diffusion glucose transporters (GLUTs), 
and sodium-glucose cotransporters (SGLTs) contribute to glucose uptake 
and represent important components in the glucose-stimulated hormone 
release from endocrine cells, therefore playing a crucial role in blood 
glucose homeostasis (<span id="ref34551529.32394191" class="cite">Berger and Zdzieblo 2020</span>). SGLT1 and SGLT2 are therapeutic targets for various diseases (<span id="ref34551530.32196987" class="cite">Sano <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>), and function in glucose absorption in the small intestine (<span id="ref34551531.32144488" class="cite">Vallon 2020</span>). This glucose:Na<sup>+</sup> symporter can transport the drug gastrodin, a seditive with a strcture of a phenolic glucoside (<span id="ref34556541.37254285" class="cite">Huang <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>NaGLT1 of <em>Rattus norvegicus</em> (BAC57446)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.7.5"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.7.5&tcname=">2.A.1.7.5</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>2-Deoxy-D-ribose porter, DeoP (<span id="ref2593.14526015" class="cite">Christensen <em>et al</em>., 2003</span>).&nbsp; Plays a role in colonization of the mouse intestine (<span id="ref10075.19168744" class="cite">Martinez-J&eacute;hanne <em>et al.</em> 2009</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>DeoP of <em>Salmonella typhimurium</em> LT-2 (gi 16767076)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.7.6"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.7.6&tcname=">2.A.1.7.6</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Sucrose permease, ScrT (<span id="ref9370.20836887" class="cite">Rodionov <em>et al.</em>, 2010</span>)</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ScrT of <em>Shewanella frigidimarina</em> (ABI73814)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.7.7"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.7.7&tcname=">2.A.1.7.7</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>The Na<sup>+</sup>-dependent sugar transporter, HP1174 (transports glucose, galactose, mannose and 2-deoxyglucose (<span id="ref6415.19161491" class="cite">Psakis <em>et al.</em> 2009</span>)). (most similar to 2.A.1.7.2; 49% identity)<br /</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>HP1174 of <em>Helicobacter pylori </em>(O25788)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.7.8"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.7.8&tcname=">2.A.1.7.8</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>N-acetylglucosamine porter, NagP (<span id="ref9370.20836887" class="cite">Rodionov <em>et al.</em> 2010</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>NagP of <em>Shewanella oneidensis</em> (Q8EBL0)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.7.9"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.7.9&tcname=">2.A.1.7.9</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The putative N-acetylgalactosamine porter, AgaP (<span id="ref9371.22711537" class="cite">Leyn <em>et al.</em> 2012</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>AgaP of <em>Shewanella amazonensis</em> (A1S4V0)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=2.A.1.70">2.A.1.70 The Arsenite/Antimonite Exporter (ArsK) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><p>One member of this family (2.A.1.70.9) has been characterized as an arsenite/antimonite exporter (<span id='ref34549479.30315082' class='cite'>Shi <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>).</p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.70.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.70.1&tcname=">2.A.1.70.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>UMF18A,&nbsp; May be a monocarboxylate uptake transporter based on its sequence similarity with families 2.A.1.11 and 2.A.1.13.&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>UMF18A of <em>Streptomyces coelicolor</em>&nbsp;(Q9L223)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.70.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.70.2&tcname=">2.A.1.70.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>UMF18B&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.70.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.70.3&tcname=">2.A.1.70.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>UMF18C</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>UMF18C of <em>Salinispora tropica</em>&nbsp;(A4X2L1)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" color=#3333CC><p>Uncharacterized MFS porter of 401 aas and 12 TMSs.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>UP of <em>Dehalococcoidia bacterium</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.70.8"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.70.8&tcname=">2.A.1.70.8</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Uncharacterized MFS porter of 397 aas and 12 TMSs, annotated in Uniprot as ArsP.&nbsp; The encoding gene is next to genes encoding ArsH (Q1LRL2), an NADPH-dependent FMN reductase, ArsC1, an arsenate reductase (Q1LRL1) and an arsenite efflux pump, ArsB or Acr3 of 10 TMSs (ArsB; Q1LRL0; ACR family, TC# 2.A.59). This MFS family shows greatest similarity with families 2.A.1.11 and 2.A.1.13, both which transport anionic speices, for example, oxalate, formate and pyruvate (TC# 2.A.1.11) and monocarboxylates (TC# 2.A.1.13).&nbsp; It is 32% identical and 52% similar to ArsK (TC# 2.A.1.70.9) which is an arsenite/antimonite exporter (<span id="ref34549479.30315082" class="cite">Shi <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ArsP of <em>Cupriavidus metallidurans (Ralstonia metallidurans)</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.70.9"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.70.9&tcname=">2.A.1.70.9</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ArsK, exporter of arsenite, antimonite, trivalent roxarsone and methylarsenite (<span id="ref34549479.30315082" class="cite">Shi <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). Expression of <em>arsK</em> is induced by arsenite [As(III)], antimonite 
[Sb(III)], trivalent roxarsone [Rox(III)], methylarsenite [MAs(III)] and
 arsenate [As(V)], and heterologous expression of ArsK in an 
arsenic-hypersensitive <em>E. coli</em> strain showed that ArsK is 
essential for resistance to As(III), Sb(III), Rox(III) and MAs(III) but 
not to As(V), dimethylarsenite [Dimethyl-As(III)] or Cd(II). ArsK 
reduces the cellular accumulation of As(III), Sb(III), Rox(III) and 
MAs(III) but not to As(V) or Dimethyl-As(III). An arsenic 
regulator gene <em>arsR2</em> is cotranscribed with <em>arsK</em>, and ArsR2 interacts with the <em>arsR2-arsK</em> promoter region without metalloids but is derepressed by As(III), 
Sb(III), Rox(III) and MAs(III)<em>.</em> Thus, ArsK is an arsenic efflux protein&nbsp; and is regulated by ArsR2 (<span id="ref34549479.30315082" class="cite">Shi <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>).</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ArsK of<em> Rhizobium radiobacter (Agrobacterium tumefaciens; Agrobacterium radiobacter)</em></p>
