HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.75.1&tcname=">2.A.1.75.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Probable transporter MCH1.&nbsp; Although the name, "monocarboxylate transporter homologue 1" implies that this system transports monocarboxylates such as lactate, pyruvate and acetate, no evidence for this possibility was obtained (<span id="ref34547416.11536335" class="cite">Makuc <em>et al.</em> 2001</span>). Instead, the <em><span class="highlight">mch1</span>-5 </em> mutant strain, lacking all 5 such paralogues in yeast showed strongly reduced biomass yields in aerobic 
glucose-limited chemostat cultures, pointing to the involvement of Mch 
transporters in mitochondrial metabolism. Indeed, intracellular 
localization studies indicated that at least some of the Mch proteins 
reside in intracellular membranes.Thus, the yeast monocarboxylate transporter-homologs perform other functions other  than do their mammalian counterparts (<span id="ref34547416.11536335" class="cite">Makuc <em>et al.</em> 2001</span>). Possibly they function in intracellular, organellar transport of these acids.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Fungi</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MCH1 of <em>Saccharomyces cerevisiae COLSPAN=5><p><p>Most closely related to TC# 2.A.1.15, transporters for organic carboxylates.</p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR Facilitator-27 (UMF27) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><p>Most similar to TC#2.A.1.11 (carboxylate transporters) and 2.A.1.55 (MDR pumps).</p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.79.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.79.1&tcname=">2.A.1.79.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS permease of 485 aas</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Rhodophyta</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS permease of <em>Cyanidioschyzon merolae</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.79.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.79.2&tcname=">2.A.1.79.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Uncharacterized MFS proter of 724 aas and 12 TMSs with a C-terminal hydrophilic extension.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>UP of <em>Chondrus crispus</em> (Carrageen Irish moss)<em> (Polymorpha crispa)</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=2.A.1.8">2.A.1.8 The Nitrate/Nitrite Porter (NNP) family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.8.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.8.1&tcname=">2.A.1.8.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Nitrate/H<sup>+</sup> symporter (K1);Nitrate/nitrite antiporter (K2).&nbsp; The 3-d structure is available revealing a positively charged pathway for nitrate/nitrite lined with arginine residues with no apparent proton pathway suggesting exchange transport is the primary or sole mechanism.&nbsp; The pathway is between the two halves of the protein and a rocker switch mechanism was proposed (<span id="ref10088.23665960" class="cite">Zheng <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>).&nbsp; In an in vitro reconstituted system, NarK appeared to be a nitrate/nitrite
antiporter.&nbsp; High-resolution
crystal structures in the nitrate-bound occluded, nitrate-bound
inward-open and apo inward-open states have been solved (<span id="ref34545466.25959928" class="cite">Fukuda <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>NarK (NarK1-K2) of <em>E. coli</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.8.10"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.8.10&tcname=">2.A.1.8.10</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>NO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup>/NO<sub>2</sub><sup>-</sup> transporter (NO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup> uptake permease;  NO<sub>2</sub><sup>-</sup> exporter) (probable NO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup>/NO<sub>2</sub><sup>-</sup> antiporter) (stress-induced; <span id="ref3421.16804183" class="cite">Clegg <em>et al</em>., 2006</span>; <span id="ref10721.18691156" class="cite">Jia <em>et al.</em> 2009</span>)</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>NarU of <em>E. coli</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.8.11"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.8.11&tcname=">2.A.1.8.11</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The 24 TMS, 2 domain, NarK1-NarK2 porter (NarK1 = a NO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup>/H<sup>+</sup> symporter; NarK2 = a NO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup>/NO<sub>2</sub><sup>-</sup> antiporter).&nbsp; NarK1 is a nitrate/proton symporter with high affinity for nitrate while NarK2 is a nitrate/nitrite antiporter with lower affinity for nitrate (<span id="ref6374.18823285" class="cite">Goddard <em>et al.</em>, 2008</span>).&nbsp; Each transporter requires two conserved arginine residues for activity.&nbsp; A transporter consisting of inactivated NarK1 fused to active NarK2 has a dramatically increased affinity for nitrate compared with NarK2 alone, implying a functional interaction between the two domains (<span id="ref6374.18823285" class="cite">Goddard <em>et al.</em>, 2008</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>NarK1/NarK2 of <em>Roseobacter denitrificans </em>(Q166T6)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.8.12"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.8.12&tcname=">2.A.1.8.12</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The root cortical and epidermal cell, high affinity, plasma membrane, NO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup> uptake transporter, NRT2.1 (<span id="ref4220.17573350" class="cite">Wirth <em>et al</em>., 2007</span>).  Also functions in nitrate sensing and signaling (<span id="ref4995.17519352" class="cite">Miller <em>et al</em>., 2007</span>; <span id="ref7095.20448103" class="cite">Girin <em>et al.</em>, 2010</span>). Activity only occurs when NRT2.1 is complexed with NAR2.1 (WR3; 8.A.20.1.1) in a 2:2 tetrameric complex (<span id="ref7336.20561257" class="cite">Yong <em>et al.</em>, 2010</span>). NAR2.1 has an N-terminal and a C-terminal TMS and has been annotated as a calcineurin-like phosphoesterase family member (<span id="ref7336.20561257" class="cite">Yong <em>et al.</em>, 2010</span>).&nbsp; Ntr transporters may also play a role in gaseous NO<sub>2</sub> uptake by leaves (<span id="ref34543562.25126090" class="cite">Hu <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>).&nbsp; The <em>Medicago truncatula</em> orthologue has been characterized (<span id="ref34543790.25430977" class="cite">Pellizzaro <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>). An NRT2 homologue in wheat has been identifed and partially characterized (<span id="ref34555124.35781289" class="cite">Kumar <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>). Nitrate is the main form of inorganic nitrogen that crops absorb, and nitrate transporters 2 (NRT2) are high affinity nitrate uptake porters. When the available nitrate is limiting, the high affinity transport systems are activated. Most NRT2s cannot transport nitrates alone and require the assistance of helper proteins belonging to nitrate assimilation related family (NAR2; TC# 8.A.20.1.1) to complete the transport of nitrate (<span id="ref34557100.37584129" class="cite">Zhao <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). Crop nitrogen utilization efficiency is affected by environmental conditions, and there are differences between different plant varieties.&nbsp; <em>Sorghum bicolor</em> has high stress tolerance and is efficient in soil nitrogen utilization. The <em>S. bicolor </em>genome database was scanned for gene structures, chromosomal localizations, physicochemical properties, secondary structures and transmembrane domains, signal peptides and subcellular localizations, promoter region cis-acting elements, phylogenetic evolution, SNP recognition and annotation, and selection pressure of gene family members (<span id="ref34557100.37584129" class="cite">Zhao <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). Through bioinformatics analysis, 5 NRT2 gene members (designated as SbNRT2-1a, SbNRT2-1b, SbNRT2-2, SbNRT2-3, and SbNRT2-4) and 2 NAR2 gene members (designated SbNRT3-1 and SbNRT3-2) were identified, the number of which was less than that of foxtail millet. SbNRT2/3 could be divided into four subfamilies. All were present in the plasma membrane; SbNRT2 proteins lacked signal peptides, but SbNRT3 proteins contained them. Expression was responsive to plant hormones and stress response elements (<span id="ref34557100.37584129" class="cite">Zhao <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Plants</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>NRT2.1 of <em>Arabidopsis thaliana</em> (O82811)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.8.13"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.8.13&tcname=">2.A.1.8.13</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>High affinity nitrate/nitrite antiporter and uptake porter, NrtB (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref8116">Unkles <em>et al.</em>, 1991</a>; <a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref8157">2011</a>; <span id="ref10723.18024100" class="cite">Wang <em>et al.</em> 2008</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Fungi</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>NrtB of <em>Emericella (Aspergillus) nidulans</em>&nbsp;(Q8X193)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.8.14"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.8.14&tcname=">2.A.1.8.14</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Nitrate/nitrite uptake porter, NapA (<span id="ref8117.10692386" class="cite">Wang <em>et al.</em>, 2000</span>)</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Cyanobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>NapA of <em>Trichodesmium</em> sp. WH 9601 (Q9RA38)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.8.15"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.8.15&tcname=">2.A.1.8.15</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p>Probable nitrate transporter NarT</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>NarT of <em>Staphylococcus carnosus </em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.8.16"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.8.16&tcname=">2.A.1.8.16</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS porter of 430 aas</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS porter of <em>Rhizobium loti</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.8.17"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.8.17&tcname=">2.A.1.8.17</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Nitrate/nitrite transporter, NarK2, of 468 aas and 12 TMSs. The <em>narK1</em> and <em>narK2</em> genes are located in an operon, <em>narK1K2GHJI</em>, with the structural genes for the nitrate reductase complex.&nbsp; Utilizing an isogenic <em>narK1</em> mutant, a <em>narK2</em> mutant, and a <em>narK1K2</em> double mutant,&nbsp;<span>Sharma <em>et al.</em> 2006</span> explored the effect on growth under denitrifying conditions. While the <em>&Delta;narK1</em>::Gm mutant was only slightly affected, but both the &Delta;narK2::Gm and double mutants exhibited poor nitrate-dependent, anaerobic growth although all three strains had wild-type levels of nitrate reductase activity. Nitrate uptake measurements showed that NarK2 has most of the activity.&nbsp; <em>E. coli narK</em> rescued both mutants.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>NarK2 of <em>Pseudomonas aeruginosa</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.8.18"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.8.18&tcname=">2.A.1.8.18</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>NRT2.1 high affinity Na<sup>+</sup>-dependent nitrate uptake porter of 517 aas and 12 TMSs. It functions with the aoxillary protein, NAR2 (TC# 8.A.20.1.2) (<span id="ref34550012.31357380" class="cite">Rubio <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>). Functional characterization of the <em>GhNRT2.1e</em> gene revealed its role in improving nitrogen use efficiency in <em>Gossypium hirsutum</em> (<span id="ref34556204.37009157" class="cite">Zhang <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).<em><br /></em></p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>NTR2.1 of <em>Zostera marina</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.8.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.8.2&tcname=">2.A.1.8.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Nitrate uptake porter</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>NasA of <em>Bacillus subtilis</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.8.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.8.3&tcname=">2.A.1.8.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Nitrate/nitrite uptake porter</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>NrtP of <em>Synechococcus</em> PCC7002</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.8.4"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.8.4&tcname=">2.A.1.8.4</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Nitrate transporter</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Diatoms</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Nitrate porter of <em>Cylindrotheca fusiformis</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.8.5"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.8.5&tcname=">2.A.1.8.5</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Nitrate/nitrite transporter/antiporter, CrnA/NrtA (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref8116">Unkles <em>et al.</em>, 1991; </a><a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref10722">Beckham <em>et al.</em> 2010</a>). The nitrate signature sequences (NS1 and NS2) in TMSs 5 and 11 and arg residues in TMSs 2 and 8 may influence substrate binding (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref8890">Unkles <em>et al.</em>, 2012</a>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Fungi</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>CrnA of <em>Emericella nidulans</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.8.6"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.8.6&tcname=">2.A.1.8.6</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Nitrate transporter</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Algae</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Nitrate porter of <em>Chlamydomonas reinhardtii</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.8.7"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.8.7&tcname=">2.A.1.8.7</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a id="2.A.1.8"></a></p>

<p>High affinity&nbsp;Nitrate/nitrite uptake transporter, Nar4.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Algae</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a id="2.A.1.8"></a></p>

<p>Nar4 <span style="font-style: italic;">of Chlamydomonas reinhardtii (</span>A8J4P3)&nbsp;</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.8.8"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.8.8&tcname=">2.A.1.8.8</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>NO<sub>2</sub><sup>-</sup> extrusion, thermophilus</em> HB8</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.8.9"></A><A permease, NarK2</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>NarK2 of <em>Thermus thermophilus</em> HB8</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD (Cu-UP)</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><p>Most similar to TC# 2.A.1.2, MDR pumps.</p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.81.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.81.1&tcname=">2.A.1.81.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The copper (Cu<sup>2+</sup>) uptake porter, CcoA of 405 aas and 12 TMSs. CcoA-mediated
Cu<sup>2+</sup> import relies on conserved Met and His residues that could act as metal ligands at the membrane-embedded Cu<sup>2+</sup>-binding domain (<span id="ref34545016.26787831" class="cite">Khalfaoui-Hassani <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>). It provides cytoplasmic Cu needed for cbb3-type cytochrome c oxidase (cbb3-Cox) biogenesis (<span id="ref34553520.34281385" class="cite">Khalfaoui-Hassani <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>). Residues important for and/or esstential for function have been identified. CcoA undergoes a thiol:disulfide oxidoreduction cycle, which is important for its Cu import activity (<span id="ref34553520.34281385" class="cite">Khalfaoui-Hassani <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>CcoA of<em> Rhodobacter capsulatus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD ATP, GTP, TTP, CTP and NAD biind, with the highest affinity for NAD, in contrast to SV2 (TC# 2.A.1.22.1), which binds both
NAD and ATP with equal affinity. This family is most closely, but distantly related to the AAHS family (2.A.1.15).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>&delta;-Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MFS uptake permease of <em>Myxococcus xanthus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.86.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.86.2&tcname=">2.A.1.86.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p><a id="2.A.1.15.17"></a></p>
<p><a></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p><a id="2.A.1.15.17"></a></p>
<p>Fused protein with N-terminal transmembrane region of 7 putative TMSs and a C-terminal hydrophilic domain homologous to SAM-dependent spermidine synthase.&nbsp; The N-terminus of this protein shows extensive sequence similarity with 2.A.1.86.1 but shows weak similarity with other MFS permeases.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>&gamma;-Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Fused protein of <em>Thiocapsa marina</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.86.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.86.3&tcname=">2.A.1.86.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Uncharacterized protein of 512 aas and 7 TMSs.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>UP of <em>Candidatus Thiodiazotropha endoloripes</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.86.4"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.86.4&tcname=">2.A.1.86.4</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Uncharacterized putative S-adenosyl-L-methionine-dependent methyltransferase with a 7 TMS N-terminus (<span id="ref34547526.19859664" class="cite">Pegg and Michael CR_4</span></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=2.A.1.9">2.A.1.9 The Phosphate: H<sup>+</sup> Symporter (PHS) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.9.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.9.1&tcname=">2.A.1.9.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><span style="font-family: Times; font-size: small;"> </span></p>
<div style="color: #000000; font-family: Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 10px; background-image: initial; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: #ffffff; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; margin: 8px;">
<p>High affinity P<sub>i</sub>&nbsp;uptake porter, SUL1, Sul-1, SFP2 of 859 aas and 10 TMSs. (also functions in Mn<sup>2+</sup>&nbsp;homeostasis); may transport a phosphate&middot;Mn<sup>2+</sup>&nbsp;complex (<span id="ref2607.12923174" class="cite">Jensen&nbsp;<em>et al</em>., 2003</span>). Also takes up selenite (<span id="ref7554.20688911" class="cite">Lazard <em>et al.,&nbsp;</em>2010</span>).&nbsp; May be a "transceptor", combining transport and receptor functions (<span id="ref34546637.28357392" class="cite">Diallinas 2017</span>).</p>
</div>
<p>&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Yeast</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Pho84 of <em>Saccharomyces cerevisiae </em>(P25297)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.9.10"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.9.10&tcname=">2.A.1.9.10</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>High affinity (25 m&mu;M) phosphate uptake porter, PiPT (<span id="ref10062.20479005" class="cite">Yadav <em>et al.</em> 2010</span>).&nbsp; The high resolution structure has been determined by x-ray crystallography (<span id="ref10198.23542591" class="cite">Pedersen <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Fungi</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PiPT of <em>Piriformospora indica</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.9.11"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.9.11&tcname=">2.A.1.9.11</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Phosphate transporter, PT, of 543 aas and 12 TMSs. It has a micormolar Km for phosphate uptake, is found in the plasma membrane and is induced by low medium phosphate concentrations (<span id="ref11123.24863474" class="cite">Wang <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Fungi</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PT in the ectomycorrhizal fungus, <em>Boletus edulis</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.9.12"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.9.12&tcname=">2.A.1.9.12</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Phosphate transporter and receptor (transceptor) of 543 aas and 12 TMSs.&nbsp; Important for signalling and uptake of phosphate.&nbsp; The majority of terrestrial vascular plants can form mutualistic associations with
obligate biotrophic arbuscular mycorrhizal (AM) fungi from the phylum Glomeromycota. This
mutualistic symbiosis provides carbohydrates to the fungus, and reciprocally improves plant
phosphate uptake. AM fungal transporters can acquire phosphate from the soil through the hyphal
networks.&nbsp;<span id="ref34546201.27688206" class="cite">Xie <em>et al.</em> 2016</span> reported a high-affinity phosphate transporter GigmPT that is required for AM
symbiosis. GigmPT functions as a phosphate transceptor for
the activation of the phosphate signaling pathway as well as the protein kinase A signaling cascade.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PT of <em>Gigaspora margarita</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.9.13"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.9.13&tcname=">2.A.1.9.13</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>H<span class=""recommended-name"">igh-affinity phosphate transporter of 511 aas and 12 TMSs, PHT1.&nbsp; It is root inducible by phosphate starvation but is not expressed in leaves (<span id=""ref34548071.29653435"" class=""cite"">Ahmadi <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). &nbsp;&nbsp; <br /></span></p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PHT1 of <em>Elaeis guineensis </em>var. tenera (Oil palm)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.9.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.9.2&tcname=">2.A.1.9.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Phosphate-repressible, high affinity P<sub>i</sub> uptake porter, Pho84 or Pho-5 of 570 aas and 12 TMSs (<span id="ref34550907.7883177" class="cite">Versaw 1995</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Fungi</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Pho-84 of <em>Neurospora crassa </em>(Q7RVX9)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.9.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.9.3&tcname=">2.A.1.9.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>P<sub>i</sub> uptake porter.  Four close paralogues in <em>Medicago truncatula </em>(PT1-4), all localized to roots, show differing affinities for phosphate (<span id="ref6315.18596039" class="cite">Liu <em>et al.</em> 2008</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Plants</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PT1 of <em>Solanum tuberosum</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.9.4"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.9.4&tcname=">2.A.1.9.4</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Pht1;2(1;4) (PT2), a low affinity Pi uptake transporter, functioning throughout the plant (<span id="ref6684.18980647" class="cite">Ai <em>et al.</em>, 2009</span>) (76% identical to 2.A.1.9.3).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Plants</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Pht1;2(1;4) of <em>Oryza sativa </em>(Q01MW8)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.9.5"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.9.5&tcname=">2.A.1.9.5</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Pht1;6 (PT6), a high affinity Pi uptake transporter, functioning thoughout the plant (<span id="ref6684.18980647" class="cite">Ai <em>et al.</em>, 2009</span>) (75% identical to  2.A.1.9.3)</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Plants</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Pht1;6 (PT6) of <em>Oryza sativa</em> (Q8H6H0)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.9.6"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.9.6&tcname=">2.A.1.9.6</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Phosphate transporter-5, PT5. Catalyzes phosphate:H<sup>+</sup>&nbsp;symport (<span id="ref7021.18174027" class="cite">Liu <em>et al.</em>, 2008</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Plants</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PT5 of <em>Medicago truncatula</em>&nbsp;(A5H2U6)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.9.7"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.9.7&tcname=">2.A.1.9.7</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Organic phosphate (glycerophosphoinositol and glycerophosphocholine,
 the products of phospholipase-B mediated deacylation of 
phosphatidylinositol and phosphatidylcholine, respectively) transport protein GIT1 (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=2.A.1#ref11266">Almaguer <em>et al.</em> 2006</a>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Fungi</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>GIT1 of <em>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.9.8"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.9.8&tcname=">2.A.1.9.8</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Putative inorganic phosphate transporter C23D3.12</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Yeast</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>SPAC23D3.12 of <em>Schizosaccharomyces pombe  </em></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="2.A.1.9.9"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=2.A.1.9.9&tcname=">2.A.1.9.9</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Inorganic phosphate transporter 1-1 (AtPht1;1; APT2, PHT1) (H<sup>+</sup>/Pi cotransporter).&nbsp; A <em>Brassica napus</em> homologue, Pht1;4, catalyzes phosphate uptake and affects root architecture (<span id="ref11310.25194430" class="cite">Ren <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>). The phylogeny and expression levels in plant tissues of the proteins of this family in potato have been examined (<span id="ref34547499.29055693" class="cite">Liu <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>). The chrysanthemum Pht1;2 is induced in the roots by phosphate starvation (<span id="ref34548776.30079072" class="cite">Liu <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). It is induced by low inorganic phosphate in <em>Spirodela polyrrhiza</em>, a floating plant widely used in biomass utilization and eutrophication phytoremediation (<span id="ref34553530.34327912" class="cite">Deng <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>). There are five PHT families in <em>A. thaliana</em>, Pht1 - 5, not all of which are homologous; 57 PHTs are present in soybean (<em>Glycine max</em>), belonging to the PHT1 - 5 families with TC#s (1) 2.A.1.9, (2) 2.A.20, (3) 2.A.29, (4) 2.A.1.14 and (5) 2.A.1.2.61 (<span id="ref34555645.36463363" class="cite">Wei <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Plants</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PHT1-1 of <em>Arabidopsis thaliana </em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4
